A time period from 2500 to 538.8 million years ago
A time period from 2.58 million years ago to the present
A time period from 208.5 to 201.4 million years ago
A time period from 443.8 to 440.8 million years ago
A time period from 2300 to 2050 million years ago
A time period from 273.01 to 266.9 million years ago
A time period from 33.9 to 27.82 million years ago
A time period from 293.51 to 290.1 million years ago
A time period from 458.4 to 453.0 million years ago
A time period from 86.3 to 83.6 million years ago
A time period from 61.6 to 59.2 million years ago
A time period from 330.9 to 323.2 million years ago
A time period from 13.82 to 11.63 million years ago
A time period from 433.4 to 430.5 million years ago
A time period from 2500 to 2300 million years ago
A time period from 443.8 to 419.2 million years ago
A time period from 199.5 to 192.9 million years ago
A time period from 1800 to 1600 million years ago
A time period from 1200 to 1000 million years ago
A time period from 438.5 to 433.4 million years ago
A time period from 538.8 to 521 million years ago
A time period from 59.2 to 56.0 million years ago
A time period from 149.2 to 145 million years ago
A time period from 184.2 to 174.7 million years ago
A time period from 1000 to 720 million years ago
A time period from 11.63 to 7.246 million years ago
A time period from 358.9 to 346.7 million years ago
A time period from 485.4 to 477.7 million years ago
A time period from 251.902 to 201.4 million years ago
A time period from 93.9 to 89.8 million years ago
A time period from 132.6 to 139.8 million years ago
A time period from 346.7 to 330.9 million years ago
A time period from 433.4 to 427.4 million years ago
A time period from 266.9 to 264.28 million years ago
A time period from 259.51 to 254.14 million years ago
A time period from 509 to 504.5 million years ago
A time period from 56.0 to 47.8 million years ago
A time period from 5.333 to 3.6 million years ago

Rock surfaces (~30 m thick) that are etched (e.g. with acid) and embedded in sheets of cellulose acetate. This method is generally used to study features on cut core surfaces, especially at scales where a thin section is impractical.
An object made by a human being, such as a tool or a decoration, especially one that is of cultural or historical interest.
Any gemstone consisting of two or more parts, whether natural, synthetic, imitation, or a combination thereof; e.g. a doublet or triplet.
Rock sample removed from the end of a drillbit when it is brought to surface, assumed to be from the total depth of the current well interval.
A smaller fraction of material (e.g. rock, regolith, sediment) that is considered to sufficiently represent certain characteristics of the parent material.

An unfaceted cut gemstone of domed or convex form. The top is smoothly polished; the back, or base, is usually flat or slightly convex, sometimes concave, and often unpolished. The girdle outline may be round, oval, square, or of any other shape.

Any Earth material shaped into a decorative form (e.g. sphere, egg, free-form, etc.) using tools to scrape away portions of that material. The technique can be applied to any material that is solid enough to hold a form even when pieces have been removed from it, and yet soft enough for portions to be scraped away with available tools.

An object formed by pouring metal, plaster, fiberglass, etc., in a fluid state into a mold and letting it harden. Casts are usually made of objects (natural or artefacts) that have a special significance or scientific/monetary value due to their nature, size, rarity and provenance (e.g. nugget, meteorite, fossil); casts are also made to limit the handling of original specimens or for display purposes (e.g. for heave specimens).

Pieces ofrockthat came from the borehole but that were not removed directly by the action of thedrillbit. Cavings can be splinters, shards, chunks, and various shapes of rock, usually spalling fromshalesections that have become unstable. The shape of the caving can indicate why the rock failure occurred. The term is typically used in the plural form.
A sample comprising loose mineral grains that have been concentrated relative to the parent material using a sample preparation technique, such as heavy liquid, magnetic or electrostatic separation.

A hard, compact mass or aggregate of mineral matter, normally subspherical but ranging from oblate to irregular; formed by precipitation from aqueous solution about a nucleus or centre (e.g. a shell or fossil), in the pores of a sedimentary or fragmental volcanic rock, and usually of a composition widely different from that of the rock in which it is found and from which it is rather sharply separated. It ranges in size from a small pellet-like object to a great spheroidal body as much as 3 m in diameter. Most concretions were formed during diagenesis, and many shortly after sediment deposition.
Rock chips or fragments derived from a drillcore of any type after drilling.

A block cut from whole, half or quartered conventional core for petrophysical analysis. Typically starting pieces are up to 20 cm in length and may be cut shorter for further sampling depending on the techniques being applied.
A plug cut from a conventionalcorefor analysis.
A coarse crushed rock sample comprising sub-centimetre sized chips. Often produced to generate a material fine enough to be pulverized into a powder, often for the purpose of geochemical analysis.

The homogeneous, solid body of a chemical element, compound, or isomorphous mixture whose constituents (such as atoms, molecules, or ions) are arranged in a highly ordered microscopic structure, forming an ordered lattice that extends in all directions; this regularly repeating atomic arrangement may be outwardly expressed by plane faces. Although a crystal is characterized first by its definite internal molecular structure and second by its external form, the term is generally used in reference to a mineral specimen that is at least partially defined by its geometrical shape consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic orientations (i.e. natural external crystalline plane faces).

A group of mineral crystals formed in an open space environment and exhibiting a euhedral crystal form determined by their internal crystal structure; or a specimen derived from it. A cluster of small crystals coating the walls of a cavity is called a druse. From a collecting perspective, crystal cluster can also refer to a group of crystals obtained from the removal of matrix to expose well-formed crystals.

Broken piece(s) of a single crystal or crystal cluster. The breakage process can be either natural (i.e. due to geological factors/events) or artificial (e.g. occurring during sampling or specimen preparation).
Ateaching aid used for understanding crystallographyconcepts and the morphology ofcrystals, especially used for teaching/recognizing symmetry elements in crystals.
A hand sample or block with at least one side cut with a rock saw, which has not been polished.

Rock chips or fragments retrieved during the drilling of a petroleum well, usually mixed with drilling fluid residue. Can be either 'unwashed' when collected straight from the well, 'washed' when rinsed to remove drilling fluid residue, and/or 'dried' if cleaned and processed to remove moisture.

A gem substitute composed of two pieces of gem material, or one of gem material and a second of glass or synthetic, fused or cemented together; e.g. a glass imitation with a thin layer of natural gemstone (e.g. opal) fused on the top.
Rock chips or fragments derived from drilling whereby the primary sampling methodology is fragmentation of the material prior to recovery.
A mixture of rock chips or fragments generated during a borehole/well construction. Drill cuttings are generated by the action of the drill bit and brought to the surface by drilling fluids.
A specimen (usually, but not always, cylindrical) of rock and/or regolith.
A sample of the fluid used for drilling (mainly drillbit lubrication) and for return of ground rock material from the bottom of the drilling interval, e.g. drilling mud.
A mount created by pouring or 'dumping' material such as minerals or rock pieces/fragments onto a mounting medium such as resin, i.e. there is no hand picking of grains.

A mineral or rock where apattern or design has been cut into or appears on asmoothsurface, generated by usingacidor asharp instrument, or by removing the rock surface coating. Typical of meteorite surfaces cut, polished and treated to expose Widmansttten figures, but can also occur naturally in minerals due to the action of fluids.
A raw, uncut gemstone that is suitable for faceting; e.g. a rough diamond.

A precious or semi-precious gemstone that has been cut and shaped with multiple flat surfaces, known as facets, to enhance its brilliance and optical properties. These facets are geometrically arranged and polished to maximize the gemstone's ability to reflect and refract light, usually resulting in a dazzling display of colours and sparkle. Opaque materials can also be faceted.

In mineralogical terms, a 'floater' is a single crystal or aggregate of crystals that is not attached to a host rock / hard matrix, and has no obvious indication that it has been removed from matrix. All sides of floater crystals are usually fully intact without damage, as they don't have a fractured attachment point. Floaters can form when crystals grow within a matrix that is either soft or subsequently removed (such as from a clay); or it may be a crystal that formed attached to matrix but was subsequently detached during tectonic activity, with the broken attachment point later re-healed or extended by a secondary mineralization event. The term is generally not used for crystals that have been freed from hard matrix, such as garnets removed from schist, whether such removal was natural or artificial. Not to be confused with 'float', a loose rock collected at the surface of the Earth.
Any liquid or gas sampled during downhole sampling processes or at the surface.
A sample of any fluid that occurs in the pores and fractures of arock, such as various saturations of oil, gas and water.

Any mineral or naturally occurring substance that, when cut and polished, has sufficient beauty, rarity, and durability for use as a personal adornment or other ornament. Organic materials such as pearl are considered gem materials rather than gemstones. Because of their desirability and demand, synthetic and imitation gemstones are common replacements for natural gemstones.
A polished mount created from minerals such as zircon for the purpose of geochronology.

A geode is a globular/spherical to irregular mass of resistant mineral matter that is usually hollow and partially to completely filled with crystals. Completely infilled geodes are often referred to asnodules, but the two names are not always consistently used: geodes differ from nodules in that a nodule is a solid mass of mineral matter, but some nodules may have a tiny void space in their interiors and the distinction between a geode and a nodule may be barely discernible if the cavity is miniscule. Geodes differ fromvugs in that geodes can be separated free from any matrix, because their walls commonly weather out of rock exposures. Unlike adruse,a geode is separable (by weathering) as a discrete concretion from the rock in which it occurs, and its inner crystals are not of the same minerals as those of the enclosing rock. The crystals lining a geode are formed by the filling of vesicles in volcanic and subvolcanic rocks by minerals deposited from hydrothermal fluids; or by the dissolution of syngenetic concretions and partial filling by the same or other minerals precipitated from water, groundwater, or hydrothermal fluids in sedimentary rocks.
An individual particle, either a mineral or fossil, sampled directly from an outcrop, drillcore or environment, or obtained from a concentrate, and stored in an unmounted state.
A mount created from loose mineral grains that have been hand picked for the purpose of imaging or analysis.

Portable, self-contained rock, fossil, regolith or mineral specimen collected for analysis and/or conservation. Hand samples are of a size that is convenient for megascopic study and for preserving in a study collection. The term 'hand sample' is generally applied to materials collected from outcrop but could also be taken from other landscape features. Hand samples are generally selected to be representative of a particular area, lithology, assemblage or outcrop.
A sample comprising loose mineral grains with a density of 2.9 g/cm or greater that have been concentrated relative to the parent material usually using a technique called heavy liquid separation.
A polished dump mount created from a heavy mineral concentrate (minerals with a density greater than 2.9 g/cm).
Gemstones made from materials that look (or have been treated to look) like real gemstones but have different chemical compositions and properties (cf. synthetic gemstone).

A strew slide prepared for transmitted light microscopy, where the original sediment sample is treated to retain all non-soluble organic matter. This compares to strew slides prepared for palynostratigraphy, where samples are oxidized prior to mounting to remove extraneous organic matter such as inertinite and vitrinite in order to highlight the assemblage of palynomorphs. As a result, kerogen slides are often generated alongside palynostratigraphic strew slides.

Lapidary rough is raw gemstone material used for various types of cutting and shaping, to create cabochons, carvings, beads, and other decorative items. Many different types of stones can be used as lapidary rough, including agate, jasper, turquoise and quartz.
A copy of a three-dimensional form, particularly a fossil or rock surface, made in molding latex.
A sample comprising loose mineral grains with a density of less than 2.9 g/cm that have been concentrated relative to the parent material usually using a technique called heavy liquid separation.
A slide prepared for microscope analysis of microfossils, where picked specimens are mounted on a numbered grid backing for identification.

Separated or isolated microfossil mounted on a backing in preparation for imaging or analysis. This term is preferred when the form of the mount is unknown, and is a partial equivalent of SEM mount / SEM stub where the mounted material is a fossil prepared for SEM microscopy. Gridded slides and well slides are occasionally referred to as mounts or mounted slides but are better considered as slide types.
Remains of sample prepared for microfossil studies, usually stored as dried sediment. Residues may be picked (i.e. depleted of specific fossils separated for analysis) or unpicked.
A slide prepared for microscope analysis of microfossils, where picked specimens are contained within one (or a series of) circular wells, often unfixed.

Any single or group of crystals (with or without matrix) that requires optical aid to be appreciated, commonly a hand-lens or a binocular microscope with a 1040 times magnification. A micromount is permanently mounted in some kind of box and labelled with the name of the mineral and the location from which it came. Proper mounting both preserves delicate crystals and facilitates their handling. The term is used mostly by mineral collectors and amateur geologists.
A facsimile representation of an object, site or location; usually in three dimensions and often at a different scale.
A three-dimensional shape built in order to generate a cast and thus reproduce objects of special significance/value (e.g. nugget, meteorite, fossil) and limit the handling of original specimens

A sample that has been prepared for viewing/analysis/storage by either securely attaching the specimen(s) to a suitable fixed point (e.g. a slide or support) and/or by using appropriate mounting compounds/media (with or without polishing) to encapsulate specimens and hold them securely in place.

A small, irregularly rounded knot, mass, or lump of a mineral or mineral aggregate, normally having a warty or knobby surface and no internal structure, and usually exhibiting a contrasting composition from the enclosing sediment or rock matrix in which it is/was embedded.
A lump of gold or other precious metal found ready-formed in surficial deposits.
Small sections of rock cut off a larger block or core.
A sample type that does not fit into any other category.

Remains of sample prepared for palynological analysis but not mounted on slides. Palynology residues are generally suspended in liquids for storage, normally glycerine. Although the term 'residue' can be applied to materials at any part of the preparation process, the term is most often applied to the final concentration which is stored.

A core taken from the side of a borehole by shooting hollow, retrievable, cylindrical bullets into the formation. With full recovery, cores from typical percussion tools are 2.5 cm in diameter and between 4.4 and 5.0 cm long. Due to the shattering or compression of the sample during collection, percussion sidewall cores cannot be used for qualitative measurements such as porosity and permeability.
A small fragment of rock remaining from the preparation of a thin section.
Acopy of a three-dimensional form, particularly fossils, made in plaster.
Materials set in a medium, typically an epoxy glue or resin, and polished.
A thick slice of rock/mineral with a smooth and shiny/glossy surface that enhances the colour, texture and general appearance of the material.

Natural rocks, (gem)stones or Earth materials that have undergone a meticulous process of grinding and polishing with progressively finer abrasive materials to create a smooth surface with a significant specular reflection /enhanced lustre. This method enhances their surface, bringing out the natural colours and patterns found within the specimen.
Any Earth material that has been modified and prepared, either by incision, by rubbing or by applying a chemical treatment, usually to create a smooth and shiny/glossy surface.
A rock sample that has been pulverised to a very fine powder and homogenized to be representative of a parent sample, or interval, often for the purpose of geochemical analysis.
An expertly crafted reproduction of a natural, cultural or historical item, made to resemble the original while preserving its cultural or scientific significance.
A sample of fluids found in the reservoir formation of a well.
Unspecified material leftover from sample preparation or an analytical technique.
Rock chips or fragments derived from reverse circulation (RC) drilling.
Rock fragments derived from crushing or chipping material other than by drilling (e.g. chips from an outcrop or mine channel sampling).
Rock chips or fragments derived from rotary air blast (RAB) drilling.

A core taken from the side of a borehole using mechanical sidewall coring tools. Hollow rotary drills cut and extract core plugs that, with full recovery, are usually between 2.3  2.4 cm in diameter by 4.5  5.0 cm long. Also known as mechanical sidewall core.
A raw piece of Earth material (mineral, rock, etc.) with the potential to be cut and polished/faceted into a gemstone.

Ore material in a ball mill or sag mill that has become rounded and no longer susceptible to additional size reduction. The term 'scat' is also a synonym for faecal material but is different to the use of the term in a mining sense.
Separated or isolated fossil(s), mineral(s) or rock fragment(s) mounted (i.e. attached) to a metal pin or backing in preparation for imaging or analysis in a scanning electron microscope (SEM).

A sample comprising loose grains (usually minerals but could be fossils) that have been separated from their parent material by manual selection under a microscope. Often done for the purpose of undertaking detailed analysis on a particular mineral, e.g. zircon, phosphate or baddeleyite geochronology.
A hand sample or block that has been sliced into a set of slabs in order to examine sequential changes in internal features or structure.

A set of slides prepared for visual microscopic inspection, where each slide preserves an individual section cut in sequence from a larger sample or specimen, normally to examine complex internal structures.

Acoretaken from the side of theborehole, usually by awirelinetool.These samples can provide useful details of the lithology, petrology, biostratigraphy, organic geochemistry, porosity, permeability, and hydrocarbon content of the formation.

A macroscopic or microscopic crystal usually identifiable by its geometric shape, and consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic orientations/geometry that reflect its crystalline system of formation; a crystal in which all parts have the same crystallographic orientation and the crystal lattice of the entire sample is continuous and unbroken to the edges of the sample with no grain boundaries.
A sample comprising loose particles of a specified size range that has been separated, split or fractionated from a bulk parent material, often using various sizes of sieves.
A thick slice of rock material that can range in size from hand sample (centimetres to tens of centimetres) to several metres.
A thin, rectangular piece ofglassused to hold samples to be studied under amicroscope
A slide prepared for microscopy by smearing geological materials across the surface of a glass slide and affixing in place. The smear may or may not be covered by a thin glass coverslip.

A slide prepared for transmitted light microscopy through the suspension of separated materials (such as spores and pollen) in a mounting medium after chemical processing such as disaggregation and oxidization. Generally used for palynological analysis but may also be used to prepare other fossils or geological materials.

A gemstone that is physically, optically, and chemically identical to a natural stone, but is created in a laboratory (e.g. synthetic rutile or strontium titanate have been used to replicate the sparkle of diamond).

A translucent section of geological material prepared for microscope analysis. The rock slice is almost always glued to a glass slide backing and may or may not be covered in a thin glass coverslip. Thick sections are more than 30 m in thickness, normally 100 m.
A polished translucent section of geological material prepared for microscope analysis that is greater than 30 m in thickness, normally 100 m.

A translucent section of geological material prepared for microscope analysis. The rock slice is almost always glued to a glass slide backing, and may or may not be covered in a thin glass coverslip. Thin sections are generally ground to 30 m in thickness.
A polished thin section of a material without a coverslip prepared for analysis.
A small block of rock cut from a hand sample or core section for the preparation of a standard thin section and typically to fit on a standard petrographic slide with dimensions of around 27 x 46 mm.

An assembled stonecomposed of three bonded parts of natural or manufactured gem materials designed to imitate natural gems; or two main pieces and a coloured cement layer (the third part of the triplet), which gives the stone colour.

Small, rounded, brightly polished pieces of rocks and minerals (usually semiprecious or precious stones), made by placing rough fragments in a barrel-shaped vessel (a rock tumbler), which rotates and tumbles them until their sharp edges are rounded and surfaces are smooth and polished.

A sample comprising loosely arranged, solid particulate material, such as sediment, soil or dust, that has not undergone significant compaction, cementation or lithification. The term is reserved for materials in which the primary sample is unconsolidated, i.e. not broken down during sample preparation processes (e.g. crushing).
The sample type is not known. Typically, this refers to samples that have been lost and for which there is no other specification.
The sample type has not been specified.
Alteration that selectively replaces specific bands within rocksXX.
Alteration that selectively replaces specific beds within sedimentary rocks.
Alteration associated with a fissure containing cemented wallrock fragments.
Alteration associated with a fault displaying angular rock fragments resulting from fracturing.
Alteration spatially associated with a fault.
Alteration confined to volumes of rocks exhibiting a foliation.
Alteration spatially associated with a fracture, i.e. with any break/separation in a geological formation with or without relative displacement of the parts (e.g. a joint or a fault).
Alteration spatially associated with a breccia.
Alteration restricted to compositionally or texturally defined layers within rocks.

Alteration that has replaced or filled in only certain portions of the rock at the scale of observation (e.g. the envelopes around veins), certain primary minerals, or pore spaces (including vesicles and interclast voids).
Alteration characterized by the replacement of most, or all, original rock-forming minerals and obliteration of textures at the scale of observation.

Alteration characterized by the replacement of only specific components (e.g. minerals, grains, clasts) of the original rock, with partial to complete obliteration of textures at the scale of observation.

Alteration characterized by the replacement of only specific components (e.g. minerals, grains, clasts) of the original rock, with partial to complete obliteration of textures only in part of the area under observation.

Alteration characterized by the replacement of only specific components (e.g. minerals, grains, clasts) of the original rock, with partial to complete obliteration of textures across the whole area of observation.
Alteration spatially associated with a shear zone.
Alteration spatially restricted to rocks within and/or immediately adjacent to structures such as shear zones, fault zones, veins, hydrothermal breccias, vugs or fractures.
A rock with no visible signs of alteration, in which primary minerals, fabrics (including primary pore space) and chemistry are unchanged.
Alteration that occurs at or around an unconformable or disconformable contact.
Alteration spatially associated with a vein.
Alteration associated with small cavities in a vein or rock, usually lined with crystals of a different mineral composition from the enclosing rock.
Alteration that can be divided spatially into several mineralogically or texturally distinct regions, with systematic variations in mineral assemblages, compositions and/or textures.
The central region of an alteration zone
The inner region of an alteration zone.
The outer region of an alteration zone.
Intense alteration refers to an almost complete to complete replacement of the primary minerals and obliteration of original textures.
Moderate intensity indicates alteration in which several of the primary mineral species have been replaced, with some modification of the original textures.
Strong intensity indicates alteration in which the majority of the primary minerals have been replaced, with considerable modification of the original textures.
A rock with no visible signs of alteration, in which primary minerals, fabrics (including primary pore space) and chemistry are unchanged.
Alteration intensity not specified.
Weak, or low, intensity indicates alteration in which only a few of the primary mineral species have been replaced, with little or no modification of the original textures.

A form of sodic alteration in which primary minerals (alkali feldspar) are replaced by albite to form albite-rich rocks (e.g. albitites). This type of alteration is usually associated with rare element mineralization (Nb, Ta, Sn, W, Li, Be). Cf. sodic alteration.

Ateration that involves the transfer of alkali ions (Na and K) from a fluid phase to adjacent rocks, i.e. the interaction of alkali (K or Na)-rich fluids with country rocks to form albite or potassium feldspar.

A type of advanced argillic alteration where alunite-group minerals (alunite, natroalunite and jarosite) are the dominant phase. Typically related to the presence of abundant sulfate ions and Al-rich protoliths.

Alteration that introduces clay minerals including kaolinite, smectite and illite as a replacement of plagioclase and amphibole due to intense H+ metasomatism and acid leaching, at temperatures between 100 and 300C.

A type of argillic alteration defined by intensive acid attack and more or less complete leaching of the alkali cations with complete destruction of the feldspars and mafic silicate phases, resulting in an assemblage of dickite, kaolinite, pyrophillite, baryte, alunite and diaspore. In addition, sulfides, topaz, tourmaline and a range of amorphous clays may be present. Found in porphyry systems, in the inner zone of hydrothermal base and precious metal-bearing veins, and most typically in high-sulfur hydrothermal systems.

A type of argilllic alteration defined by the presence of montmorillonite, illite, chlorite, kaolin group clays (kaolinite, dickite, halloysite, allophane) and minor sericite. K-feldspar may remain unaltered, and K, Ca, Mg and Na may not entirely leach out. Precursor textures are usually preserved.
The formation of biotite in country rocks, usually in early stages of hydrothermal events and commonly as a replacement of ferromagnesian minerals.

Alteration defined by calcium-bearing silicate minerals such as diopside and wollastonite. Calcsilicate skarn or hornfels are typical within impure limestone or dolomite strata adjacent to an intruding igneous rock.

Carbonate alteration involving the precipitation of calcite. Note the term is most commonly used to describe the replacement of organic material (generally originally hard part) by calcium carbonate (CaCO) during fossilization, as well as the pedological accumulation of calcium carbonate within soil horizons.
Alteration of both Ca-rich and silicate rock involving anion metasomatism with introduction of CO and formation or replacement of carbonate minerals.

The formation of chlorite is typical of many hydrothermal systems, particularly in peripheral propylitic alteration or as retrograde overprinting alteration, commonly as a replacement of pyroxene and amphibole minerals or biotite.

The reactions between primary magmatic minerals and the water-rich solutions that separate from the same body of magma at a late stage in its cooling history (with, for example, pyroxene being replaced by amphibole).

Alteration of limestones involving cation metasomatism and base metal exchange, in which Mg2+ substitutes for Ca2+, and calcite (CaCO3) becomes dolomite [CaMg(CO3)2]. Usually through action of magnesium-bearing water (seawater or percolating meteoric water).

The formation of epidote in country rocks by hydrothermal alteration. Also refers to the alteration of rocks in which plagioclase feldspar is albitized, whereby the anorthite molecule is freed for the formation of epidote and zoisite (a process often accompanied by chloritization).
A form of alkali metasomatism of quartzofeldspathic country rocks in the environs of carbonatite complexes.

Alteration involving the destabilization and destruction of feldspars and biotite to form the assemblage quartz + muscovite with varying amounts of topaz, tourmaline, fluorite oxides (cassiterite, hematite, wolframite, scheelite and sulfides of Fe, Cu, Mo, Bi), and CuBiPb sulfosalts. Common in continental porphyry systems and with granitic intrusions within argillaceousarenaceous rock sequences, and with SnW mineralization systems.

Localized high-temperature alteration involving the destabilization and destruction of feldspars and biotite to form quartz and muscovite with varying amounts of topaz, tourmaline, lepidolite, fluorite, oxides (cassiterite, hematite, wolframite, scheelite), sulfides of Fe, Cu, Mo, Bi, and CuBiPb sulfosalts.

Alteration caused by oxidizing fluids resulting in the formation of hematite and some K-feldspar, sericite, chlorite and epidote. The term 'red rock alteration' is not recommended for use in describing alteration, as it does not qualify the mineral changes in the rock (e.g. Na or K enrichment) and may be confused with oxidation processes more typical of weathering.

Advanced silicahematite alteration, examples of which are known only from the Proterozoic rocks of the Bryah, Padbury and Yerrida Basins (formerly Glengarry Basin) in Australia. These jasperoids are hard, purple to dark purple rocks composed primarily of amethyst quartz and fine disseminated hematite and some magnetite.
The presence of alteration is recognized but does not fit into any other category.
Used to indicate that no information is available on alteration.
The presence of alteration is noted, but the type of alteration is not otherwise classified or described.

A type of hematitic alteration defined by complete replacement of limestone, and occasionally other rock types, by fine-grained quartz; commonly associated with brecciation. Involves oxidation of minerals and the formation of hematite (hematitic jasperoids), in some cases with considerable amounts of pyrite (sulfidic jasperoids).

The replacement or breakdown of silicate minerals to form kaolinite and other kaolinite-group minerals (e.g. dickite), typically in acid to intermediate rocks. Kaolinization is observed in the marginal argillic zone of high-sulfidation systems, as well as in near-surface, steam-heated environments, in vein-type deposits, as massive argillic alteration zones of low-sulfidation epithermal environments, and in greisen and derived pegmatites and aplites. Kaolinite can also form during supergene weathering, but dickite is restricted to hydrothermal environments.

Alteration involving carbonatization and variable silicification of ultramafic (mainly peridotites and serpentinites) and mafic rocks, resulting in the formation of magnesium carbonate  quartz  mica (fuchsite) rocks. Listvenites are associated with gold mineralization and have potential for carbon storage due to the fast kinetics of carbonation reactions in serpentinized peridotites.

Alteration typified by the assemblage quartzsericitepyrite (QSP) typically resulting from removal of sodium, calcium, and magnesium from calc-alkalic rocks, with pervasive replacement of silicates by micaceous phyllosilicates, muting the original rock texture. It is a common style of alteration in porphyry base-metal systems around a central zone of potassic alteration. More specifically, it relates to hydrogen-ion (H+) metasomatism of silicate minerals such as K-feldspar, plagioclase and biotite.

High-temperature alteration resulting in the formation of K-feldspar and biotite (porphyry systems), and adularia (epithermal systems), from the replacement of plagioclase and mafic silicate minerals. It is usually accompanied by sulfides  anhydrite  biotite.

Alteration characterized by the addition of H20 and CO2, and locally S, with no appreciable H+ metasomatism. Typically results in the formation of epidote, chlorite, Mg-Fe-Ca carbonates, albite, K-feldspar and pyrite. In some systems, propylitic alteration is mineralogically zoned from inner actinolite-rich to outer epidote-rich alteration.
Alteration of country rocks due to the ionic replacement by iron and sulfur atoms combining to form pyrite.

Metasomatic alteration typical of dykes and mafic rocks in contact with or proximal to serpentinized ultramafic rocks. The mafic rocks are altered by high pH, Ca2+ and OH fluids, which are a byproduct of the serpentinization process, and become rodingites, i.e. metasomatic rocks rich in grossularandradite garnet, calcic pyroxene, and variable amounts of vesuvianite, epidote and scapolite.

Alteration of calcium-bearing plagioclase feldspar to a characteristic assemblage of minerals called saussurite. The typical assemblage includes albite (or oligoclase), zoisite or epidote, together with variable amounts of calcite, sericite, prehnite, and calcium-aluminium silicates other than those of the epidote group. The plagioclase may be reconstituted into a more sodium-rich variety (albite), although the original form of the crystal is usually retained. Typically related to residual fluids in the late stages of magmatic crystallization or hydrothermal alteration, and especially common in mafic rocks due to their high calcium content.

A hydrothermal or deuteric (or metamorphic) process involving the introduction of, alteration to, or replacement by 'sericite', i.e. the formation of fine-grained white mica (e.g. sericite, phengite or paragonite) in country rocks. See also Phyllic (QSP) alteration.
Replacement of magnesium-rich silicate minerals (e.g. olivine, pyroxenes, or amphiboles) in dunites, peridotites or other ultramafic rocks by serpentine minerals.
The replacement or breakdown of silicate minerals by reaction with free silica. Not to be confused with silicification.

Silicification or silicic alteration is hydrothermal alteration in which the quartz, opal, chalcedony, jasper, or other forms of amorphous silica content of the rock increases. Commonly caused by a net addition of silica in the altered rock, but silicification may also occur by decomposition reactions where quartz is a byproduct (desilication) or by cation leaching in silica-stable systems. Silicification involves dissolution of rock minerals and precipitation of silica, but the term can also refer to the permeation process that occurs during petrification of organic materials (e.g. to create fossil wood). Not to be confused with silication.

The alteration of pure limestone and dolomite by introduction of Si, Al, Fe and Mg. Typical skarn minerals include pyroxene, garnet, vesuvianite, wollastonite, actinolite, magnetite or hematite, epidote and scapolite.

Generally forms replacement zones in wallrocks (exoskarn - in limestone or occasionally mafic to intermediate volcanic rocks), or within intrusions (endoskarn). Andradite and diopside occur in oxidized assemblages related to porphyry Cu systems; grossular and hedenbergite are more common in reduced skarns (Au, W, and Sn).

Metasomatic replacement of dolomitic limestone. High-temperature magnesian skarns are characterized by forsterite and diopside and low-temperature magnesian skarns contain serpentinite and talc. Both occur as retrograde minerals after forsterite and clinopyroxene.

The overprinting of earlier (prograde) skarn alteration in the form of epidote, amphibole, chlorite, and other hydrous phases. It is typically structurally controlled and more pronounced in shallow environments; but may also affect adjacent wallrock limestone.
Alteration commonly found in deeper parts of porphyry systems and defined by albite (sodic plagioclase) and actinolite. Cf. albitic alteration.
Sulfide mineral alteration of country rocks, i.e. the deposition of pyrite and other sulfides (e.g. pyrrhotite, chalcopyrite, etc.) by hydrothermal processes.
Silicasulfide alteration of dolomites resulting in hard, dense purple-black rocks with considerable pyrite content. Sulfidic jasperoids are typically found in Nevada, Australia and Iran.

Talc alteration or steatitization is the introduction of, alteration to, or replacement by, talc (steatite), especially the act or process of hydrothermal alteration of ultrabasic rocks that results in the formation of a talcose rock (such as steatite, soapstone, or relatively pure concentrations of talc). The formation of talc, usually with carbonate  chlorite  magnetite, as a replacement/alteration phase is typical of hydrothermal mineral deposits in Archean greenstone belts.

Tourmaline alteration of country rocks, i.e. a pneumatolytic modification of a pre-existing rock in which boron-rich, late-stage fluids react with the mineral assemblage of the primary rock (usually granite), eventually producing a rock consisting of tourmaline and quartz.
A rock with no visible signs of alteration, in which primary minerals, fabrics (including primary pore space) and chemistry are unchanged.

The development of amphibole from pyroxene. Specifically, a late-magmatic process of replacement whereby uralitic amphibole results from alteration of primary pyroxene. Also a common metamorphic process typical of mafic and ultramafic igneous rocks containing pyroxene.
Regionally extensive alteration around epithermal and geothermal systems. Mineralogical changes from zeolite-rich to propylitic assemblages reflect increasing depth and temperature.

A borehole intentionally drilled at controlled departures from the vertical or parent borehole trajectory and at controlled azimuths, achieved with the use of geosteering equipment or via other methods (e.g. directional wedge). The main purpose is usually to establish multiple boreholes from a single location and/or to intersect a target or zone of interest. Note that the term 'deviated' is not recommended as an alternate label of 'directional', as it can be used to refer to a borehole that unintentionally deviates from the intended trajectory...
A directional well in which the ratio of the measured depth (MD) to the true vertical depth (TVD) is at least 2:1.

A borehole drilled in a horizontal direction. In the energy industry, this is achieved with geosteering equipment and applies to boreholes where the departure from vertical exceeds about 80. In the mineral industry, horizontal drilling is typically carried out from an underground location or on the wall of an open pit.
A borehole drilled from the start point at a pre-set nonvertical angle above or below horizontal.
A borehole drilled from the start point at a pre-set nonvertical angle below horizontal (drilled downwards).
A borehole drilled from the start point at a pre-set nonvertical angle above horizontal (drilled upwards).

A borehole drilled with geosteering equipment with the intent of controlling the trajectory to drill laterally within a targeted stratigraphic interval or intervals. Usually, but not always, drilled close to horizontal and for relatively short distances.
A borehole drilled in a vertical downwards direction with the intent of maintaining a vertical trajectory. Deviations up to 2 from the vertical line are usually accepted as 'vertical.
A borehole drilled underground from the start point in a pre-set vertical upwards direction.
Above ground level (AGL) or height above ground level (HAGL) is the distance of an object or point from the ground below it.

The Australian Height Datum (AHD) is the vertical datum to which all height measurements are referred to in Australia. Adopted in 1971, the datum surface is that which passes through mean sea level (MSL) at the 30 tide gauges around the coast of the Australian continent as determined in 196668. AHD is considered fit for purpose for tasks over short distances (less than about 10 km) for projects such as cadastral, civil engineering, construction and mining; however, the Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) has been defined to assist users working over larger areas (greater than about 10 km) for environmental studies (e.g. flood, storm modelling), LiDAR surveys, geodesy, hydrography.

The 'Australian Height Datum (Tasmania) 1983' (AHDTAS83) zero reference is fixed to mean sea level (MSL) observed for 1972 only at tides gauges in Hobart and Burnie, and was propagated throughout Tasmania on 17 October 1983. Because AHD (mainland) and AHD (Tas) are referenced to MSL observed at different times and locations, there is a vertical offset between the two datums (variably estimated at about 10 cm, between 12 cm and 26 cm, and about 1 cm (https://www.icsm.gov.au/australian-height-datum). Note that the term AHD is used to refer to both the Australian Height Datum 1971 (AHD71; Australian mainland) and Australian Height Datum (Tasmania) 1983 (AHDTAS83).

The Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) is a reference surface for heights in Australia, introduced on 1 January 2020 to allow more accurate height computations where needed. Due to biases and distortions of the AHD, Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) users are only capable of deriving AHD heights with accuracy of 613 cm across Australia, which is inappropriate for some applications that require a more accurate reference surface. AVWS heights can be computed directly from GNSS without needing to connect to survey mark infrastructure with accuracy of 48 cm. AHD is considered fit for purpose for tasks over short distances (less than about 10 km) for projects such as cadastral, civil engineering, construction and mining, whereas the Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) has been defined to assist users working over larger areas (greater than about 10 km) for environmental studies (e.g. flood, storm modelling), LiDAR surveys, geodesy and hydrography.

In the resources industry,the depth of any point in a borehole/drillhole/well is the measurement of the distance between a reference point or elevation and that point. It is the most common method of reference for locations in a borehole. In the minerals industry, it usually refers to the distance from the drill collar. Inthe oil industry, 'depth' also refers to the location itself. By extension, depth can refer to locations below, or distances from, a reference point or elevation, even when there is no well. In that sense, depth is a concept related toelevation, albeit in the opposite direction. Depth in a borehole is not necessarily measured vertically or along a straight line. Because boreholes are not always drilled vertically, there may be two 'depths' for every given point in a borehole: themeasured depth(MD)measured along the path of theborehole, and thetrue vertical depth(TVD), the absolute vertical distance between thereference datumand the point in theborehole. In perfectly vertical holes, the TVD equals the MD; otherwise, the TVD is less than the MD measured from the same datum. Common references used are reduced level (RL), drill collar, ground level (GL),drilling rigfloor (DF),rotary table(RT),kelly bushing(KB or RKB) andmean sea level(MSL).

In the mineral resources industry, 'drill collar' is referred to as the location (in an x, y, z coordinate system) as well as the start point of a borehole from which depths are measured. Drill collars are tubular pieces of material, usually metal or plastic, to aid in keeping the hole entry from collapsing.

The drill floor (DF), also known as derrick floor, is the working area in which the rig crew conducts drilling operations, and is often used as a reference point for downhole/depth measurements. Depth measurements are commonly referenced to the DF, with notations like 2538 m DF or 2358 m BDF, indicating 2538 m below the drill/derrick floor.

The height or level of the natural ground or the level of the exposed surface of the ground. This may be at the Earth's surface (ground surface) or below (e.g. bottom of a mine shaft or floor of an open pit). Ground level can be used as a reference point for vertical measurements (especially in drilling), without reference to any equipment used during drilling (cf. rotary table, kelly bushing).

A tidal low water datum, originally developed by Sir G Darwin for parts of the Indian Ocean. Designed for regions of mixed tides, the datum is depressed below mean sea level by the sum of the amplitudes of the principal semidiurnal lunar and solar tides and the principal diurnal tides (M2 + S2 + K1 + O1). Area of use: World. Users are advised to not use this generic vertical datum but to define explicit realizations of Indian Spring Low Water (ISLW) by specifying location and epoch, for instance 'ISLW at xxx during yyyy-yyyy'.
A depth measured relative to the Indian Spring Low Water (ISLW) datum. Area of use: World.

In drilling, the kelly bushing (KB) or rotary kelly bushing (RKB) is an adapter that serves to connect the rotary table to the kelly (a long square or hexagonal steel bar with a hole drilled through the middle for a fluid path). Depth measurements are commonly referenced to the KB, such as 2538 m KB, meaning 2538 metres below the kelly bushing (BKB).
A depth measured relative to the Lowest Astronomical Tide (LAT) datum. Area of use: World.

The lowest tide level that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions. It can only be obtained properly by studying tidal predictions covering, ideally, 19 years. Area of use: World. Users are advised to not use this generic vertical datum but to define explicit realizations of Lowest Astronomical Tide (LAT) by specifying location and epoch, for instance 'LAT at xxx during yyyy-yyyy'.

A global datum of the average surface of Earth's coastal bodies of water used as a reference to measure elevation (on the ground), altitude (in the air), or depth (below sea level) of an object or point. Derived from the arithmetic mean of hourly heights of the sea at the tidal station observed over a period of time (usually 19 years). Areas of use: World. Users are advised to not use this generic vertical datum but to define explicit realizations of mean sea level (MSL) by specifying location and epoch, for instance 'MSL at xxx during yyyy-yyyy'.

The distance below mean sea level, the inverse of measurements to mean sea level (MSL). The term 'subsea' (SS) by itself should not be used, as it is ambiguous. It could mean: below sea floor or bottom, below mean sea level (MSL), below Lowest Astronomical Tide (LAT), etc.
The depth in metres measured below the mean sea level (MSL). Area of use: World. Not specific to any location or epoch.
The height in metres measured above the mean sea level (MSL). Area of use: World. Not specific to any location or epoch.
Mudline as referenced in subsea operations refers to the seafloor or water bottom.
The point at depth where the pre-collar hole ends and the diamond tail (i.e. diamond drilling) starts, and from which the length/depth of the diamond core is referenced.

Reduced level (or relative level, RL)insurveyingrefers to equating elevations of survey points with reference to a common assumeddatum (usually AHD). It is a vertical distance between survey point and adopted datum plane, thus it is considered as the base elevation that is used as reference to reckon heights or depths of other important places.Reduced here means equating and level means elevations. Datum may be a real or imaginary location, commonly with a nominated elevation of straightzero.

The revolving or spinning section of the drill floor that provides power to turn the drillstring in a clockwise direction (as viewed from above), often used as a starting point for measurement of borehole depth (below rotary table or BRT).

A seismic reference datum (SRD) is used in land seismic projects as a reference surface to counteract the fact that elevation on land is variable. An SRD is a plane that sits above the highest elevation in the data. In a land project with a seismic reference datum set, the SRD will have a time of 0 ms. All time data, for example seismic and velocities, will start at this datum. Marine seismic is usually referenced to mean sea level (MSL), a global datum for measuring height. In a marine project, zero elevation (the mean sea level) will have a time of 0 ms.
The exact depth reference datum, surface, or point (e.g. for a borehole) is not known.
The depth of the interface between water and solid substrate, such as the seabed or the bottom of a terrestrial body of water.

A wellhead (WH) is the component at the surface of an oil or gas well that provides the structural and pressure-containing interface for the drilling and production equipment. Depth is commonly referenced from the valve or outlet point from which samples are extracted.

Air core drilling and related methods use hardened steel or tungsten blades to bore a hole into unconsolidated ground, and is used when safe and clean removal of sample material is paramount. The drillbit has three blades arranged around the bit head, which cut the unconsolidated ground. The rods are hollow and contain an inner tube which sits inside the hollow outer rod barrel. The drill cuttings are removed by injection of compressed air into the hole via the annular area between the inner tube and the drill rod. The cuttings are then blown back to the surface up the inner tube where they pass through the sample separating system and are collected if needed. Drilling continues with the addition of rods to the top of the drillstring. Air core drilling can occasionally produce small chunks of cored rock. This method is often coupled with rotary hammer drilling at the base of the hole when saprock is encountered.

Auger drilling is done with a helical screw that is driven into the ground with rotation; the earth is lifted up the borehole by the blade of the screw. Auger drills may be either rotated by hand or mechanically driven. Hollow stem auger drilling is used for softer ground such as swamps where the hole will not stay open by itself, and for environmental drilling, geotechnical drilling, soil engineering and geochemistry reconnaissance work in exploration for mineral deposits. Solid flight augers/bucket augers are used in harder ground construction drilling. In some cases, mine shafts are dug with auger drills. Small augers can be mounted on the back of a utility truck, with large augers used for sinking piles for bridge foundations.

A proprietary drilling method involving a large rotating bucket on the end of a drillstem. Used for large diameter open holes up to 2.5 m wide, mainly for drilling water-bearing sandy soil, sludge, clay, muddy sub clay, sandy gravel, cobble, and weathered soft formation. The name originates from the German Bauer Group manufacturer.
A sampling method that obtains a large volume or large surface area core with shallow penetration and minimum disturbance. Commonly uses a double spade system.

The bucket rig is a form of the rotary drill rig. It uses mechanical or hydraulic drive to rotate a kelly (i.e. a steel bar with a hole drilled through the middle for a fluid path) which is attached to the bucket. This type of rig normally utilizes a square friction type or round locking type kelly with three or four telescoping sections which can extend to 30 m or more. Bucket rigs may be equipped to drill holes from 25.4 cm to 152.4 cm in diameter. Bucket drilling uses a cylindrical bucket with cutting blades or teeth mounted on a hinged bottom to repeatedly cut and lift sediments from the borehole. To drill, the bucket is rotated to allow the bottom of the cutting teeth to fill the bucket. When the bucket is full, it is raised by cable.

A percussion drilling method that uses a heavy drilling tool that is raised and lowered with enough force to pulverise the rock, with the debris removed by a bailer. Although this drilling method has largely been supplanted in recent years by other, faster drilling techniques, it is still the most practicable drilling method for large diameter, deep bedrock wells, and in widespread use for small rural water supply wells. The impact of the drillbit fractures the rock and in many shale rock situations increases the water flow into a well over rotary. Many large diameter water supply wells, especially deep wells completed in bedrock aquifers, were completed using this drilling method.

A proprietary drilling method commonly used in opal mining, and more recently potash mining, involving a large rotating bucket on the end of a drillstem. Used for large diameter open holes up to 3 m wide. Also known as Calweld bucket drilling. The name originates from the California Welding Company that originally produced the rigs.

Coiled tubing drilling (CTD) is a drilling method that uses a continuous steel coiled tube spooled on a large reel instead of metal pipes. This reduces the amount of time required to trip in and out of the hole (the coil can simply be run in and pulled out while a drillpipe must be assembled and dismantled joint by joint). Instead of rotating the drillbit by using a rotary table or top drive at the surface, the drillbit is turned by a downhole mud motor, powered by the motion of drilling fluid pumped from the surface. CTD is used in both mineral and petroleum industries. In the latter, CTD is commonly used in existing wellbores for re-entry drilling or sidetracking through the production tubing, for new shallow wells, deepening conventional wells and for drilling underbalanced.

A metal rod with an instrumented cone tip pushed hydraulically or by hammering into weakly consolidated ground at a controlled rate. Tip resistance, sleeve friction and water pressure are commonly measured parameters. Includes static and dynamic cone penetration tests.

Diamond core drilling in which core samples are periodically recovered by withdrawing the complete core barrel and drill rods from the hole. The end of the barrel is disassembled by removing the core bit and catcher, the stainless steel splits are then pumped out of the inner barrel by using high pressure water. The splits are then opened to reveal the core in virtually undisturbed condition. Conventional core drilling systems are used for shallow site investigation and shallow to medium deep underground up-hole drilling applications.
Drilling using a rotating core barrel to obtain a cylindrical core of rock.

The Delft continuous sampler, developed by GeoDelft, is used for obtaining high quality samples within very soft cohesive soils. The sampling system is available in two sizes to take continuous samples, 29 or 66 mm in diameter, normally with a maximum penetration of about 18 m. A steel outer tube is pushed into the ground using standard CPT (cone penetrometer test) equipment and the soil sample core is fed into a thin-walled plastic inner tube as the sampler advances. After extraction, the samples are cut into 1 m lengths and placed in purpose-made cases, being retained in the plastic tubes.

Diamond core drilling (or diamond drilling) utilizes an annular diamond- or tungsten-carbide-impregnated drillbit attached to the end of rotating hollow drill rods to cut a cylindrical core of solid rock. Fine to microfine, industrial-grade diamonds are used. They are set within a matrix of varying hardness, from brass to high-grade steel. Matrix hardness, diamond size and dosing can be varied according to the rock which must be cut. Holes within the bit allow water to be delivered to the cutting face. This provides three essential functions: lubrication, cooling and removal of drill cuttings from the hole. Core samples are retrieved via the use of a core tube, a hollow tube placed inside the rod string and pumped with water until it locks into the core barrel. As the core is drilled, the core barrel slides over the core as it is cut. An 'overshot' attached to the end of the winch cable is lowered inside the rod string and locks on to the backend (aka head assembly), located on the top end of the core barrel. The winch is retracted, pulling the core tube to the surface. The core does not drop out of the inside of the core tube when lifted because either a split ring core lifter or basket retainer allow the core to move into, but not back out of the tube.

Direct push technology includes several types of drilling rigs and drilling equipment that advance a drillstring by pushing or hammering without rotating the drillstring. Direct push rigs include both cone penetration testing rigs and direct push sampling rigs such as a PowerProbe or Geoprobe. Direct push rigs typically are limited to drilling in unconsolidated soil materials and very soft rock. Direct push drilling rigs use hydraulic cylinders and a hydraulic hammer in advancing a hollow core sampler, typically no longer than 2 m, to gather soil and groundwater samples. The core pipe has a valve on top that is used to create a vacuum at the top of the core when pulling the core out of the sediment. The method can be used in up to 5 m of water.

A drilling method using a drillstem equipped with a non-rotating drillstring and a rotating downhole bit driven by a downhole motor. Downhole motor drilling is used in the energy industry to drive the drillbit or other downhole tools during directional drilling or performance drilling applications. As drilling fluid is pumped through the positive displacement motor (PDM), it converts the hydraulic power of the fluid into mechanical power to cause the bit to rotate. During directional drilling, this capability is used while drilling in sliding mode, when the drillstring is not rotated from the surface. Positive displacement motors can also be used for performance drilling, straight hole drilling, coring, underreaming and milling operations. In straight hole drilling, the motor functions as a drilling performance tool to increase the rate of penetration and reduce casing wear by minimizing drillstring rotation.
Gravity-driven drilling method used for obtaining a core of soft, unconsolidated sediment by relying upon the weight of the core tool for penetration.
A proprietary type of direct push drilling. High-quality core is extracted by hydraulic power. Used in rough terrain, soft sand, mud, shallow water or tight, congested areas.
Used only where short cores are required. The core barrel is gravity forced into poorly consolidated material, producing near-surface, high-quality core.

A hand auger consists of a hollow stem steel rod, rotated by hand. Various steel augers can be attached at the bottom end of the drill rod. The augers are rotated into the ground until they are filled, and then lifted out of the borehole to be emptied. Extension rods can be added for extra depth.

Any drilling method that uses a non-rotating drillstem (i.e. the string of pipe that transmits power from the surface down to the drillbit) and a rotating drillbit (the part of the bottom-hole assembly that cuts, grinds or breaks the bottom-hole formation to make the hole).

Drilling method used in unconsolidated formations and achieved by water circulation through the rods to wash cuttings away from the front of the bit. The cuttings flow up the annular space and into a settling pit so that the water can be recirculated. Jetting in semiconsolidated formations may be assisted by using a combination of rotary and percussion techniques.

A drilling method using a drillstem equipped with a bit that is rotated to cut and grind the rock with a fluid pumped down the stem to force cuttings up through the annular space between the stem and the wall of the hole. Oil well drilling of this type utilizes tri-cone roller, carbide-embedded, fixed-cutter diamond or diamond-impregnated drillbits. This is preferred because there is no need to return intact samples to surface for assay as the objective is to reach a formation containing oil or natural gas. Sizable machinery is used, enabling depths of several kilometres to be penetrated. Rotating hollow drillpipes carry down bentonite and barite infused drilling muds to lubricate, cool, and clean the drilling bit, control downhole pressures, stabilize the wall of the borehole and remove drill cuttings. Also used in minerals exploration to penetrate difficult ground (i.e. swelling clays or waste rock) without stopping, to reduce cost or the chance of bogging.

Large volume, relatively undisturbed sediment core (~3 m long) from a Kasten Corer. The corer is constructed of stainless steel and is square in cross-section. A weight of several hundred kilograms on top of the corer pushes it 2 to 3 m into the seabed.

The Mackereth corer (Mackereth, 1958; Smith, 1959) is a pneumatic device that consists of a cylindrical aluminium chamber about 1.2 m long and 0.5 m in diameter. The apparatus is lowered to the lake floor on a rope, and air hoses connect the chamber to the vessel at the water surface. Compressed air is used to pump the water out of the chamber and then to force the inner core barrel downward through the chamber and into the sediment. The method can recover single-drive moderate (up to 12 m) cores from lakes of diverse depths. Mackereth cores can be deployed on virtually any small craft and can be used in water depths up to 100 m.

The Mackintosh tool consists of rods that can be threaded together with barrel connectors and which are normally fitted with a driving point at their base, and a light hand-operated driving hammer at their top. The tool provides a very economical method of determining the thickness of soft deposits such as peat. The driving point is streamlined in longitudinal section with a maximum diameter of 27 mm. The drive hammer has a total weight of about 4 kg. The rods are 1.2 m long and 12 mm diameter. The device is often used to provide a depth profile by driving the point and rods into the ground with equal blows of the full drop height available from the hammer: the number of blows for each 150 mm of penetration is recorded.

Any drilling method that uses a non-rotating drillstem (i.e. the string of pipe that transmits power from the surface down to the drillbit) and a non-rotating drillbit (the part of the bottom-hole assembly that cuts, grinds or breaks the bottom-hole formation to make the hole).

The piston corer is a long, heavy tube plunged into the sediments at the bottom of water bodies to extract samples of mud, silt and clay. Piston corers have a piston mechanism that is triggered when the corer hits the bottom. The piston helps to avoid disturbing the sediment, keeps settled material or cavings out of the tube as it is run into the hole and helps to retain the sample in the tube.

Mechanically driven auger drilling is typically used for surface geochemistry sampling or for holes that are too wide or deep for hand auger drilling. Auger drilling is done with a helical screw which is driven into the ground with rotation; the earth is lifted up the borehole by the blade of the screw. Small power augers can be portable or mounted on the back of a utility truck, with larger auger rigs used for construction, like sinking piles for bridge foundations or mine shafts.
An object (e.g. penetrometer) inserted into the substrate that records material properties without taking physical samples.

The drilling mechanism for reverse circulation (RC) drilling is a pneumatic reciprocating piston known as a 'hammer' driving a tungsten-steel drillbit. Compressed air passes down to the drillbit along the annular space between an outer and inner drill rod to return to the surface inside the rods carrying drill cuttings. This is the reverse of the air path employed in normal open hole rotary percussion drilling (including RAB drilling). At the top of the hole, the air and drill cuttings are passed through a cyclone to collect the cuttings for sampling. The RC drilling technique prevents the upcoming sample from being contaminated with material from the wall of the hole above the sampling depth. RC drilling utilizes much larger rigs and machinery and comparatively higher air pressure. Depths of up to 500 m are routinely achieved.

Rotary air blast drilling (RAB) is an 'open hole' rotary drilling method whereby rock or sediment chips are generated by a drag bit or pneumatic reciprocating piston-driven hammer and the cuttings are blown up on the outside of the drill rods by air, or a combination of air and foam, and collected at the surface. It is used most frequently in the mineral exploration industry.

Any drilling method that uses both a rotating drillstem (i.e. the string of pipe that transmits power from the surface down to the drillbit) and drillbit (the part of the bottom-hole assembly that cuts, grinds or breaks the bottom-hole formation to make the hole).

A rotary percussion drilling method using a cutting tool powered by compressed air that creates a rapid percussion effect coupled with rotary action to drill hard rocks. The hammer can be either down the hole (DHH) at the bottom of the drillstring or at the top of the drillstring (top-hole hammer). Rotary hammer drilling is commonly referred to in industry as percussion drilling and is an open hole method, meaning that the drill cuttings are blown up on the outside of the drill rods. Note that percussion is also applied in other methods. For example, reverse circulation (RC) drilling uses this cutting method, but the drill cuttings return to the surface within the drill rods. A rotary hammer is also a common component in rotary air blast (RAB) drilling. Usage of rotary hammer is recommended for instances where the open hole sampling method is used but where details of the sample return method are unknown. It should be avoided if a more specific term is known (e.g. RAB or RC drilling), as well as where it represents only a minor component of the borehole drilling (e.g. bottom of hole for aircore drilling).

A sonic or vibratory drillhead works by sending high-frequency resonant vibrations down the drillstring to the drillbit, while the operator controls these frequencies to suit the specific conditions of the soil/rock geology. Vibrations may also be generated within the drillhead. The frequency is generally between 50 and 180 Hz (cycles per second) and can be varied by the operator. Resonance magnifies the amplitude of the drillbit, which fluidizes the soil particles at the bit face, allowing for fast and easy penetration through most geological formations. An internal spring system isolates these vibrational forces from the rest of the drill rig.
Use when statutory submissions from the resource industry do not specify the drilling method used while drilling a specific borehole.

Vacuum drilling is principally designed for mineral exploration drilling to provide a low-cost, efficient recovery of uncontaminated drill samples. Vacuum drilling uses a tungsten carbide tipped blade bit to make the hole. The cuttings are then sucked up the drillpipe using an industrial vacuum pump. The sample is separated from the air flow through a sealed cyclone into a transparent collection (vacuum) flask. Any remaining fine material is removed by a secondary filter before the air passes through the vacuum pump and vented to the atmosphere. In softer material, drilling with this method is a fast, accurate and economical method of obtaining samples. Although hole depths of 50 m or more have been recorded, most are less than 10 m.

A core tube is attached to a source of mechanical vibration (the power head) and lowered into sediment. The vibrations provide energy for rearranging the particles within the sediment in such a way that the core tube penetrates under the static weight of the vibracoring apparatus. Samples include stiff and stony clays, soft rock and sands, and saturated sediments which can not be sampled using gravity or piston corers. Also known as VIBRA.

Window or windowless sampling uses either a drop weight or hydraulic hammer to drive 1 m or 2 m long sample tubes into the ground. The sample tubes have open slots or 'windows' along their length to allow for logging and sampling. In windowless sampling, the sample tube contains a liner which retains the sample and reduces potential for cross contamination of soils during the drilling process. Window or windowless sampling is used to bore through shallow soft soils to investigate the substrata in order to gain a profile of the ground conditions and to facilitate soil sampling for chemical and geotechnical analysis.

Wireline core drilling is a technique used to extract the core without having to retrieve the entire string of drill rods, which generally are retracted only when the hole is finished or the drillbit must be replaced. Drill rods are added at the top as required to extend the drillstring as the hole gets deeper. The core sample is carried by an inner tube (core barrel) locked in place in contact with the drilling head. To recover the core, the drive system is disconnected, opening the top of the drillstring. A tool called the overshot assembly is lowered at the end of a wire using the retraction winch. When it reaches the core barrel, it locks onto the top and, applying tension to the wire, unlocks the core barrel from the drillhead and retracts both the core barrel and core sample to the open top end of the drillstring. Here, the core sample is removed before returning the empty core barrel down the drill tube to lock back onto to the cutting head and drilling recommences.

The angle, measured in the horizontal plane, between north (unspecified) and the projection of the borehole axis at the point of measurement. For curved trajectories, the azimuth is measured from the projection of the tangent to the borehole axis at the point of measurement.
The width of the borehole.

Measured on a vertical plane, dip is the angle of a borehole defined by a tangent line at the point of measurement and the horizontal plane. In the minerals industry, vertical is commonly denoted as 90 and changes to 0 (horizontal). The sum of inclination and dip is 90.

A particularly crooked place in a borehole where the trajectory of the borehole in 3D space changes rapidly, either intentionally or unintentionally. In surveying borehole trajectories, a standard calculation of dogleg severity is made, usually expressed in 2D degrees per 30 metres of wellbore length.
A geometric measurement of inclination and azimuth at a certain depth along the borehole trajectory.
The spatial location where the drilling of a borehole was completed, expressed as coordinates and elevation (i.e. x, y, z).
The azimuth measured clockwise from the central meridian of a plane-rectangular coordinate system such as a local reference grid.

Measured on a vertical plane, inclination is the angle defined by a tangent line to the borehole and a vertical line representing the Earth's gravity vector at the point of measurement. In the energy industry, inclination is usually expressed as an angle from the vertical (0, downward pointing) to 90 (horizontal). The sum of inclination and dip is 90. In the resources industry, inclination is often used interchangeably with dip, though the two concepts are not the same.
The point at a given measured depth at which a directional borehole is intentionally deviated.
The azimuth measured clockwise from magnetic north through to 360. This parameter changes with time and thus needs to be qualified by a date.

The angle, measured in the horizontal plane, between magnetic north and true north. This angle varies depending on the position on the Earth's surface, and changes over time. By convention, magnetic declination is positive when magnetic north is east of true north, and negative when it is to the west. Magnetic declination is a critical parameter to report in conjunction with magnetic azimuth to fully characterize the 3D orientation of a borehole.

Measured depth (MD), or drilled to depth (DD), is the distance measured along the actual trajectory of the borehole from the borehole start point / surface reference point to the point of interest or survey point, i.e. to any feature in the hole such as a casing point, a sidewall core or a significant geological marker.
Measured depth of the borehole measured from the kelly bushing to the point of interest or survey point.
Measured depth of the borehole measured from the rotary table to the point of interest or survey point.
The measured depth where the pre-collar hole ends and the diamond tail (i.e. diamond drilling) starts, and from which the length/depth of the diamond core is referenced.

Reduced level depth (usually reported as mRL, i.e. metres from reduced level) is the vertical distance between a survey point and the adopted datum plane, i.e. the base elevation that is used as reference to report heights or depths during drilling. The reference datum may be a real or arbitrary location/plane, and is commonly assigned a nominated elevation.
The spatial location where the drilling of a borehole commenced, expressed as coordinates and elevation (i.e. x, y, z).
Total depth is the distance measured along the actual trajectory of the borehole from the borehole start point / surface reference point to the end of the hole where the drilling has stopped.
The azimuth measured clockwise from true north (also called geodetic north or geographic north) through 360.

True vertical depth (TVD) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the depth reference level / borehole start point (e.g. mean sea level, kelly bushing, rotary table, ground level, drill collar) projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth). This is a calculated or derived depth. In the energy industry, this depth is always calculated from the deviation survey data.

True vertical depth below mudline (TVDBML) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the mudline projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

True vertical depth drill floor (TVDDF) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the drill floor projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

True vertical depth kelly bushing (TVDKB) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the kelly bushing projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).

True vertical depth rotary table (TVDRT) of a point within a borehole is the distance of that point from the rotary table projected on a vertical line (i.e. a line connecting the point to the centre of the Earth).
The true vertical depth subsea (TVDSS) is the vertical distance from the mean sea level to a point on the borehole course. This depth is always calculated from the deviation survey data.
The vertical section is the horizontal distance along the centreline of a wellbore to a certain point on a well trajectory, measured along a pre-defined azimuth in the horizontal plane.
A well or bore drilled to recover strata samples for their use in acid leachate testing.

A well drilled into a potential or known fluid energy reservoir to determine the continuation of a known pool and extent of the reservoir, in order to establish the existence of a significant quantity of recoverable fluid energy resource. Note that this concept merges the appraisal and extension definitions of PPDM Well Status and Classification (v3).

A well or bore drilled to facilitate the installation and subsequent detonation of explosives, pulverising material and throwing it away from the wall or face, reducing the effort required to advance the face or recover and remove materials.
A cased borehole drilled for the installation of electric cables, optic fibres and related services in an underground mine.
A well/borehole drilled into a known fluid energy source, in order to recover fluid energy resources and generate fluid energy products. This may include service wells.

A borehole drilled to remove water, as a way to facilitate construction or other activity. It is often used as a safety measure in mining below the watertable or as a preliminary step to development in an area.

A borehole drilled and cased to enable the removal of groundwater from a mine. Mine dewatering is critical when a mine extends below the water table and groundwater does, due to gravity, infiltrate the mine workings.

A well, often a depleted production well, into which waste fluids can be injected into an isolated formation for safe disposal. Disposal wells are typically subject to regulatory requirements to avoid the contamination of freshwater aquifers.
