A well in which fluids are injected rather than produced, where the primary objective is to dispose of fluid/water into an isolated formation.
A borehole drilled to enable construction of underground declines, ore drives and stope access to facilitate mining.

A borehole drilled for the purpose of electrokinetic in-situ leaching (EK-ISL), an emerging mining technology that allows for the recovery of metals from low-permeability ore bodies via boreholes without excavation or permeability enhancement techniques such as fracking. Instead, it uses electrode wells to generate electric fields and induce the transport of charged chemical species that facilitate the selective dissolution, transport and recovery of targeted metals such as copper or gold.

Environmental drilling is performed when soil, rock or groundwater samples are required to assess an area for contamination, or when groundwater monitoring wells or remediation wells are required for the treatment of groundwater. Typically this type of drilling is conducted for a) testing and monitoring for sites such as landfills or lagoons that have a potential for pollution, b) monitoring and testing of environmentally sensitive sites such as protected lands or public water supply wellfields, c) testing to determine the source and extent of a known pollution problem, d) sampling and well construction for recovery or remediation of pollutants in groundwater, e) identification of product (oil, petrol etc.) or human artefacts (fill, trash, archeological).
A well/borehole drilled to determine and evaluate the fluid energy potential of a previously undeveloped area.
Drilling to search for and delineate new sources of economic minerals or basic raw (i.e. construction) materials.

concepts.prefLabel: exploration and exploitation of fluid energy resources
concepts.definition: A borehole/well drilled to explore for and exploit naturally occurring fluid energy resources, including petroleum (hydrocarbon) fluids, other natural gases (e.g. hydrogen and helium), and geothermal (naturally heated fluids occurring on or within the Earth's crust).

concepts.prefLabel: exploration and exploitation of minerals and basic raw materials
altLabels: Exploration and exploitation of mineral resources
concepts.definition: Drilling to assist in the discovery, identification and extraction of mineral resources or basic raw (i.e. construction) materials, including the assessment of their importance and the evaluation of their economic potential. Mineral resources are inclusive of brine-hosted minerals and solid fossil fuels (e.g. coal).

Drilling to assess the stability and conditions of rocks in the substrate prior to foundation and construction activities. This drilling aims to differentiate between solid basement and rock detached (floating) from the basement, as well as boring large holes deep into the ground in order to insert structures (e.g. piles, piers, or caissons) that are used to build a foundation for a construction project.
A well/borehole drilled to force gas into the target reservoir, whether to enhance fluid recovery or for temporary/permanent storage.

Drilling for the primary purpose of understanding the geological characteristics of the site, such as stratigraphy, structure, and physical or chemical rock properties. These boreholes are generally drilled as part of scientific/technical investigations conducted by government or research organizations.
A borehole drilled for the examination of subsurface geophysical properties (e.g. gravitational, electrical and magnetic fields, etc.).

Geotechnical or engineering drilling is carried out to determine soil and rock characteristics in order to facilitate infrastructure and mine planning. It includes the collection of rock and soil samples to determine physical properties (e.g. strength, hardness, fracture and fault frequency) for geotechnical analysis and to identify where unsafe rock or soil conditions could trigger a structural collapse or cause a hazardous scenario during, for example, an earthquake or flooding event. Geotechnical drilling is conducted to assess the potential construction sites of both above and below ground projects, including but not limited to buildings and storage structures, dams, bridges, roads, wharves and other civil works, and below surface projects such as tunnels and shafts (including all open pits and underground mining areas), access or inspection holes, or to facilitate installation of monitoring equipment (e.g. tiltmeters/inclinometers, piezometers and other sensors). Geotechnical work can overlap with environmental drilling on sites where there is a potential for environmental hazards.
A borehole drilled to estimate grade and location of resources/material in the ground (in-situ) to an acceptable degree of confidence for mining to be economic.

A borehole drilled to explore the extent and properties of an aquifer and the water quality of groundwater within a given area. Being generally deeper than production or monitoring boreholes, exploration boreholes may also provide geological information on the area under investigation, including stratigraphy, biostratigraphy, lithology and/or structure.

A borehole drilled to monitor groundwater properties such as levels, quality and production impacts, as a method of assessing changes to the quantity and quality of groundwater (e.g. for piezometer installation). Groundwater data allows for sustainable water extraction and management, and the detection and remediation of groundwater contamination, among other purposes.

A borehole drilled or altered for the purpose of groundwater abstraction, whether for domestic use, agricultural use or in support of resource infrastructure (e.g. mineral holes, petroleum wells, mines, refineries). Production boreholes are often drilled in sets, known as fields, and can be in close association with exploration and/or monitoring water bores.
An exploratory borehole drilled to identify rock voids, and any other relevant changes in conditions of the earth before drilling, mining, tunnelling or construction commences.
A borehole drilled and completed for the search, abstraction, monitoring and/or disposal/injection of water.

Hydrogeology drilling in mining operations is conducted in order to monitor and sample the water table at and around a mining site, retrieve water for use (e.g. for dust control), or to remove water from a mine (dewatering).

A borehole drilled for the purpose of in-situ leaching (ISL, also called in-situ recovery or ISR) or solution mining, a mining process used to recover minerals (e.g. copper and uranium) through boreholes drilled into a deposit. It works by artificially dissolving minerals occurring naturally in a solid state and pumping the pregnant solution to the surface where the minerals can be recovered.

A borehole drilled for the purpose of in-situ leaching (ISL) or solution mining of salt dome structures, specifically to create a cavern suitable for temporary storage of non-aqueous gases. Salt caverns are formed by pumping fresh water to dissolve the salt and removing the resulting brine via a single well, which then serves for gas injection and withdrawal. For storing non-aqueous gases such as hydrogen and carbon dioxide, the caverns are usually at depths of at least a few hundred metres.
A well drilled to introduce new or return produced fluids from a development or production well back into the subsurface after energy products have been extracted.

A borehole drilled for the intentional recharge of an aquifer under controlled conditions for subsequent recovery, demonstrable environmental benefit, or mitigation of the impacts of abstraction. This recharge must be an additional contribution to an aquifer, not a return of abstracted water.

A borehole drilled to identify the physical and geochemical properties of materials and whether they have the potential to cause environmental harm and/or contribute to, or detract from, the success of rehabilitation and closure. This drilling focuses on identification of fibrous materials, radioactive materials, materials capable of generating acid and/or metalliferous drainage (including neutral drainage and saline drainage), and dispersive and/or erosive material.
A borehole drilled to obtain samples for metallurgical test work, i.e. to understand the properties of metals and their production and purification.

A borehole drilled at the surface or underground to develop mines and/or quarries to facilitate production of economic minerals and basic raw materials. It includes drilling for underground services such as cables, water pipes, access and airways.
A service well drilled with the purpose of monitoring the movement of gases and liquids in the subsurface, formation pressure and temperature, seismicity, and injected CO2 plumes.

A cased borehole drilled for paste filling (or cemented back filling) in an underground mine, i.e. to backfill underground mine stopes and/or drives to facilitate removal of remnant ore material while retaining geotechnical stability.

A well drilled to inject fluids (e.g. CO) into deep subsurface rock formations for long-term storage. The process is also referred to as geosequestration (GS) in general, or more specifically as 'carbon capture and storage' (CCS) in the case of CO or 'greenhouse gas storage' (GHG). Fluids are commonly captured from an industrial (e.g. steel and cement production) or energy-related source (e.g. a power plant or natural gas processing facility).
A well/borehole drilled to extract a fluid energy resource for commercial purposes.
A well drilled to both produce and inject fluids, either cyclically or simultaneously.
A borehole drilled for the purpose of pumping water back into an aquifer.
A borehole drilled for the purpose of pumping water into an aquifer for disposal at some distance from a mine as a means of dewatering.
In the petroleum and geothermal industries, a relief well is drilled to intersect and remedy a geothermal well where control has been or may be lost (e.g. blowout).

An environmental borehole drilled to facilitate the collection of water, soil or rock samples to investigate potential contamination and the requirements for environmental remediation (e.g. cleanup, removal, containment) needed to reverse or stop environmental damage, or as part of the remediation process (e.g. pumping out groundwater for treatment or disposal).
A borehole conducted during rescue operations to provide ventilation, water or food while larger holes are drilled to extract trapped miners.

concepts.prefLabel: resource definition and conversion to ore reserves
concepts.definition: Drilling to determine the size and grade of an orebody in order to improve confidence in the Mineral Resource and Ore Reserve classification.
A well drilled to provide maintenance and monitoring during fluid energy production, which may include supply, disposal, relief, and observation.

Boreholes drilled to provide services such as the transport of water, compressed air, other gases or materials; placement of electric cables and airlines; or raise bores for access or ventilation. It includes drilling conducted during mine rescue operations.
A borehole drilled to insert and detonate an explosive charge to generate ground vibrations. The vibrations are recorded using sensors placed at predetermined locations in the surrounding area.
A borehole drilled to check that there are no minerals of current and potential economic interest located below sites for proposed infrastructure.
A borehole/well drilled to examine the subsurface's ability to accommodate the temporary / permanent storage of gases and liquids, and to implement such storage.

A borehole/well drilled variously to: provide geological information in areas of poor outcrop and inadequate drillhole coverage, such as assisting the determination of the lithological intervals and stratigraphy present at a location (e.g. GSQ stratigraphic drilling); permit the collection of pristine samples for biostratigraphic, geochemical, geochronological or other studies; investigate the presence of geological setting(s) favourable for mineralization; and/or evaluate emerging technologies. The concept is similar to 'stratigraphic/structural/research (mineral exploration)', but is distinct in not having a primary economic focus.

A well drilled primarily with the intention of gathering geological data or to evaluate new technologies. The information may include stratigraphy, temperature gradient, heat flow, reservoir presence and quality.

A borehole drilled to determine the lithological and stratigraphic intervals present at a location and/or to evaluate emerging technologies. Typically to enhance geological understanding of an area and/or to investigate the presence of geological setting(s) favourable for mineralization. It is most commonly associated with government drilling programs.

A borehole drilled to determine the lithological intervals present at a location and their structural and/or stratigraphic relationships. Typically drilled to determine the presence, location and extension of a potential resource, and most commonly associated with early stages of the exploration process. It can be associated with trialling of new drilling or analytical technologies.

A borehole/well drilled to investigate the attitude of strata and structural/tectonic relationships of rock units at a location. Typically to enhance geological understanding of an area and/or to investigate the presence of geological setting(s) favourable for mineralization. Most commonly associated with government drilling programs or early stages of exploration. The concept is similar to 'stratigraphic/structural/research (mineral exploration)', but is distinct in not having a primary economic focus.

A borehole/well drilled to identify the presence of stygofauna and facilitate the monitoring of its biodiversity and overall 'health' parameters. Stygofauna, also known as subterranean aquatic fauna, are aquatic fauna that inhabit the water filled pore spaces, voids, cracks and fissures of most rock types and groundwater systems such as aquifers or underground caves.
A well used to inject and subsequently recover natural gas or other gaseous material (e.g. manufactured hydrogen) into/from subsurface rock formations.

concepts.prefLabel: transient storage - liquids other than water
concepts.definition: A borehole/well used for the injection or withdrawal of liquid or liquefied hydrocarbons into or out of an underground hydrocarbon storage facility, including salt caverns.

A cased borehole drilled for uncemented geomaterial filling in an underground mine. Uncemented backfill drilling is a method used to backfill underground mine stopes and/or drives to facilitate removal of remnant ore material while retaining geotechnical stability. Uncemented backfills include hydraulic fills, sand fills, aggregate fills and rock fills.
The specific purpose for the drilling is unknown (or was not recorded).
A borehole drilled to create a ventilation shaft in an underground mine.
A well/borehole drilled to force water into the target reservoir, usually to enhance energy fluid recovery.

A monitoring bore drilled to identify the condition of the groundwater and of the water table at and around a mining site or part thereof (e.g. around open pits, tailings dams and waste dumps). Holes are drilled at intervals and cased with slotted casing, allowing groundwater entry and thus regular checking and sample collection/analysis to determine any variations in the height of the water table, water pressure, water quality, presence of contaminants and salinity.
A well drilled to extract water from an aquifer for use in exploration and/or mining operations, e.g. to supply water for dust control.
A well drilled to retrieve water to support petroleum and geothermal operations.
Indicates that the borehole was drilled from a pre-existing hole, whether at surface or underground.

Indicates that the borehole was drilled from an artificially made or engineered surface, commonly near a natural ground surface. This concept includes drilling originating from tailings and waste dumps, as well as excavations such as quarries and open pit mines.
Indicates that the borehole was drilled from artificially made surfaces related to byproducts of exploration and mining operations, such as tailings and waste dumps.

Indicates that the borehole was drilled from the natural ground surface or from ground with limited disturbance carried out in preparation for drilling, i.e. shallow excavation works, drill pads, cut and fill.

Indicates that the borehole was drilled in marine waters / open sea from a floating vessel or fixed platform, such as a drill ship, jackup or semisubmersible rig, petroleum platform or a marine research vessel, on the seaward side of the baseline of the territorial sea (as defined in the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973, Registered 11 September 2019).

Indicates that the borehole was drilled from or near the natural ground surface. This includes drilling originating on land and on internal waters, i.e. those bodies of water that are located on the landward side of the baseline of the territorial sea (as defined in the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973, Registered 11 September 2019).
Indicates that the borehole was drilled from an open pit floor or open pit wall.
Indicates that the borehole was drilled from an underground location.

All borehole operations and activities are terminated. The operator has left the site with no intention of returning to the borehole. Note that this is similar to 'completed' status in the Australian Coal Logging Standards v3.1 (CoalLog). Also note that 'abandoned - energy' is similar to 'rehabilitated' as used by the mineral resources industry.

All borehole operations and activities are prematurely terminated due to unforeseen circumstances, e.g. surface ground failure or borehole collapse (with or without equipment being stuck). Borehole should undergo necessary rehabilitation.

Drilling of a borehole has been approved by the relevant authorities, whether within a resource company, a government regulatory agency (e.g. as part of government-supported exploration drilling initiatives or for research purposes), indigenous representative groups, a research organisation, or as part of geotechnical investigations and/or infrastructure programs. Drilling has not yet commenced.

A borehole where a cap (usually a PVC cap secured with a screw) or a plug have been put temporarily in place during interim rehabilitation or to allow for the possibility of re-entering the hole (e.g. during a pause in operations and/or maintenance), e.g. to prevent fauna from falling into the hole. A permanent rehabilitation should follow at the completion of the operations.
A well in which casing has been installed, but is suspended and inactive pending installation of completion, monitoring or other equipment.

Decommissioning is a broad stage that involves the timely, safe, and environmentally responsible removal of, or otherwise satisfactorily dealing with, drilling-related property, equipment or infrastructure that is not in use, has not been maintained in working order such that it can be used, and has no demonstrable future use (i.e. has no associated permissioning documents allowing for and outlining plans for future use). The term is predominantly used in the energy industry.
A stage referring to the collection of activities that specifically occur while a borehole is being drilled, from groundbreaking to reaching the intended depth/zone.

Drilling of the borehole is completed, but operations involving the borehole are continuing (e.g. installation of production infrastructure, wirelogging, etc.). Note that in the Australian Coal Logging Standards v3.1 (CoalLog), 'completed' status is closer in meaning to 'abandoned' in this vocabulary).

Drilling of the borehole is complete and no further activity (other than decommissioning/rehabilitation) is planned. Note that in the Australian Coal Logging Standards v3.1 (CoalLog), 'completed' status is closer in meaning to 'abandoned' in this vocabulary).
Drilling operations have been temporarily suspended (e.g. due to adverse weather conditions, maintenance, or other reasons).

The status of a borehole commencing from the rig being moved onsite up until the time that drilling is completed. Note that this stage does not include any operations at the drillsite and within the borehole that follow the completion of drilling the hole. Note that this corresponds to the status of 'drilling' in the PPDM Wellbore Status vocabulary 2014.

The status of a borehole during which fluids (commonly gas and water) are injected rather than produced, typically with the primary objective of maintaining/increasing reservoir pressure to enhance production. Injection wells are also used to dispose of treated wastewater, recharge aquifers, tap geothermal energy, and in environmental remediation for the cleanup of contaminated soil or groundwater; the concept includes injecting for permanent storage. Boreholes/wells are specifically designed/drilled for this purpose, although a production well can be converted into an injection well and vice versa.

A reservoir maintenance or secondary recovery method that uses injected gas to supplement the pressure in an oil reservoir or field. This concept includes injecting for the purpose of permanent gas storage (e.g. CO).

Waterflooding or water injection is where water is injected into the oil reservoir, to maintain the pressure (also known as voidage replacement) or to drive oil towards the wells, and thereby increase production. Water-injection wells are common offshore, where filtered and treated seawater is injected into a lower water-bearing section of the reservoir. The concept includes water recharge of aquifers.
A borehole/well that is actively monitoring reservoir, aquifer or other geological parameters, such as water level, water quality, fluid pressure.
A borehole that was proposed in concept and/or approved on application, but was never drilled. This does not include the circumstance where the status is 'unknown'.
The status of a borehole from the commencement to the completion of drilling operations, and including the production/investigation stages.

A borehole where drilling has been halted but for which operations/activities are not completed, and the borehole has not been fully decommissioned/rehabilitated. This stage includes the potential resumption of drilling.
Refers to the stated intention of drilling a borehole that has yet to be submitted for approval from the relevant authorities.

Planning and approval include all stages from the initial conception of a borehole through to obtaining necessary approval(s) from the relevant authorities, whether within a resource company, a government regulatory agency, indigenous representative groups, a research organisation, or as part of geotechnical investigations and/or infrastructure programs.

A permanently, securely plugged borehole, usually at a prescribed distance below the ground. Note that 'plugged' is similar to the PPDM definitions of 'plugged and abandoned' as used by the energy industry. Under current regulation, backfilling is a mandatory requirement.

An abandoned borehole that has also been plugged. The extent of seal may vary from just plugged near the surface (e.g. many coal boreholes) to plugged to prevent the migration of oil, gas, water or other substance from one stratum to another (i.e. PPDM definition). Note that 'plugged and abandoned ' is similar to 'plugged' as used by the mineral resources industry.

A borehole that has been securely plugged below ground, with the remaining void backfilled to the surface with low permeability material, and with a mound of low permeability material (approximately 250 mm high by 800 mm wide and up to 2 m for large diameter drillholes) covered with topsoil to facilitate water shedding away from the drillhole and prevent subsidence.
A borehole that is no longer operating and for which activities are completed, i.e. the borehole is fully decommissioned/rehabilitated.
The status of a borehole during which liquids or gas are being extracted from the borehole.
The status of a borehole that alternately produces and injects liquid or gas into a borehole.
An application exists to drill a borehole, but drilling has not yet commenced or been approved.

The process of enlarging a borehole, for example when a drilling bit has worn down from its original size or lithological plastic flow into the wellbore requires the reinstating of the original hole size.
In the mineral industry, the borehole site has been fully rehabilitated. Note that this status is similar to the PPDM definitions of 'abandoned' as used by the energy industry.
A borehole/well with one or more valves temporarily closed in the direction of flow.

Borehole operations have been halted for a significant period of time or in a manner that requires significant effort for the resumption of activities. The borehole can be plugged downhole and fluids injected on top of the plug in order to create a temporary seal to prevent hydrocarbon leakage. The surface equipment remains in place. Suspended is never the final status of a borehole.
The status of the borehole is unknown (or has not been recorded).
A borehole that is not rehabilitated. Typically this includes boreholes drilled prior to mandatory rehabilitation legislation coming into effect.
Activities relating to production wells, for example logging activities, recompletion, testing, repairs, maintenance, plug and abandonment and demobilisation.
A definition for AAI NZ.
A definition for AAMI.
Insurance options for seniors, over 50s and retirees.
A definition for Bingle.
Caravan and RV insurance.
A definition for CTP.
Our insurance is designed for people who are unable to access mainstream insurance products due to their financial circumstances and/or poor insurance, claims or criminal history.
A definition for GIO.
Shannons is Australia's leading insurance provider for motoring enthusiasts.
A definition for Suncorp.
A definition for Terri Scheer.

A Competent Person is a minerals industry professional, who is a [National Reporting Organisation (NRO) to insert appropriate membership class and name of Professional Organisation (PO)] or other Recognised Professional Organisations (RPOs) with enforceable disciplinary processes including the powers to suspend or expel a member. A Competent Person must have a minimum of five years relevant experience in the style of mineralisation or type of deposit under consideration and in the activity which that person is undertaking.

Exploration Results include data and information generated by mineral exploration programmes that might be of use to investors, but which do not form part of a declaration of Mineral Resources or Mineral Reserves.

An Exploration Target is a statement or estimate of the exploration potential of a mineral deposit in a defined geological setting where the statement or estimate, quoted as a range of tonnes and a range of grade or quality, relates to mineralisation for which there has been insufficient exploration to estimate Mineral Resources.

A Feasibility Study is a comprehensive technical and economic study of the selected development option for a mineral project that includes appropriately detailed assessments of applicable Modifying Factors together with any other relevant operational factors and detailed financial analysis that are necessary to demonstrate at the time of reporting that extraction is reasonably justified (economically mineable). The results of the study may reasonably serve as the basis for a final decision by a proponent or financial institution to proceed with, or finance, the development of the project. The confidence level of the study will be higher than that of a Pre-Feasibility Study.

An Indicated Mineral Resource is that part of a Mineral Resource for which quantity, grade or quality, densities, shape and physical characteristics are estimated with sufficient confidence to allow the application of Modifying Factors in sufficient detail to support mine planning and evaluation of the economic viability of the deposit. Geological evidence is derived from adequately detailed and reliable exploration, sampling and testing and is sufficient to assume geological and grade or quality continuity between points of observation. An Indicated Mineral Resource has a lower level of confidence than that applying to a Measured Mineral Resource and may only be converted to a Probable Mineral Reserve.

An Inferred Mineral Resource is that part of a Mineral Resource for which quantity and grade or quality are estimated on the basis of limited geological evidence and sampling. Geological evidence is sufficient to imply but not verify geological and grade or quality continuity. An Inferred Resource has a lower level of confidence than that applying to an Indicated Mineral Resource and must not be converted to a Mineral Reserve. It is reasonably expected that the majority of Inferred Mineral Resources could be upgraded to Indicated Mineral Resources with continued exploration.

A Measured Mineral Resource is that part of a Mineral Resource for which quantity, grade or quality, densities, shape, and physical characteristics are estimated with confidence sufficient to allow the application of Modifying Factors to support detailed mine planning and final evaluation of the economic viability of the deposit. Geological evidence is derived from detailed and reliable exploration, sampling and testing and is sufficient to confirm geological and grade or quality continuity between points of observation. A Measured Mineral Resource has a higher level of confidence than that applying to either an Indicated Mineral Resource or an Inferred Mineral Resource. It may be converted to a Proved Mineral Reserve or to a Probable Mineral Reserve.

A Mineral is any substance, extracted for value, occurring naturally in or on the Earth, in or under water or in tailings, residues or stockpiles, having been formed by or subjected to a geological process but excludes, water, oil and gas.

A Mineral Reserve is the economically mineable part of a Measured and/or Indicated Mineral Resource. It includes diluting materials and allowances for losses, which may occur when the material is mined or extracted and is defined by studies at Pre-Feasibility or Feasibility level as appropriate that include application of Modifying Factors. Such studies demonstrate that, at the time of reporting, extraction could reasonably be justified. The reference point at which Mineral Reserves are defined, usually the point where the ore is delivered to the processing plant, must be stated. It is important that, in all situations where the reference point is different, such as for a saleable product, a clarifying statement is included to ensure that the reader is fully informed as to what is being reported.

A Mineral Resource is a concentration or occurrence of solid material of economic interest in or on the Earths crust in such form, grade or quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction. The location, quantity, grade or quality, continuity and other geological characteristics of a Mineral Resource are known, estimated or interpreted from specific geological evidence and knowledge, including sampling. Mineral Resources are subdivided, in order of increasing geological confidence into Inferred, Indicated and Measured categories.

Modifying Factors are considerations used to convert Mineral Resources to Mineral Reserves. These include, but are not restricted to, mining, processing, metallurgical, infrastructure, economic, marketing, legal, environmental, social and governmental factors.

A Pre-Feasibility Study is a comprehensive study of a range of options for the technical and economic viability of a mineral project that has advanced to a stage where a preferred mining method, in the case of underground mining, or the pit configuration, in the case of an open pit, is established and an effective method of mineral processing is determined. It includes a financial analysis based on reasonable assumptions on the Modifying Factors and the evaluation of any other relevant factors which are sufficient for a Competent Person, acting reasonably, to determine if all or part of the Mineral Resource may be converted to a Mineral Reserve at the time of reporting. A Pre-Feasibility Study is at a lower confidence level than a Feasibility Study.

A Probable Mineral Reserve is the economically mineable part of an Indicated, and in some circumstances, a Measured Mineral Resource. The confidence in the Modifying Factors applying to a Probable Mineral Reserve is lower than that applying to a Proved Mineral Reserve.
A Proved Mineral Reserve is the economically mineable part of a Measured Mineral Resource. A Proved Mineral Reserve implies a high degree of confidence in the Modifying Factors.

Public Reports are reports prepared for the purpose of informing investors or potential investors and their advisers on Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources or Mineral Reserves. They include but are not limited to annual and quarterly company reports, media releases, information memoranda, technical papers, website postings and public presentations.

A Scoping Study is an order of magnitude technical and economic study of the potential viability of Mineral Resources that includes appropriate assessments of realistically assumed Modifying Factors together with any other relevant operational factors that are necessary to demonstrate at the time of reporting that progress to a PreFeasibility Study can be reasonably justified.

1 Adelaide Terrace is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. It houses the Resources Safety and Dangerous Goods Divisions, and both Private and Public Sector Labour Relations subdivisions of the Department. The office is located at Level 3, 1 Adelaide Terrace, East Perth WA 6004.

66 St Georges Terrace is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. It houses the Energy Policy WA subdivision of the Department. The building is in the Perth CBD at Level 1, 66 St Georges Terrace, Perth WA 6000.

Carlisle is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. The site includes several buildings encompassing separate functions of the Geological Survey of Western Australia, including the Perth Core Library, and is located at 37 Harris St, Carlisle WA 6101.

The Collie office, one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, houses the South Mine Inspectorate, and is at 66 Wittenoom Street, Collie WA 6225.

Western Australia has two purpose-built core libraries: the Perth Core Library, located in Carlisle, and the Joe Lord Core Library in Kalgoorlie. The core libraries archive drillcore acquired during mineral and petroleum exploration in the State. They include viewing and sampling facilities to assist subsequent exploration activity. Both facilities are administered by the Geological Survey.

The Kalgoorlie office is one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, representing the department in the Goldfields and Esperance regions. In addition to administrative functions of the Department and of the Geological Survey of Western Australia, the Kalgoorlie office houses the Joe (JH) Lord Core Library, East Mine Inspectorate and Kalgoorlie Mining Registrar. The office is at the corner of Hunter and Broadwood Streets, West Kalgoorlie WA 6430.

Gordon Stephenson House is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. It houses the Consumer Protection Group of the department. The building is in the Perth CBD at 140 William Street, Perth WA 6000.

The Albany office is one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, representing the department in the Great Southern region. The office is at 2/129 Aberdeen St, Albany WA 6331.

The JH (Joe) Lord Core Library is one of two Geological Survey storage and viewing facilities housing geological exploration materials (predominantly drillcores and samples) and related media. The building is on the Kalgoorlie site at the corner of Hunter and Broadwood Streets, West Kalgoorlie WA 6430.

The Broome office is one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, representing the department in the Kimberley region. The office is at Level 1, Woody's Arcade, 6/15 Dampier Terrace, Broome WA 6725.

The Leonora office, one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, houses the Leonora Mining Registrar, and is at the corner of Tower (Goldfield Highway) and Rochester Streets, Leonora WA 6438.

Mason Bird Building is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. It houses the Building and Energy and WorkSafe Divisions of the Department. The building is at 303 Sevenoaks Street, Cannington WA 6107.
Offices of the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety located in the Perth metropolitan area (Western Australia).

The Geraldton office is one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, representing the department in the Mid-West region. The office is in the Post Office Plaza at 5052 Durlacher Street, Geraldton WA 6531.

Mineral House is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. It is the department's main administrative office, housing the Geological Survey and Resource Strategy, Resource and Environmental Compliance, Resource Tenure and Aboriginal Empowerment Petroleum, Mineral Titles Divisions of the Department, the West Mine Inspectorate and the Perth Mining Registrar. The building is at 100 Plain St, East Perth WA 6004.

The Mount Magnet office, one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, houses the Mount Magnet Mining Registrar, and is at the corner of Hepburn and Richardson Streets, Mount Magnet WA 6638.

The Karratha office is one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, representing the department in the North West region. The office houses the Karratha Mining Registrar and North Mine Inspectorate, and is located at Level 2, The Quarter, 20 Sharpe Avenue, Karratha WA 6714.

The Perth Core Library is one of two Geological Survey storage and viewing facilities housing geological exploration materials (predominantly drillcores and samples) and related media. The building is on the Carlisle site at 37 Harris Street, Carlisle WA 6101.
The Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety has representative offices in a number of regional centres in Western Australia.

The Bunbury office is one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, representing the department in the South West region. The office is located at Level 8, 61 Victoria Street, Bunbury WA 6230.

The Southern Cross office, one of several regional offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety, houses the Southern Cross Mining Registrar, and is located at 75 Canopus Street, Southern Cross WA 6426.
A seismic method that involves monitoring artificially induced signals.
Remotely sensed spectral imaging obtained from an airborne platform.

A discipline concerned with investigating the Earth from the surface to a depth of several kilometres, specifically aiming to meet the growing demands for natural resources and geo-energies, to respond to the effects of climate change, to provide critical data for civil engineers, and to forecast the effects of natural hazards.

Applied mineralogy is located at the intersection of natural sciences and engineering sciences/technology and deals with the entire line of raw material, from extraction/preparation to processing and disposal, i.e. the application of mineralogical information to understanding and solving problems encountered during exploration and mining, and during processing of ores, concentrates, smelter products, and related materials. It involves characterizing minerals and materials, and interpreting the data with respect to exploration, mineral processing, tailings disposal and treatment, hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, and refining.
The study of human cultures through the recovery and analysis of their material relics.

Archival science, or archival studies, is the study and theory of building and curating archives, i.e. collections of documents, recordings, photographs and various other materials in physical or digital formats, for the purpose of acquiring, evaluating, and accessing recorded materials.

Artificial intelligence (AI), in its broadest sense, is intelligence exhibited by machines, particularly computer systems, i.e. the capability of machines/computers to imitate intelligent human behaviour without being explicitly programmed. By extension, a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and uses learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

The field of science concerned with the study of life in the universe and attempting to solve the mystery of how life emerged on Earth. This includes the search for life beyond Earth, studying environments that could support life as well as investigating interactions between planets and their stars and exploring how this could influence life. Astrobiology is very much an interdisciplinary endeavour encompassing a wide range of scientific fields such as, but not limited to; biology, astronomy, chemistry, geology, atmospheric science, oceanography, and even aeronautical engineering.

The natural sciences that study celestial objects and the phenomena that occur in the cosmos. It uses mathematics, physics, and chemistry to explain their origin and their overall evolution. Objects of interest include planets, moons, stars, nebulae, galaxies, meteoroids, asteroids, and comets or, more generally, everything that originates beyond Earth's atmosphere.
The study of the Earth's atmosphere and its various inner-working physical processes.

The study of the undifferentiated complex of rocks that underlies the rocks of interest in an area, i.e. the crust of the Earth below sedimentary deposits and regolith, extending downward to the Mohorovii discontinuity. Basement geology may be self-referential in that it is also the study of defining what constitutes basement at regional and local scales, and whether geologically or economically defined.

A geological method of studying sedimentary basins and their potential for energy/mineral commodities, by analysing the sediment fill itself (its composition, primary structures, and internal architecture) to synthesize the basin's geological history/evolution.

A highly interdisciplinary field involving the integration of biology, geology and chemistry, and encompassing the study of the chemical, physical, geological and biological processes and reactions that govern the composition of the natural environment (including the biosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, pedosphere and the lithosphere).

The interdisciplinary study of biology and geology, embracing interactions between the Earth's biosphere and geosphere (i.e. lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and cryosphere). It encompasses the biological aspects of geology, e.g. systematic paleontology, the study of organically influenced sedimentation, or the identification of a concealed rock unit by the type of plant growing at the surface above it.
The natural science that studies life and living organisms, including their physical structure, chemical processes, molecular interactions, physiological mechanisms, development and evolution.

The correlation and age determination of rocks through the use of fossils, i.e. the determination of approximate absolute ages from the distribution of fossil assemblages in strata and primarily based on a number of time scales that related absolute age to the established sequence of (primarily planktonic) fossil events.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the distribution of fossils in the stratigraphic record and the organization of strata into units on the basis of their contained fossils, specifically to date and correlate strata to elucidate Earth's history. In the petroleum industry, biostratigraphy often denotes the use of terrestrial (pollen and spores) and marine (diatoms, foraminifera, nanofossils) microfossils to determine the numerical or relative age and depositional environment of a particular formation, source rock, or reservoir of interest.

Boreheole (or well) logging is the practice of making a detailed record (a well log, report or graph) of the geological materials and formations penetrated by a borehole. The log may be based either on visual inspection of samples brought to the surface (geological logs) or on physical measurements made on these samples or by instruments lowered into the hole (geophysical logs). Some types of geophysical well logs can be done during any phase of a well's history: drilling, completing, producing, or abandoning. Logging is performed in boreholes drilled for the oil and gas, groundwater, mineral and geothermal exploration, as well as part of environmental, geotechnical or geological studies.

Built environment refers to human-made conditions and physical features, and is commonly used in architecture, landscape architecture, urban and regional planning, public health, sociology, and anthropology, among others. These curated spaces provide the setting for human activity and were created to fulfill human desires and needs. The term can refer to a plethora of components including the traditionally associated buildings, cities, public infrastructure, transportation, open space, as well as more conceptual components like farmlands, dammed rivers, wildlife management, and even domesticated animals. Studies of the built environment often highlight the connection between physical space and social consequences. It impacts the environment and how society physically manoeuvers and functions, as well as less tangible aspects of society such as socioeconomic inequity and health.

Studies related to the identification of deep, subsurface geological sites that are suitable to act as reservoirs for the long-term storage of injected CO, to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions to the atmosphere.

The science and art of making maps and charts, and the specific use of digital technologies (mapping tools and software) to create seamless geographical displays of data as an image on a computer screen.

Chemostratigraphy, or chemical stratigraphy, is the study of the chemical signatures and their variations within lithological sequences to determine stratigraphic relationships. It includes the element of stratigraphy that deals with chemical signals as recorded in the stratigraphic record to identify spatialtemporal variations in the concentration and distribution of particular elements and isotopes (e.g. carbonate cycles and isotope cycles).
The branch of stratigraphy that deals with the age of strata and their time relations.

Climate change science is the study of changes in the statistical properties of the climate system that persists for several decades or longer  usually at least 30 years. In a broader sense, climate change science also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate. These statistical properties include averages, variability and extremes. Climate change may be due to natural processes, such as changes in the Suns radiation, volcanoes activity or internal variability in the climate system, or due to human influences such as changes in the composition of the atmosphere or land use caused by human activity (e.g. burning of fossil fuels, deforestation). In common usage, climate change is often used interchangeably to describe global warming  the ongoing increase in global average temperature  and its effects on Earth's climate system.

Climatology or climate science is the scientific study of Earth's climate, typically defined as weather conditions averaged over a period of at least 30 years. Climate concerns the atmospheric condition during an extended to indefinite period of time; weather is the condition of the atmosphere during a relative brief period of time and is studied by within the field of meteorology.

Coal geology includes the study of the sedimentation of coals and coal-bearing sequences; their stratigraphy, age and geographic distribution; their physical properties, including coal rank and quality, and the associated classification of coals; their hydrogeological characteristics; contained gases, and the contribution of coal deposits (amongst other rock types) to accumulations of oil and natural gas.

Collection management refers to the development, storage, and preservation of cultural and natural property, as well as objects of contemporary culture (including contemporary art, literature, technology, and documents) in museums, libraries, archives and private collections. The primary goal of collections management is to meet the needs of the individual collector or collecting institution's mission statement, while also ensuring the long-term safety and sustainability of the objects within the collector's care. Collections management consists primarily of the administrative responsibilities associated with collection development and maintenance (information, preservation, movement, documentation, exhibitions and access processes), and is closely related to collections care, that is the physical preservation for posterity of items in the collections.

concepts.prefLabel: computational modelling and simulation in earth sciences
concepts.definition: A multidisciplinary field that combines geoscience with advanced mathematical modelling, simulation, numerical modelling, visualization and data analysis techniques. Computational geoscience uses large-scale, nonlinear models that couple multiple physical, chemical, and biological processes across various length and time scales to improve our understanding of the Earth system and its complexities, addressing geoscience grand challenges, and providing decision-support tools for geoscience policy makers and industry. The emergence of computation as a powerful tool for prediction and decision-making in the geosciences is driven by advances in the rapid expansion of our ability to instrument and observe the Earth, sustained improvements in computational models and solution methods for complex geoscience systems, and the relentless growth in computing power.

Computed tomography (CT) is a method for imaging and analysing features in rock, mineral or soil specimens in three dimensions using energy attenuation of photons (X-ray tomography), neutrons (neutron tomography), ultrasonic waves (ultrasound tomography), or using magnetic resonance (magnetic resonance imaging). The detected data are used to reconstruct the internal distribution of materials.

The study of conventional (carbonate and clastic) petroleum systems that contain hydrocarbon accumulations and are defined as those where buoyant forces keep hydrocarbons in place below the sealing caprocks and permit petroleum (oil and/or natural gas) to flow readily from reservoirs into wellbores; i.e. are accessible by standard oilfield techniques and typically do not require advanced drilling, completions, and reservoir stimulation methods. Studies of conventional reservoir include assessment of rock properties, particularly porosity, permeability and compressibility, and of the timing and mechanism of trap formation, as petroleum source rocks, reservoir rocks, impermeable caprocks/seals must form in a favourable sequence to allow accumulation in reservoir rocks (following petroleum generation in source rocks and its ensuing migration therefrom).
Studies related to the measurement of petrophysical properties in samples collected in the field or from drillcores.

Core logging is the systematic recording and analysis of drillcores, to provide geological understanding of the materials penetrated by a borehole, and to assist in resource estimation. It employs different methods and techniques to characterize subsurface minerals, rocks and formations, as well as their geometry, structure and relationships relative to depth  by observation, measurements and analysis. Although a large proportion of drilling is carried out in the pursuit of mineral and energy resources, core logging is also a critical component of other investigations (e.g. stratigraphic, geotechnical, etc.).
Spectral imaging (typically hyperspectral) of rock samples such as core.

The study of crystals, i.e. of homogeneous, solid bodies of chemical element, compound, or isomorphous mixture, having regularly repeating atomic arrangement that may be outwardly expressed by plane faces. It comprises studies of crystal growth, structure, physical properties and their classification by form. It includes optical crystallography (the branch dealing with the optical properties of crystals) and structural crystallography (the study of the internal arrangement and spacing of atoms and molecules composing crystalline solids).

The process of extracting and discovering patterns in large datasets involving methods at the intersection of machine learning, statistics, and database systems. Data mining is an interdisciplinary subfield of computer science and statistics with an overall goal of extracting information (with intelligent methods) from a dataset and transforming the information into a comprehensible structure for further use.

Data science is an interdisciplinary academic field that uses statistics, scientific computing, scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from noisy, structured, and unstructured data. Data management is the practice of collecting, organizing, protecting, and storing an organizations data so it can be analysed for business decisions or provided to third parties.

Deep learning is a subset of machine learning methods that utilize neural networks for representation learning, i.e. simulate the complex decision-making power of the human brain. The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and is centered around stacking artificial neurons into layers and 'training' them to process data. The adjective 'deep' refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.'
The study of annual growth rings of trees for dating of the recent past.

Descriptive mineralogy includes a description of the crystallographic, general physical and chemical characters of each mineral species, and provides an account of their mode of occurrence and characteristic associations. For minerals possessing an economic value, it includes a brief statement of their uses and industrial applications.

Digital heritage is the use of digital media in the service of understanding and preserving cultural or natural heritage; more specifically, according to the Charter on the Preservation of Digital Heritage of UNESCO, digital heritage is defined as embracing 'cultural, educational, scientific and administrative resources, as well as technical, legal, medical and other kinds of information created digitally, or converted into digital form from existing analogue resources'. The main goal of the digitization of cultural and natural heritage is to enable the preservation and permanent access of current and future generations to culturally and scientific important objects at all scales.
Downhole, or borehole, geophysical surveys measure the physical properties of rocks along a subsurface drillhole.

Studies related to and associated with the technological advancement of drilling operations, aimed at mitigating the drilling operational deficiencies and instabilities that could hinder operational performance activities and the economic part of drilling development with great effort to minimize their environmental footprint. It includes geoscience-related results obtained during the testing of improved or emerging technologies.

The science of designing as well as safely and economically making a hole (also called a well or wellbore) from the surface through a rock (or formation) to target potential energy or mineral resources in the subsurface and facilitate the evaluation of the geological intervals penetrated.

Earth and Space Science Informatics (ESSI) encompasses a broad field that addresses data management practices, computation and analysis, and hardware and software infrastructure. It involves collaborative work to assess, design, implement, and promote practices and tools that enable effective data management, discovery, integration, and reuse for interdisciplinary work in Earth and space science (ESS) disciplines.

An all-embracing term for all fields of natural sciences related to the planet Earth. It is occasionally used as a synonym for geology or geological sciences, but this usage is misleading because in its wider scope earth science may be considered to include such subjects as meteorology, physical oceanography, soil chemistry, and agronomy.

The study of Earth as an integrated system, particularly the physical, chemical, biological and human interactions that determine the past, current and future states of the Earth. Earth System Science is the study of the interactions and interdependencies within and between the Earths various physical, chemical and biological spheres (lithosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, atmosphere, cryosphere), and the impacts that changes to any of these may have for the entire Earth System (including humans).
A branch of biology concerning interactions among organisms and their biophysical environment, which includes both biotic and abiotic components.
A discipline that investigates and promotes understanding of economic and policy issues associated with the production and use of mineral and energy commodities.

concepts.prefLabel: electrical and electromagnetic methods in geophysics
concepts.definition: Geophysical methods that involve the use of electrical and electromagnetic fields to study the subsurface properties of the Earth. These methods exploit the interaction between electromagnetic waves and the electrical conductivity, permittivity, and magnetic susceptibility of subsurface materials.

The use of geophysical methods to detect and image different electrical properties of the subsurface, by measuring naturally occurring (i.e. passive) or artificially introduced (i.e. active) voltage potentials, electrical currents, and/or electromagnetic fields. Subsurface electrical properties can be measured galvanically via direct electrode connection to the ground or inductively via electromagnetic field induction through the subsurface. The Electrical resistivity technique is used to determine the resistivity of subsurface materials, the Induced Polarization (IP) technique is used to measure the decay of voltage in the ground, and the Self-Potential (SP) technique looks for natural voltage sources underground.

The use of geophysical methods to detect and image the electrical properties of the subsurface by inducing electromagnetic (EM) energy within the subsurface (i.e. propagation of electromagnetic fields composed of an alternating electric intensity and magnetizing force) and measuring the response of earth materials.

The measurement and modelling of the elevation of geographic locations, i.e. of the height above or below a fixed reference point, most commonly a reference geoid (a mathematical model of the Earth's sea level as an equipotential gravitational surface).

The search for deposits of useful fossil fuels and energy resources. It includes multidisciplinary approaches, including geological studies, remote sensing, photogeology, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and below ground investigations.

A branch of geology that focuses on the study of conventional, non-conventional and renewable natural resources used for energy production, i.e. including fossil fuels (like coal, oil, and natural gas), renewable energy resources (like wind, solar, and geothermal), and nuclear resources. This field involves understanding the formation, distribution, extraction, and environmental impacts of these energy resource.

The practice of using natural science, mathematics, and the (engineering) design process to solve technical problems, increase efficiency and productivity, and improve systems. More specifically, 'the creative application of scientific principles to design or develop structures, machines, apparatus, or manufacturing processes, or works utilizing them singly or in combination; or to construct or operate the same with full cognizance of their design; or to forecast their behaviour under specific operating conditions; all as respects an intended function, economics of operation and safety to life and property' (American Engineers' Council for Professional Development).

The application of geology to engineering study for the purpose of assuring that the geological factors regarding the location, design, construction, operation and maintenance of engineering works are recognized and accounted for. Engineering geologists provide geological and geotechnical recommendations, analysis, and design associated with human development and various types of structures. The realm of the engineering geologist is essentially in the area of Earth-structure interactions, or investigation of how the Earth or Earth processes impact human-made structures and human activities.

A professional engineering discipline related to environmental science that encompasses broad scientific topics like chemistry, biology, ecology, geology, hydraulics, hydrology, microbiology, and mathematics to create solutions that will protect and also improve the health of living organisms and improve the quality of the environment.
The study of the effect on humans (and life in general) of the distribution and interrelations of the chemical elements and radioactivity among surficial rocks, water, air, and biota.

A multidisciplinary, applied science concerned with the practical application of the principles of geology in the solving of environmental problems created by humans and their activities. Environmental geology is specifically concerned with Earth processes, Earth resources, and engineering properties of Earth materials that are relevant to: 1) the protection of human health and natural ecosystems from adverse biochemical and/or geochemical reactions to naturally occurring chemicals or to chemicals and chemical compounds released into the environment by human activities; and 2) the protection of life, safety, and well-being human from natural processes, such as floods, hurricanes, earthquakes and landslides, through land-use planning.
Environmental resource management or environmental management is the management of the interaction and impact of human societies on the environment (and not the management of the environment itself).

An interdisciplinary academic field that integrates physical, biological and information sciences to the study of the environment, and the solution of environmental problems. It specifically addresses: (1) social and political decision making and policy setting relative to the environment or environmental ethics, (2) the planning and management of natural and human resources with an emphasis on the social and political aspects, and (3) legal and regulatory aspects of environmental protection activities carried out by the government under its powers.

Evolutionary paleontology (also called evolutionary paleobiology) is paleontologys intersection with evolutionary biology. Its main aims are to reconstruct the history of life on Earth (historical paleontology, phylogeny) and the patterns and causes of evolutionary change and extinction (biological and physical processes and unique historical events).

Experimental mineralogy and petrology are the Earth science disciplines that model or simulate mineralogical, petrological, and geochemical processes within the laboratory in order to understand the physical and chemical properties of minerals, rocks, melts, and fluids and their interactions.

A discipline that employs high-pressure, high-temperature apparatus to investigate the geochemistry and phase relations of natural or synthetic materials at elevated pressures and temperatures. Experiments are particularly useful for investigating rocks of the lower crust and upper mantle that rarely survive the journey to the surface in pristine condition. They are also one of the prime sources of information about completely inaccessible rocks, such as those in the Earth's lower mantle and in the mantles of the other terrestrial planets and the Moon. The work of experimental petrologists has laid a foundation on which modern understanding of igneous and metamorphic processes has been built.

Geochemistry that is specifically focused on identification of mineralization, its dispersion haloes, alteration patterns and distribution. It specifically focuses on the enrichment or depletion of certain elements (including pathfinders) having a genetic affinity to the target mineralization. Exploration geochemistry is typical of exploration stages aiming at locating mineral deposits but also applies to the near-mine exploration conducted to further locate and delineate resources.

A planetary science discipline concerned with the geology of celestial bodies such as the planets and their moons, asteroids, comets, and meteorites, i.e. a science that applies principles and techniques of geology, geochemistry, and geophysics to the study of the nature, origin, and history of the condensed matter and gases in the solar system and beyond. It includes a) remote-sensing observations and in situ manned exploration of other planetary bodies, such as the Moon and Mars, Venus, Mercury, and 'earthlike' or 'rocky' satellite moons of the giant planets; b) the study of the chemistry, mineralogy (cosmic mineralogy), and history of objects that occur on the Earth but are of known or possible extraterrestrial origin (such as meteorites and tektites) or that are returned to the Earth (such as lunar samples); and c) the study of the effects of extraterrestrial processes (such as meteorite impact, solar energy changes, and tides) on the Earth in the present and past.
Analysis of the chemical and physical properties of fluids extracted from rocks and geological materials in the subsurface.

The study of the composition, stratigraphy and petrology of liquids and/or gases contained within tiny (usually in the order of micrometres) cavities formed either by the entrapment in crystal irregularities of fluids from which the mineral/rock crystallized, or by any process after the crystallization of the host mineral is essentially complete (e.g. healing of fractures within a crystal).

The study of tiny encapsulations of fluids that trap oil, gas, water and solid phases in minerals and rocks to determine parameters such as temperature, pressure, salinity, density and depth of trapping  thereby providing direct information about the conditions of formation. In the case of hydrocarbon exploration, these studies are conducted to assess the fluid history of the rock/sedimentary basin and the prevailing thermal conditions, to determine whether oil and gas are likely to be found at a particular location, as well as the source and type of hydrocarbon present.

The study of trace evidence provided by Earth materials that is used to answer questions raised by the legal system, specifically the potential to link a suspect to a particular crime or a particular crime scene.

Functional morphology is an interpretative subdiscipline of paleobiology, and is the study of the form, structure and function of organisms or parts of organisms in terms of the biological roles that they play (i.e. function and behaviour).
The science and study of natural and artificial gemstones, including their source, description, geology, origin, identification, grading and appraisal.

The empirical investigation of the principles that control mineral formation in the geological environment, including mineral paragenesis and the physical and chemical parameters of formation and alteration (mineral ontogenesis); the quantitative geothermometric, geobarometric, and chemical studies of mineral-forming systems; and experimental modelling of crystal growth in the laboratory.

A multi-disciplinary approach that uses the techniques and subject matter of geography, geology, geophysics and other Earth sciences to examine topics which inform archeological and chronological knowledge and thought. Geoarcheologists study the natural physical processes that affect archeological sites such as geomorphology, the formation of sites through geological processes and the effects on buried sites and artifacts post-deposition.

An interdisciplinary study of life sciences and Earth sciences, i.e. the field of scientific research that explores the interactions between the physical Earth and the biosphere to investigate the evolutionary interconnectedness of life and Earth  it deals with process (how organisms affect the Earth and vice versa), as well as history (how the Earth and life have changed together). There is considerable overlap with the fields of ecology, evolutionary biology, microbiology, paleontology, and particularly soil science and biogeochemistry. Geobiology applies the principles and methods of biology, geology and soil science to the study of the ancient history of the co-evolution of life and Earth as well as the role of life in the modern world. Geobiological studies tend to be focused on micro-organisms, and on the role that life plays in altering the chemical and physical environment of the pedosphere, which exists at the intersection of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and/or cryosphere. It differs from biogeochemistry in that the focus is on processes and organisms over space and time rather than on global chemical cycles.

The study of the distribution and amounts of the chemical elements in minerals, ores, rocks, soils, water, the atmosphere on Earth and within solid bodies of the solar system, including the distribution, circulation and abundance of elements (and their ions and isotopes), molecules, minerals, rocks and fluids.
Geochemical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geochemistry.

The science of dating and determining the time sequence of events in the history of the Earth, i.e. the study of the relative or numerical/absolute age of rocks, minerals and fossils. Numerical age is the measurement of age in years ('numerical' is preferred to 'absolute' ages, as the latter typically have some amount of error and are inexact) whereas relative age, in contrast, is the approximate age of rocks, fossils or minerals made by determining the age of the material relative to the age of and relationships with other surrounding material.

The practice of protecting and managing sites and landscapes which have value for their geology or geomorphology. The identification (cf. geoheritage) and conservation of these geological sites is through government agencies and local geological societies. The designation of these sites is done through an analysis of the site, and the production of proper management infrastructure. The principles of geoconservation are to create a means of protection for the sites and assess their value to the geological and wider community. Typically the conservation of geodiversity at a site or within a landscape takes place alongside that of biodiversity.

The science of measuring and representing the geometry (size and shape) of the Earth and the precise location of points on its surface; it includes the determination of the gravitational field of the Earth and the study of temporal variations such as Earth tides, polar motion, and rotation of the Earth.

A subfield of geophysics dealing with the forces and processes of the interior of the Earth. It applies physics, chemistry and mathematics to the understanding of how mantle convection leads to plate tectonics and geological phenomena such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting and so on. It also attempts to probe the internal activities of the Earth by measuring magnetic fields, gravity, and seismic waves, as well as the mineralogy of rocks and their isotopic composition.

The branch of ethics that considers the interaction of human activity with the physical world and with the practice of the Earth Sciences. It comprises scientific research and philosophical reflection on the values governing human behaviours wherever they interact with the Earth system, including the ethical, social, and cultural implications of the activities of geoscientists when conducting scientific and technological research and practice.

Geographic Information Science (GIScience) is the basic research field that seeks to redefine geographic concepts and their use in the context of geographic information systems. GIScience also examines the impacts of GIS on individuals and society, and the influences of society on GIS. GIScience re-examines some of the most fundamental themes in traditional spatially oriented fields such as geography, cartography, and geodesy, while incorporating more recent developments in cognitive and information science

The study of adverse geological conditions capable of causing widespread damage or loss of property and life. These hazards are geological and environmental conditions and involve long-term or short-term geological processes. Geohazards can be relatively small features (e.g. geyser) but can also attain huge dimensions (e.g. submarine or surface landslide) and affect local and regional socio-economics to a large extent (e.g. tsunamis, volcanic eruptions).

The identification of global, national, state-wide, or local features of geology (such as igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary, stratigraphic, structural, geochemical, mineralogical, paleontological, geomorphical, pedological, and hydrological attributes) that are: (a) intrinsically important or culturally important sites; (b) offer information or insights into the formation or evolution of the Earth, or into the history of science, or (c) that can be used for research, teaching, or reference. Geoheritage is inextricably linked to geoconservation, for the preservation of these sites for posterity.

The application of modern information technology/computational systems to organize, preserve, and distribute geoscience data, and to facilitate and advance their analysis, i.e. the science and technology that develop and use data, software, and computing facilities in the cyberinfrastructure ecosystem to address the needs of geosciences and related branches of science and engineering.
Geoinformatics data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geoinformatics.

The process of making observations in the field, as well as collecting and studying samples of Earth's materials to understand the geology of an area, and more specifically to produce a diagram, drawing, or other graphical representation of the area in question, by means of signs and/or symbols and with the means of orientation indicated, so that the relative position and size of each feature on the map corresponds to its correct geographical situation according to a definite and established scale and projection.
The applied science of creating computerized representations of portions of the Earths subsurface based on geophysical and geological observations made on and below the Earth surface.

An Earth science concerned with the planet Earth and the rocks/materials of which it is made, the processes that act on these materials and by which these change over time, the products formed, to understand the history of the planet and its life forms since its origin, and including the study of physical forces that act on the Earth, the chemistry of its constituent materials, and the biology of its past inhabitants as revealed by fossils. Geology can also include the study of the solid features of any terrestrial planet or natural satellite such as Mars or the Moon. Modern geology significantly overlaps all other earth sciences, including hydrology and the atmospheric sciences, and so is treated as one major aspect of integrated Earth system science and planetary science.
Geological data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geology.

The development and application of mathematical methods and principles to process geoscientific data for geological feature imaging or for understanding (modelling) geological processes, from the atomic to planetary scale, across the entire spectrum of geoscientific disciplines.

A professional engineering discipline that focuses on spatial information (i.e. information that has a location) to design, develop, and operate systems for collecting and analysing spatial information about the land, the oceans, natural resources, and man-made features.
Geomatic engineering data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geomatics engineering.

The discipline concerned with the collection, distribution, storage, analysis, processing, presentation of geographic data or geographic information, as well as the products, services and tools involved in the collection, integration and management of geographic (geospatial) data.

A branch at the intersection of geology and engineering that embraces the fundamentals of structural geology and a knowledge of the response, or strain, of earth materials (soil and rocks) to deformation or changes caused by the application of stress and/or strain energy, as well as the application of such studies to solve engineering problems in the design of engineering works.

The practice of combining geology or geostatistics with extractive metallurgy, to create a spatially or geologically based predictive model to optimize the efficiency of mineral processing plants. Geometallurgy specifically maps the 3D variability in petrophysical and mineralogical properties of an entire orebody, to define domains that require different mining and metallurgical processing techniques, to maximize recovery of the saleable product at minimum cost.

The scientific study of the general configuration of the Earth's surface, i.e. of the origin and evolution of topographic and bathymetric features created by physical, chemical or biological processes operating at or near the Earth's surface.
