Specifically studies dealing with the classification, description, nature, origin, processes, and development of present landforms and their relationships to underlying structures, and of the history of geological changes as recorded by these surface features. Geomorphology overlaps in meaning with physiography, with 'physiography' commonly regarded as a more descriptive and 'geomorphology' as a more interpretative study of landforms.
The study of fluid dynamics of naturally occurring flows, such as lava flows, oceans, and planetary atmospheres, on Earth and other planets.

The applied science of creating computerized representations of the Earth based on geophysical and geological observations and their interpretation. Geophysical models are a simplified concept and/or visualization of how one or more physical properties are distributed within the Earth. They are generally an object, a halfspace, 1D (layered earth), 2D, or 3D.

A natural science concerned with the physical processes and physical properties of the Earth and its surrounding space environment, and the use of quantitative methods for their analysis. It includes several disciplines focusing on the study of the Earth's electrical, gravitational and magnetic fields and the propagation of elastic (seismic) waves within it.
Geophysical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geophysics.

A variety of practices that transmit scientific ideas, methods, knowledge, and research to non-expert audiences in an accessible, understandable, or useful way, with a particular focus on subjects related to Earth's physical features, processes, and systems.
The developing of tools that promote geoscience data integration and synthesis, and also facilitate quantitative cross-disciplinary access to data.

Also known as Earth science education, it is the study of Earth's physical features, processes, and systems, as well as the natural and human-induced events that shape it. It encompasses a wide range of disciplines, including geology, oceanography, meteorology, climatology, environmental science, and more. Geoscience education plays a crucial role in fostering scientific literacy, environmental awareness, and sustainable development, as well as in preparing future generations of geoscientists, policymakers, educators, and citizens.

concepts.prefLabel: geospatial information systems and geospatial data modelling
concepts.definition: The application of geographic information systems (GIS), i.e. an integrated computer hardware and software, to store, manage, analyse, edit, output, visualize and model geographic data.

A branch of statistics focusing on spatial or spatiotemporal datasets, developed originally to predict probability distributions of ore grades for mining operations, but now applied also in petroleum geology, hydrogeology, hydrology, meteorology, oceanography, geochemistry, geometallurgy, geography, forestry, environmental control, landscape ecology, soil science and agriculture.
Engineering applied to the capture and storage of materials (commonly liquids and gases, and especially greenhouse gases) or energy (commonly gas or heat) in the subsurface of the Earth.

A field at the intersection of geology and engineering dealing with the study of the engineering behaviours of earth materials to address engineering problems. It uses soil and rock mechanics for practical applications in, amongst other disciplines, mining engineering, petroleum engineering, coastal engineering, and onshore/offshore construction.

The study of the accessible thermal energy stored within the Earth's crust, in order to access and extract it. It includes studies of related geological systems and the methods, materials and operations used in the production of energy.

A subdiscipline of geophysics that studies the thermal state of the interior of the solid Earth and of the thermal properties of Earth materials. Components of geothermal research are temperature distribution within the Earth, terrestrial heat flow, heat generation, thermal properties of Earth materials, volcanology, geothermal energy, hydrocarbon formation, fluid flow, and permafrost. Cf. temperature studies.
The study of heatflow and radioactive activity within the Earth.
Tourism that sustains or enhances the distinctive geographical character of a place  its environment, heritage, aesthetics, culture, and the well-being of its residents.

The scientific discipline concerned with all aspects of ice and solid water on landmasses. It deals with the structure and properties of glaciers and ice sheets, their physical properties, formation and distribution, the dynamics of ice flow, and the interactions of ice accumulation with climate.

Grade control is the process aiming to maximize the value of ore mined and fed into the mill. This is commonly achieved by systematic, closely-spaced drilling to check the quality and grade of the ore while mining is underway. Drillhole data, other sampling data and geological mapping can all be used to delineate ore for mining purposes, thus controlling the grade of feedstock to the mill.
The measure of changes in gravity due to variations in the density of the rocks to remotely map the distribution of different rock types and the structure of rocks in the Earth's subsurface.
The study of variations (anomalies) in the Earth's gravity field via measurements of the spatial gradient of gravitational acceleration.

Spectral imaging obtained in the field or at a mine site, especially using portable devices (e.g. pXRF); applications include characterization of outcrops and materials, mine wall face mapping, and ore grade classification.

Heritage conservation seeks to sustain the values of heritage (including both natural and cultural heritage) landscapes, places and objects, individually and collectively, so that the community and visitors can continue to appreciate, experience and learn from them and about them, and so that they can be passed on to future generations. More specifically, this field refers to the more practical or applied aspects of site or object restoration, preventative activities, and/or remedial treatments.

The study of collections, their heritage values and the ways of presenting their significance (interpretation) as a 'means of communicating ideas and feelings which help people enrich their understanding and appreciation of their world and their role within it' (Australian Heritage Commission).

concepts.prefLabel: heritage tourism, visitor and audience studies
concepts.definition: Heritage tourism is a form of non-business travel whereby tourists engage with the heritage, tangible and intangible, moveable and immovable, abstract or concrete, natural or cultural, of a region through activities, experiences, and purchases which facilitate a connection to the people, objects, and places of the past (including geological sites) associated with the locations being visited. Studies associated with this field refer to the management of such sites, the evaluation of the impact of visitors and the assessment of tourist satisfaction and emotional experiences during the visit.

Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice.

concepts.prefLabel: heritage, archive and museum studies not elsewhere classified
concepts.definition: Heritage, archive and museum studies not otherwise described by other sub-categories of heritage, archive and museum studies.

concepts.prefLabel: heritage, archive and museum studies not elsewhere classified
concepts.definition: Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice

The branch of geology concerned with the reconstruction and comprehension of the geological history of the Earth, i.e. the evolution of the Earth and its life forms from its origins to the present day. This discipline examines the vastness of geological time, measured in billions of years, and investigates changes in the Earth (gradual and sudden) over this deep time. It focuses on geological processes, such as plate tectonics, that have changed the Earth's surface and subsurface over time and the use of methods including stratigraphy, structural geology, paleontology, and sedimentology to tell the sequence of these events. It also focuses on the evolution of life during different time periods in the geologic time scale. Not to be confused with history of geology.

That branch of the history of science that documents the development of geological knowledge, including the history of observations of geological features, the history of theories to explain their origin, and the history of the organization and development of geological institutions and societies. The biographical study of geologists is included. Not to be confused with historical geology.

Collectively, the study of practices, items and places designated as significant, including the investigation and interpretation of past human events (history), the identification, conservation and presentation of significant places, processes and items (heritage), and the study of human cultures through recovered artefacts or relics (archeology). Although history and archeology imply the interpretation of human culture, heritage and museum studies can be applied to concepts of both natural (abiotic or biotic) or cultural significance.

The study of a group of individuals involved in persistent social interaction or of a large social group sharing the same spatial or social territory, typically subject to the same political authority and dominant cultural expectations.

The chemistry of ground and surface waters, particularly the relationships between the chemical characteristics and quality of waters and the areal and regional geology. On a broader scale, the science that uses the tools and principles of chemistry to explain the mechanisms behind major geological systems such as the Earth's crust and its oceans.

The area of geology that deals with the distribution and movement of subsurface water (i.e. groundwater) in the soil and rocks of the Earth's crust, and with related geological aspects of surface waters.

The study of the fossilized tracks, trails, burrows and excavations made by animals and more broadly the study of bioturbation, which is the reworking of sediment by animals. Ichnofossils or trace fossils are used to interpret paleoecological aspects of sedimentary environments.

The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of igneous rocks, i.e. those that are formed from magma. It relies heavily on the use of chemistry, chemical methods, and phase diagrams.

Information and computing (or computer) science (ICS) or computer and information science (CIS) (or sciences) is a field that emphasizes both computing and informatics, upholding the strong association between the fields of information sciences and computer sciences and treating computers as a tool rather than a field. Information science is primarily concerned with gathering, storing, disseminating, sharing and protecting any and all forms of information  it is a broad field, covering a myriad of different areas but is often referenced alongside computer science because of the incredibly useful nature of computers and computer programs in helping those studying and doing research in the field, particularly in helping to analyse data and in spotting patterns too broad for a human to intuitively perceive.

Information management (IM) is the appropriate and optimized capture, storage, retrieval, and use of information. It may be personal information management or organizational. Information management for organizations concerns a cycle of organizational activity: the acquisition of information from one or more sources, the custodianship and the distribution of that information to those who need it, and its ultimate disposal through archiving or deletion and extraction.

An information system (IS) is a formal, integrated set of components for the collection, storage and processing of data, aimed at providing information, contributing to knowledge and delivering digital products that facilitate decision-making.
The broader field for the study of the chemistry of inorganic rocks, minerals, and other Earth materials that are not currently or once living.

The part of cultural heritage that deals with items that have no physical existence, such as past and current traditions or living expressions inherited from our ancestors and passed on to our descendants (e.g. oral traditions, performing arts, social practices, rituals, festive events), knowledge and practices concerning nature and the universe, or the knowledge and skills to produce traditional crafts.

The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of organisms of the 'invertebrate' phyla, i.e. of those animals that lack notochords (non-vertebrates).

The application of natural variations in the relative abundances of isotopes of various elements, measured by isotope-ratio mass spectrometry, to reveal information about the ages of rock, air or water bodies, or processes of mixing between them.
The determination of the relative and absolute concentrations of the elements and their isotopes in the Earth and on Earth's surface.
Spectral imaging and mapping obtained under controlled laboratory conditions, e.g. for the qualitative and quantitative mineral identification and phase relationships.

Land-use and environmental planning involves the regulation and commitment of land-use, as to how the landscape is used (whether for food production, forestry, nature conservation, water storage, urban development, mining, etc.), to ensure the most efficient, effective and beneficial management and utilization of resources, and to provide optimal environmental and social outcomes.
The study of the complete chemical composition of whole rocks, considering the main and trace elements, but also isotopes.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the description and systematic organization of the rocks of the Earth's crust into distinctive named units based on the lithological character of the rocks and their stratigraphic relations. In the petroleum industry, lithostratigraphy specifically refers to the study and correlation of strata to elucidate Earth's history on the basis of their lithology or the nature of the well log response, mineral content, grain size, texture, and colour of rocks.
A comprehensive study of the geological and geographical features of a subdivision of or area within a region (in this context defined as an area of land that has common natural features).

The acquisition of a continuous record as a function of depth, usually graphic and plotted to scale, of observations, analyses or measurements made on the geological materials of the section exposed in a borehole or of the sample (drillcore or cuttings) obtained from it.

Machine learning (ML) is the field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalize to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

The study of the Earth's magnetic field via non-invasive geophysical methods which measure perturbations in the Earths magnetic field caused by magnetic minerals in crustal rocks, specifically to image anomalies caused by source bodies within the subsurface.

The study of physical phenomena associated with moving electricity in conductive rocks or the permanent magnetic effects of naturally magnetic rocks, and the study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

The element of stratigraphy that deals with the magnetic characteristics of rock units. Specifically the geophysical correlation technique used to date sedimentary rocks lacking fossils and volcanic sequences by collecting oriented samples at measured intervals throughout a section and measuring the characteristic remanent magnetization.

Magnetotellurics (MT) is a passive geophysical method used to infer the Earth's subsurface electrical resistivity/conductivity from measurements of natural variations of geomagnetic and geoelectric field at the Earth's surface, i.e. the use of natural electromagnetic signals to image subsurface electrical conductivity structure through electromagnetic induction.
The study of the history and structure of the ocean floor. It involves geophysical, geochemical, sedimentological and paleontological investigations of the ocean floor and coastal zone.

Maritime archeology (also known as marine archeology) is a discipline of archeology that specifically studies human interaction with the sea, lakes and rivers through the study of associated physical remains, be they vessels, shore-side facilities, port-related structures, cargoes, human remains and submerged landscapes.
The technical aspects related to the protection and care of materials to avoid their physical deterioration while actively ensuring their preservation for posterity.

An interdisciplinary scientific field studying the influence of natural geological factors on human and animal health. Broadly, medical geology studies exposure to or deficiency of trace elements and minerals (the distribution of trace elements as related to nutrition, or the geographic patterns of disease); inhalation of ambient and anthropogenic mineral dusts and volcanic emissions; transportation, modification and concentration of organic compounds; the occurrence of toxic elements in unusual quantities in parts of the Earth's crust; and exposure to radionuclides, microbes and pathogens.

The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of metamorphic rocks, i.e. those derived from the transformation of existing rocks into new types. It relies heavily on the use of chemistry, chemical methods, and phase diagrams.

The systematic study of fossil microbialites and other evidence of/for microbes and microbially influenced features in the geological record, focussing on their morphology, classification, and environmental and biostratigraphic significance. Microbial paleobiology commonly intersects with disciplines such as geobiology, astrobiology and biostratigraphy, and is commonly employed in studies concerned with the origins of life on Earth.

The systematic study of microfossils (i.e. fossils too small to be observed without the aid of a microscope), their morphology, classification, and environmental and biostratigraphic significance. Microfossils can represent the remains, or partial remains, of a wide range of organism kingdoms and phyla, but palynomorphs are generally excluded.

The application of geological theory to warfare and the peacetime practices of the military. Military geologists are used for terrain analysis (geomorphology, soil science), engineering (building of roads and airfields), and the identification of resources (e.g. water supply or construction materials), and to research the effects of military practices on Earth's and planets' geology. The peacetime application of military geology includes the building of infrastructure, typically during local emergencies or foreign peacekeeping deployments.

The study of the chemical composition of minerals, i.e. of naturally occurring inorganic element or compound with a defined chemical composition and crystal structure, i.e. having a periodically repeating arrangement of atoms and characteristic chemical composition, resulting in distinctive physical properties. It includes the analysis of the major, minor, trace and isotope elemental composition of a mineral, as well as the bonding of these elements in the minerals crystal structure.

Studies related to the search for deposits of useful minerals. It may include geological reconnaissance, geological mapping, remote sensing analysis, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and subsurface (e.g. drilling and underground) investigations. Also studies to establish the nature of a known mineral deposit, in preparatory to development and exploitation; in this sense exploration goes beyond discovery, and is a broader term than prospecting.

The study of concentrations of inorganic, naturally occurring, typically solid, typically non-renewable materials that are of intrinsic economic interest in or on the Earth's crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction. It includes the study of mineral systems, i.e. the combination of geological processes that are required to form and preserve an ore deposit. Also included is the characterization of orebodies (e.g. quantification of physical properties and chemical properties, and delineation of volumes, grades and geometry), and of limitations to the development and exploitation of mineral occurrences.

Understanding the combination of geologic processes that are required to form and preserve ore deposits at all scales. It recognises seven critical geological processes: source of mineralizing fluid, source of metals, fluid pathway, thermal gradient, energy source, structural focusing of fluids, and chemical or physical trap for metal precipitation.
The scientific study of minerals, their formation, occurrence, physical and chemical properties, composition, and classification.
The scientific study of the chemistry, crystal structure, and physical properties of minerals and mineralized artifacts.

Studies related to the process of extracting metallic or non-metallic mineral deposits from the Earth. The term may also include the preliminary treatment of extracted materials, e.g. cleaning or sizing.

The application of molecular analytical techniques to fossil or subfossil material in order to test for the presence of original biomolecules. These molecules may be proteins, DNA, carbohydrates or lipids, or their diagenetic products.

A branch of paleontology that deals with the form and structure of organisms based on their fossil remains; especially a study of the forms, relations, and phylogenetic development of biological structures apart from their functions.

The study of natural phenomena that might have a negative effect on humans or the environment, specifically hazards encompassing geological and meteorological phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires, cyclonic storms, floods, droughts, avalanches and landslides, as well as phenomena such as natural radioactivity.
The study of the post-Miocene structures and structural history of the Earth's crust.
The branch of isotope geochemistry focusing on non-radiogenic (or stable) isotope systems, i.e. those where a nuclide is not known to undergo radioactive decay.

The branch of geochronology / isotope geochemistry focusing on non-radiogenic (or stable) isotope systems, i.e. those where a nuclide is not known to undergo radioactive decay, to determine the numerical age of suitable geological materials.
The study of the ocean, including its physical, chemical, biologic, and geological aspects.
The study of economically valuable minerals (ores) in the Earth's crust, including their formation, distribution, and extraction methods.
The microscopic study of metallic ores using reflected light.

The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of ore minerals, i.e. of naturally occurring minerals that contain valuable elements or minerals in sufficient quantities to be economically mined and processed for their desired metal or mineral content.

The study of the role of processes and compounds that are derived from living or once-living organisms, i.e. the study of the transformation undergone by organic matter of all types, whether of biological or man-made origin, in the Earth System. The transformations involved vary from those mediated by biological processes involved in the production of living tissue and the operation of food-chains, to those controlled by temperature and pressure at depth in the crust. Photochemical processes in the atmosphere and hydrosphere can also be important in controlling the environmental behaviour of some organic compounds.
Organic petrology involves the study of organic matter (OM) in rocks, including its origin and thermal maturity due to burial within the Earth's crust.

That branch of paleontology that treats the geographic distribution of organisms in past geological time, especially with regard to the ecologic, climatologic, and evolutionary factors involved. It includes the more specialized paleophytogeography and paleozoogeography subdisciplines.

The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of plants, fungi and algae from geological contexts, and their use for the biological reconstruction of past environments (paleogeography), as well as the evolutionary history of plants and allied kingdoms, with a bearing upon the evolution of life in general. These fossils can be impressions or compressions of the plants left on the rock's surface, or 'petrified' objects, such as wood, which preserve the original plant material in rocklike form.

The study of climates prior to the period of instrumental records, and of the causes of their variation, on either a local, regional or worldwide basis. It uses a variety of proxy methods from the Earth and life sciences to obtain data preserved within rocks, sediments, ice sheets, tree rings, corals, shells, and microfossils to determine the past states of the Earth's various climate regions and its atmospheric system.

A subdiscipline of paleontology concerned with reconstructing past biota, populations, communities, landscapes, environments, and ecosystems from available geological and biological (fossil) evidence. It encompasses the study of interactions between organisms and/or interactions between organisms and their environments across geological timescales, including reconstructions of past ecosystems and environments using this information.
The reconstruction of past environments and their climates within regions or across regions, based on the sediments, soils, strata, and associated biological remains.

The dating of geological materials by comparing the magnetic signature in rocks to known changes in the Earth's magnetic field (based on movements of the magnetic north pole over geological time). It is based on matching the changes in the paleomagnetic field recorded in lava flows or sediments with their corresponding dates in the magnetic polarity time scale. When applied to archeology, it is referred to as archeomagnetics.

The study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials (rocks, sediments and archeological materials) in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

The scientific study of life in the geological past through the analysis of fossils, including those of microscopic size, and of traces representing preserved behaviour, preserved in rocks. It is concerned with all aspects of the biology of ancient life forms: their shape and structure, evolutionary patterns, taxonomic relationships with each other and with modern living species, geographic distribution, and interrelationships with the environment.

Originally, the study of pollen and spores, extant and fossil (paleopalynology), including stratigraphic and paleoecological applications. Now includes the study of a wide range of other robust-walled, acid-insoluble microscopic remains of various plants, animals, fungal spores and protists, including kerogen and unidentifiable organic matter.
The detection of natural low frequency earth movements, commonly with the purpose of discerning geological structures and locating underground oil, gas, or other resources.

One of the disciplines of soil science, pedology is the study of soil morphology, genesis, and classification. Pedometrics specifically refers to the use of quantitative methods for the study of soil distribution and genesis.

That branch of geology dealing with the description and systematic classification of rocks and especially by means of microscopic examination of thin sections. Petrography is more restricted in scope than petrology and overlaps considerably with mineralogy.

The fields of engineering concerned with activities related to the production of hydrocarbons to determine the way in which a reservoir is developed and depleted, i.e. the study and application of scientific and engineering principles to the fluid flow through a porous medium during the development and production of oil and gas reservoirs so as to obtain a high economic recovery.

The characterization of the physical properties and elemental analysis of oil and gas, used to interpret the type of source rock and correlate to a source rock, determine the thermal maturity of the oil and gas (and hence the maturity of the source rock), potential dating of the source rock, and compare oil and gas composition between different fields or within a field.

Study of the mode of origin and conditions of accumulation of hydrocarbons in the Earth's crust; their exploration, involving application of the techniques of geophysics, geochemistry, paleontology, stratigraphy, and tectonics; and their evaluation. It includes the assessment of petroleum systems and their composite parts: source, migration pathways, reservoir, seal, and method of entrapment.
That branch of geology dealing with the origin, occurrence, structure, and history of rocks, including the conditions under which they form. Petrology is broader in scope than petrography.

The study of the physical and chemical properties of rocks in relation to their interaction with fluids. A major application of petrophysics is in studying reservoirs for the hydrocarbon industry (especially the distribution of the pore system and its contained hydrocarbons and water).

The study of the physical and mechanical properties of rocks. Petrophysics focuses on how the microstructure of porous geological materials affects their mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid flow, and sonic properties. Rock mechanics considers the mechanical or geomechanical properties of rocks, including reservoir strength, elastic properties, hardness, ultrasonic behaviour, index characteristics, and in situ stresses.

The science and technology of collecting/measuring, processing, analysing and interpreting information from noncontact imaging and other sensor systems that record the interaction between electromagnetic energy and matter, i.e. the acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon by using a recording device that is not in physical contact with the subject being studied. Aerial photographs and imagery acquired from a satellite or drone are examples of remotely sensed information.

An approach to systematics (the study of the kinds and diversity of organisms and the relationships between them) that attempts to recover the phylogenetic (genealogical) relationships among groups of organisms, and produces classifications that reflect exactly those genealogical relationships.

The branch of natural science which deals with the classification, form, processes, extent and patterns of natural phenomena in the natural environment such as the atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and geosphere. It differs chiefly from geology in that it considers conditions of the Earth primarily over shorter time scales (e.g. Quaternary and/or modern rates). It is more inclusive than geomorphology, dealing not only with landforms but also climate, oceans, atmosphere, soils, geologic processes, natural resources, and the biogeographical distribution of animal and plant life.

concepts.prefLabel: physical geography and environmental geoscience not elsewhere classified
concepts.definition: Physical geographical and environmental science data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of physical geography.

The systematic study of the inorganic world, as distinct from the study of the organic world, which is the province of biological science. Physical science is ordinarily thought of as consisting of four broad areas: astronomy, physics, chemistry, and the Earth sciences. Each of these is in turn divided into fields and subfields.

Public administration is the planning, preparation, and execution of policy meant to build and strengthen civil society. Policy, in this context, refers to prudence or wisdom in the management of affairs, or management procedures based primarily on material interest.

The field search for valuable commodities, mineral specimens (e.g. gold nuggets, crystals), lapidary material, and mineral deposits  usually with the ultimate objective of economic development by mining operations. Prospectors may be divided into two general categories: those with academic, scientific training and those with only field training or in the purely amateur category.

A predictive tool typically used for mineral exploration targeting at the broad regional- to camp-scale. It is less effective and less frequently used at the project- to deposit-scale where predictive tools compete with direct detection techniques. It includes the delineation of prospective areas based on personal experience and interpretation of available geological, geochemical and geophysical data, as well as statistical data analysis/modelling, and in combination GIS-based spatial datasets and/or soft computational models (e.g. fuzzy logic).

A discipline focused on the quantitative measurements of the mineralogy, chemistry, morphology and microstructures of minerals and mineral assemblages using a range of analytical techniques (e.g. modal analysis, X-ray diffractometry, infrared and Raman spectroscopy, refractometry, spectral mapping, etc.). Specifically, quantitative mineral methodologies are utilized to measure and/or constrain mineral abundances, as well as to provide mineral grade and texture information for geological and mineral processing applications.

The study of industrial mineral resources, i.e. geological materials that are mined/quarried for their commercial value and are not fuel (fuel minerals or mineral fuels) or sources of metals (metallic minerals) but are used in their natural state or after beneficiation either as raw materials or as additives in a wide range of applications based on their physical and/or chemical properties. These studies include the quantification of the physical properties, chemical properties, volumes, and limitations to development of quarry products. Quarry resources (also referred to as basic raw materials or industrial minerals) include, but may not be limited to, sand (including silica sand), clay, hard rock (including dimension stone), limestone (including metallurgical limestone), agricultural lime, gravel, gypsum, other construction and road building materials and materials which may substitute these raw materials.

The branch of geology that study environmental changes from 2.58 million years ago to the present. In particular, Quaternary geology study the process and deposits that developed during the Quaternary, a period characterized by glacialinterglacial cycles.

The branch of geochronology / isotope geochemistry focusing on radiogenic isotope systems, i.e. those where a daughter isotope is produced from the decay of a radioactive parent isotope, to determine the numerical age of suitable geological materials.

The dating of geological materials by using the effects of radioactivity other than the natural decay from a parent to a daughter isotope. It includes methods such as fission tracks (measure of the density of track marking left in a material by the spontaneous fission of uranium-238 impurities), luminescence (measure of the effect of background radiation on certain minerals), and electron spin resonance (ESR), measure of the amount of unpaired electrons in crystalline structures that were previously exposed to natural radiation). The term radiogenic here is used as in Colman et al. (1987).
The branch of isotope geochemistry focusing on radiogenic isotope systems, i.e. those where a daughter isotope is produced from the decay of a radioactive parent isotope.
The radiometric, or gamma-ray spectrometric method is a geophysical process used to estimate concentrations of the radioelements potassium, uranium and thorium in the near surface.
The geological study of large-scale regions, providing a link between global and local geology, and a framework for site-specific studies.

The mineralogical study of specific geographic regions, from ore deposits clusters to large metallogenic provinces. It includes evaluation of location and the spatial distribution of minerals and mineral assemblages in relation to the geological history of the province (region) or the formation of the deposit. Regional mineralogy can include mineral regional fingerprinting, and directly links to metallogeny and genetic mineralogy.

The study of the geology of surficial deposits, i.e. those at or near the Earth's surface. It includes the study of soils and unconsolidated sediments, their geological features and structures, and their relationships to the underlying bedrock.

The study of the chemical composition of materials and components making up the surficial, weathered, and usually unconsolidated layer that nearly everywhere forms the surface of the land and overlies or covers the bedrock. Regolith includes rock debris of all kinds, volcanic ash, glacial drift, alluvium, loess and eolian deposits, vegetal accumulations, and soil.

The stage in the life-cycle of a project or mine where the resources have been extracted and the site or part thereof is being rehabilitated back to its original condition or an acceptable environmental standard.

Geoscience studies related to the definition and exploitation of energy derived from natural resources such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat, that are replenished either through natural reproduction or other recurring processes in a finite amount of time on a human time scale.

A characterization of a reservoir that incorporates all the characteristics of the reservoir that are pertinent to its ability to store hydrocarbons and also to produce them. Reservoir characterization models are used to simulate the behaviour of the fluids within the reservoir under different sets of circumstances and to find the optimal production techniques that will maximize the production. Typically, a reservoir analysis incorporates interpretation of depositional facies and diagenesis, mineralogical and textural maturity parameters obtained from macro/meso (e.g. cores, sidewall cores, cuttings) and micro (e.g. thin sections, scanning electron microscope work) samples, as well as direct and indirect measurements of porosity, permeability and grain density from well log analysis and core and mechanical sidewall cores. Image logs are used to determine fracture density where applicable. Regional reservoir distribution and thickness is derived from multiple well reservoir data, seismic interpretation and depth mapping.
The study of fuels, metals and other materials of economic interest; it is concerned with the distribution, value and availability of resources, and the cost and benefits of their recovery.
Engineering that applies various branches of science in order to create new technology that aims to protect, maintain, extract, and establish sustainable natural resources.

A theoretical and applied science of the physical behaviour of rocks and rock masses. In relation to geology, it is the branch of mechanics concerned with the response of rock and rock masses to the force fields of their physical environment.
Remotely sensed spectral imaging obtained from a platform in orbit outside the atmosphere of Earth.

The use of satellites to determine the location (geographic position) of a receiver on Earth. The technique involves measuring the range between the receiver and the satellite, and the range measurement used to calculate the receiver's position using observation equations and least squares. The technique is used in global and regional satellite navigation systems.

A characterization of regional caprocks and intraformational barriers (seals) to understand their capacity to trap fluids (oil, gas, etc.); specifically to determine seal capacity (i.e. the capillary pressure, or column height, at which a trapped fluid commences to leak through a seal rock) and conduct fault seal analysis (a measure of the capacity of a fault to leak or seal hydrocarbons).
The study of the composition, characteristics, occurrence, and origin of sediments and sedimentary rocks.
The scientific study of sedimentary rocks and of the processes by which they were formed; the description, classification, origin, and interpretation of sediments.

The study of stratigraphy and depositional facies as interpreted from seismic data; an integrated stratigraphic and sedimentologic technique to interpret seismic reflection data for stratigraphic correlation and to predict depositional environments and lithology.
The science of the acquisition, processing, and analysis of seismic datasets measured and recorded with reference to a particular area of the Earth's surface, to evaluate the subsurface.

Seismic tomography is a technique for imaging the subsurface of the Earth with seismic waves produced by controlled active sources such as vibrations or explosions, or natural passive sources such as earthquakes, wind, waves or human activity. P-, S-, and surface waves can be used for tomographic models of different resolutions based on seismic wavelength, wave source distance, and the seismograph array coverage. The data received at seismometers are used to solve an inverse problem, wherein the locations of reflection and refraction of the wave paths are determined. This solution can be used to create 3D images of velocity anomalies which may be interpreted as structural, thermal, or compositional variations.

The scientific study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves both natural and artificially generated through the Earth or through other planetary bodies. The field also includes studies of earthquake environmental effects such as tsunamis as well as diverse seismic sources such as volcanic, tectonic, oceanic, atmospheric, and artificial processes such as explosions. Seismic exploration is a method of exploration geophysics that uses the principles of seismology to estimate the properties of the Earth's subsurface from artificially generated seismic waves.

The study of rock relationships within a chronostratigraphic framework of repetitive, genetically related strata bounded by surfaces of erosion or nondeposition, or their correlative conformities (Van Wagoner et al., 1990). Specifically, a field of study in which basin-filling sedimentary deposits, called sequences, are interpreted in a framework of eustasy, sedimentation and subsidence through time in order to correlate strata and predict the stratigraphy of relatively unknown areas.

The study of the chemical composition of the unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the surface of the earth that serves as a natural medium for the growth of land plants, and whose formation is conditioned by relief and controlled by genetic and environmental factors such as climate (including water and temperature effects) and biological activity (macro- and micro-organisms) acting on parent material over a period of time.

The science dealing with soils as a natural resource on the surface of the Earth including (a) soil formation, soil classification and mapping; (b) physical, chemical, biological, and fertility properties of soils per se; and (c) these properties in relation to the use and management of soils.
The evaluation of the lithological sources of hydrocarbons, i.e. those rocks which contain organic matter and are (or have been) generating and/or expelling hydrocarbons to form accumulations.

The use of multiple bands across the electromagnetic spectrum to create a dataset that contains many images of the same object, where each one of them is measured at a different wavelength. It includes multispectral imaging that typically captures three to fifteen spectral bands, and hyperspectral imaging that combines spectroscopy and digital photography to capture hundreds of wavelength bands.

The exploration and scientific study of caves and other karst features, both physical and biological, including their composition and mineralogy, structure (morphology), physical properties, history, ecology, and the processes by which they form (speleogenesis) and change over time (speleomorphology).
The systematic identification, analysis, planning, and implementation of actions designed to influence stakeholders. This process identifies the needs of key groups and ensures those needs are met.

The study of the history, composition, relative ages and distribution of strata, and the interpretation of strata to elucidate Earth's history. The comparison, or correlation, of separated strata can include study of their form, distribution, lithology, fossil content, geophysical and geochemical properties, relative or numerical/absolute age, and their interpretation in terms of environment or mode of origin, and geological history.

The branch of geology that deals with the form (geometry), spatial arrangement, and internal structure of the rocks, and especially with the description, representation, and analysis of structures (e.g. bedding, folds, faults and fractures), chiefly on a meso- to macroscopic scale. The subject is similar to tectonics, but the latter is generally used for the broader regional or historical phases.

The branches of geology that, combined, focus on the manifestation of plate tectonic motions in the deformation of Earth's crust and lithosphere, from the scale of mountain ranges to individual faults and folds, and on timescales from deep Earth history to present-day tectonism and associated natural hazards.

The study of the form, physical properties, composition, function, and evolution of Earths surface, a dynamic interface where physical, chemical, biological, and human processes cause and are affected by forces in the Earth system, with impact-feedback loops that occur over a wide range of temporal and spatial scales.

The subfield of hydrology concerned with above-earth water, in contrast to groundwater hydrology that deals with water below the surface of the Earth. Its applications include rainfall and runoff, the routes that surface water takes (for example through rivers or reservoirs), and the occurrence of floods and droughts.

The applied science of determining the two-dimensional or three-dimensional positions of points necessary to determine the area of any part of the Earth's (or other planetary body) surface, the lengths and directions of the boundary lines, and the contour of the surface, and of accurately delineating the whole on paper/digitally.
The branch of paleontology concerned with all processes occurring after the death of an organism until its discovery. It includes biostratonomy and fossil diagenesis.

The theory and practice of identifying, describing, naming, and classifying organisms. The terms taxonomy and systematics are usually distinguished, the latter having broader connotation, but they may also be used more or less synonymously.

The branch of geology dealing with the broad architecture of the outer part of the Earth, i.e. the regional assembling of structural or deformational features, a study of their mutual relations, origin and historical evolution. It is closely related to structural geology, with which the distinctions are blurred, but tectonics generally deals with larger features.

The collection, preparation, petrographic description, and approximate dating of tephra. The technique uses discrete layers of tephra (volcanic ash from a single eruption) to create a chronological framework in which paleoenvironmental or archeological records can be placed. The premise of the technique is that each volcanic event produces ash with a unique chemical 'fingerprint' that allows the deposit to be identified across the area affected by fallout. Thus, once the volcanic event has been independently dated, the tephra horizon will act as time marker (as such it is a variant of the basic geological technique of stratigraphy).

The study of the thermal evolution of a region of a planet. Thermochronologists use radiometric dating (the determination of the age of a sample based on the rate of decay of a radioactive nuclide) along with closure temperatures (i.e. the temperature of the mineral being studied at the time given by the date recorded) to understand the thermal history of a specific rock, mineral, or geological unit.

The non-destructive, three-dimensional characterization of earth and planetary materials that uses material-penetrating energy sources. Tomography methods in Earth Science include experiments in controlled laboratory settings such as computed tomography of rock samples or soils, and field experiments such as seismic tomography of the Solid Earth.

The geological study of unconventional petroleum systems, which comprise formations with tight gas, tight oil, oil sands, oil shale, bitumen, gas shales, coal seam gas/coalbed methane, and gas hydrates, and are defined as those where petroleum is distributed throughout the reservoir at basin-wide scale and in which buoyant forces or the influence of a water column on the location of hydrocarbons in the reservoir are not significant.

Urban planning, also known as town planning, city planning, regional planning, or rural planning in specific contexts, is a technical and political process that is focused on the development and design of land use and the built environment, including air, water, and the infrastructure passing into and out of urban areas, such as transportation, communications, and distribution networks, and their accessibility. Traditionally, urban planning followed a top-down approach in master planning the physical layout of human settlements, with a primary focus on public welfare (i.e. considerations of efficiency, sanitation, protection and use of the environment) as well as effects of the master plans on the social and economic activities. Over time, urban planning's focus has shifted to social and environmental factors to be a tool to improve the health and well-being of people while maintaining sustainability standards.

The application of geological knowledge and principles to the planning and management of cities and their surroundings. It includes geological studies for physical planning, waste disposal, land use, water-resources management, and extraction of usable raw materials.

A dating method that utilizes the seasonal (summer and winter) sedimentological variations of deposits in lakes that undergo an annual freeze-up, by counting and measuring thicknesses in annual paired layers of sediments. Because each years sediment accumulation varies in thickness according to the climatic conditions of the melt season, any long sequence of varve measurements provides a distinctive 'signature' and can be correlated for moderate distances from lake basin to lake basin. Counting and correlation of varves have been used to measure the ages of Pleistocene glacial deposits.

The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of Phylum Chordata. This includes modern vertebrates, non-vertebrate chordates (such as lancets and turnicates), and extinct groups of uncertain placement (such as conodonts).
The branch of geology that deals with volcanism (e.g. volcanoes, lava, magma), its causes and related geological, geophysical and geochemical phenomena.

Stratigraphic and lithodemic units that are formally defined and named in the Australian Stratigraphic Units Database (https://www.ga.gov.au/data-pubs/datastandards/reference-databases/stratigraphic-units) following conventions set out in the International Stratigraphic Guide (Salvador, 1994; an abridged version of the guide is available at https://stratigraphy.org/guide/index.html).

A temporally and conceivably spatially defined episode in Earth's history that leads/contributes to the modification of any of the Earth's systems (geosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, atmosphere and biosphere).

Concentrations of naturally occurring solid, gas, and liquid geological materials within the earths crust (both on and below the surface) that occur in sufficient masses or volumes to have existing or potential economic and societal value. These resources include, but are not limited to, rock, metal and non-metal mineral resources, oil, natural gas, and geothermal energy resources; and environmental resources (water and soil).

Any physical, recognizable form and feature of the Earth's surface having a characteristic shape and produced by natural causes. It includes major forms such as plain, plateau and mountain, and minor forms such as hill, valley, slope, esker and dune. Taken together, the landforms make up the surface configuration of the Earth.

A named body of rock (sedimentary, igneous, metamorphic or mixed), that is defined and characterized on the basis of its observable and distinctive lithological properties or combination of lithological properties and stratigraphic/field relations. It represents the basic unit of geological mapping and includes formally defined stratigraphic and lithodemic units (cf Australian Stratigraphic Units Database, www.ga.gov.au/data-pubs/datastandards/stratigraphic-units) as well as lithotectonic units defined solely on the basis of lithologic properties and inclusion within a tectonic unit.
An assemblage of rocks that is unified on the basis  of structural or deformational features, mutual relations, origin or historical evolution. It may be igneous, sedimentary, metamorphic or mixed.

A geographic area or section of the Earth's crust characterized by a particular assemblage ofmineral deposits, or by one or more distinctive types/styles of mineralization. The concept underscores the genesis and regional-to-global distribution of mineral deposits, with emphasis on their relationship in space and time to regional petrological and tectonic features of the Earth's crust.

A unifying model comprising all of the geological and geodynamic factors, at all scales, that control the inception, evolution and preservation of an ore deposit. Critical components of a mineral system include a source of metals, a mode of transport, a site of deposition or accumulation where commodities become concentrated and are preserved to enable economically viable extraction during a given period. A mineral system model permits classification of known deposit types or styles into a genetically related family based on their association with the above factors.

The petroleum supersystem concept, introduced by Bradshaw (1993), is a methodology to understand hydrocarbon occurrences throughout Australia at a continental-scale. The petroleum supersystem links sedimentary packages of similar age, structural history, depositional environment and hydrocarbon potential, both within and between basins. Thus, the petroleum supersystems approach can potentially be a powerful exploration tool for predicting the petroleum systems elements in frontier basins with limited datasets (Bradshaw et al 1994).

A named geomorphological entity with internal coherence in its landform characteristics and landform evolutionary history. At the lowest levels, physiographic units reflect the underlying geology and have similar groupings of regolith materials that are related to the landform types, their evolution, and the underlying bedrock.

A body of unconsolidated to secondarily recemented materials that overlies more coherent bedrock, and that has been formed and shaped by weathering, erosion, transport and/or deposition of older material. It includes the weathered component of the underlying bedrock.

A feature that describes the geometric relationship of rocks and geological features in general. Structural features are divided into two broad classes: those acquired during the genesis of a rock mass (primary structure, e.g. bedding) or by later deformation or displacement of primary structures and of the rocks (secondary structures, e.g. a fold or fault).
A regional- to continental-scale element of the solid Earth that is the result of lithosphere or crustal-scale deformation, including magmatic and gravity-driven near-surface processes.

A named body of rock with distinct geological or geophysical characteristics (e.g. structure, stratigraphy, magmatic activity, metamorphism, seismic velocity, electrical conductivity) that reflect a different interpreted tectonic setting and geological history from that of surrounding bodies of rock.
The negative decadic logarithm of the concentration of free protons (or hydronium ions) expressed in 1 mol/L.

The ngstrm is an internationally recognized unit of length equal to 0.1 nm or 1 x 10 m. Although accepted for use, it is not formally defined within the International System of Units (SI). The ngstrm is often used in the natural sciences to express the sizes of atoms, lengths of chemical bonds and the wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation, and in technology for the dimensions of parts of integrated circuits. It is also commonly used in structural biology.

The unit of radioactivity used for natural gamma ray logs. This unit is based on an artificially radioactive concrete block located at the University of Houston (Texas, US), that is defined to have a radioactivity of 200 American Petroleum Institute (API) units.

A minute of arc, arcminute, or minute arc (MOA), is a unit of angular measurement equal to one sixtieth (1/60) of one degree (circle/21600), or /10800 radians. In turn, a second of arc or arcsecond is one sixtieth (1/60) of one minute of arc. Since one degree is defined as one three hundred and sixtieth (1/360) of a rotation, one minute of arc is 1/21600 of a rotation. Prime (') is the symbol for the arcminute.

Arcsecond is a unit of angular measure, also called the second of arc, equal to 1/60 arcminute. One arcsecond is a very small angle: there are 1296000 in a circle. The International System of Units (SI) recommends double prime () as the symbol for the arcsecond. The symbol has become common in astronomy, where very small angles are stated in milliarcseconds (mas).
Anastronomical unit, abbreviated asAU, au, a.u, or ua is a unit of length equal to149,597,870,700m(92,955,807.273mi) or approximately the mean EarthSun distance.
A currency used in Australia, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Heard Island and McDonald Islands, Kiribati, Nauru, Norfolk Island and Tuvalu.
A measure of volume used in the mining industry to indicate an in situ volume of material, frequently used in mining contracts to indicate the amount of material to be moved

The bar is a non-International System of Units (SI) unit of pressure, defined by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) as exactly equal to 100000 Pa. It is about equal to the atmospheric pressure on Earth at sea level, and since 1982 the IUPAC has recommended that the standard for atmospheric pressure should be harmonized to 100000 Pa = 1 bar  750.0616827 Torr. Units derived from the bar are the megabar (Mbar), kilobar (kbar), decibar (dbar), centibar (cbar) and millibar (mbar or mb). They are not part of either the SI or CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system of units, but they are accepted for use with the SI.

A barrel is one of several units of volume, including dry barrels, fluid barrels (UK beer barrel, US beer barrel), oil barrel, etc. The volume of some barrel units is double others, with various volumes in the range of about 100200 litres (2244 gal{imp}; 2653 gal (US). The barrel is commonly used as a measure of liquid recovery.

The unit of volume for crude oil according to the Anglo-American system of units. One barrel is exactly 42 gal (US) and is easily converted to any other unit of volume. As the US gallon since 1893 is defined as 3.785411784 litres, a volume of one barrel is exactly 158.987294928 litres.
A measure of oil output, represented by the number of barrels (US petroleum) of crude oil (according to the Anglo-American system of units) produced in a single day.
A measure of energy defined as the energy equivalent to one barrel of oil (6.117863210 J).

concepts.prefLabel: barrel of oil equivalent per megalitre
concepts.definition: A measure of oil quality or energy density defined as the energy in one barrel of oil equivalent (6.117863210 J) per million litres.

The International System of Units (SI) derived unit of activity, usually meaning radioactivity. Radioactivity is caused when atoms disintegrate, ejecting energetic particles. One becquerel is the radiation caused by one disintegration per second; this is equivalent to about 27.0270 picocuries (pCi). The unit is named for a French physicist, Antoine-Henri Becquerel (18521908), the discoverer of radioactivity. Note: both the becquerel and the hertz are basically defined as one event per second, yet they measure different things. The hertz is used to measure the rates of events that happen periodically in a fixed and definite cycle. The becquerel is used to measure the rates of events that happen sporadically and unpredictably, not in a definite cycle.
A unit of specific radioactivity (massic activity) equal to the activity of one becquerel of a sample with a total mass of one gram.
A measure of volume equivalent to one billion cubic metres. Alternate label bcm not recommended to avoid confusion with bank cubic metres (BCM/bcm).
The number of years divided by one billion. Commonly used in disciplines that describe events over long periods, such as astronomy and geology.

The bit is the most basic unit of information in computingand digitalcommunications, representing the capacity of data storage systems or communication channels. The name is a portmanteau of binary digit. A byte corresponds to 8 bits. Terms for large quantities of bits can be formed using the standard range of SI prefixes for powers of 10, e.g., kilo = 10 = 1000 (as in kilobit or kbit), mega = 10 = 1000000 (as in megabit or Mbit) and giga = 10 = 1000000000 (as in gigabit or Gbit). These prefixes are more often used for multiples of bytes, as in kilobyte (1 kB = 8000 bit), megabyte (1 MB = 8000000 bit), and gigabyte (1 GB = 8000000000 bit).

British thermal unit (BTU or Btu) is a traditional unit of energy equal to about 1.0550558526 kJ. It is approximately the amount of energy needed to heat 1 pound (0.454 kg) of water from 39 F to 40 F. The unit is most often used in the power, steam generation, heating and air conditioning industries. In scientific contexts the BTU has largely been replaced by the International System of Units (SI) unit of energy, the joule, though it may be used as a measure of agricultural energy production (BTU/kg). It is still used unofficially in metric English-speaking countries (such as Canada), and remains the standard unit of classification for air conditioning units manufactured and sold in many non-English-speaking metric countries.

concepts.prefLabel: British thermal unit per imperial pound
concepts.definition: The amount of energy generated by a pound of substance is measured in British thermal units (IT) per pound of mass (Btu{IT}/lb). 1 Btu{IT}/lb is equivalent to 2.326 x 10 J/kg.
A measure of oil quality or energy density defined as the energy in one BTU (British Thermal Units, or 1055 J) per million litres.
A measure of concentration within cement. The amount of an additives' mass per unit mass of cement.
A measure of concentration within water. The amount of an additives' mass per unit mass of water.
The byte (B) is a unit of digital information in computing and telecommunications that most commonly consists of 8 bits.

The carat is a unit of mass equal to 200 mg (0.2 g) and is used for measuring gemstones and pearls. The current definition, sometimes known as the metric carat, was adopted in 1907 at the Fourth General Conference on Weights and Measures, and soon afterward in many countries around the world. The carat is divisible into one hundred points of 2 mg each. Other subdivisions, and slightly different mass values, have been used in the past in different locations. In terms of diamonds, a paragon is a flawless stone of at least 100 carats (20g). The ANSI X.12 EDI standard abbreviation for the carat is CD.
Carat per 100 tonnes is a derived unit of density, defined by mass in carats divided by mass in 100 t.
Carat per cubic metre is a derived unit of density, defined by mass in carats divided by volume in cubic metres. The symbolic abbreviation is ct/m (or ct.m).
Carat per stone is a derived unit of density, defined by mass in carats divided by mass in stones.
Carat per tonne is a derived unit of density, defined by mass in carats divided by mass in tonnes.

A centimetre is a unit of length in the metric system, equal to one hundredth of a metre, which is the International System of Units (SI) base unit of length. Centi is the SI prefix for a factor of 0.01. The centimetre is the base unit of length in the now deprecated CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system of units.
Centipoise is a CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system unit for dynamic viscosity, expressed as cP. 1 cP = 0.01 P.

A chain is a unit of length. It measures 66 ft, or 22 yd, or 100 links, or 4 rods. There are 10 chains in a furlong, and 80 chains in one statute mile. An acre is the area of 10 square chains (that is, an area of one chain by one furlong). The chain has been used for several centuries in Britain and in some other countries influenced by British practice, and was commonly used to define map scales prior to the introduction of the metric system.
The number of unique and discrete objects or entities in a set.
A measurement of ionizing radiation, expressed as a rate of counts per second (CPS), as registered by a radiation monitoring instrument.
The CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system unit of volume, equal to 10 m, 1 ml, or about 0.0610237 in.
A measure of concentration, typically a fluid held within a solid. The cubic centimetres or millilitres of a substance per gram of host material.
A measure of concentration, typically a fluid held within a solid. The cubic centimetres or millilitres of a substance per ton of host material.
A unit of volume equal to that of a cube having sides each 1 dm in length, equal to 10 m and 1 litre. Commonly used in fluid measure and for engine sizes.
A measure of concentration. The number of cubic feet of a fluid contained within 1 st of host material.
A measure of concentration. The number of cubic feet of a fluid contained within 1 t (metric) of host material.

The cubic foot is an imperial and US customary unit of volume, used in the US and the UK. It is defined as the volume of a cube with sides of 1 ft (0.3048 m) in length. To calculate cubic feet multiply length  width  height.
Power of the unit foot according to the AngloAmerican and the imperial system of units with the exponent 3 divided by the unit for time day.
Power of the unit foot according to the AngloAmerican and the imperial system of units with the exponent 3 divided by the unit hour.
The International System of Units (SI) unit of volume, equal to 1  10 cm, 1000 l, 35.3147 ft or 1.30795 yd. A cubic metre holds about 264.17 gal (US) or 219.99 gal{Imp}.
Power of the International System of Units (SI) base unit metre with the exponent 3 divided by the unit day.

Cubic metre per hour (m/h) is a unit in the category of volume flow rate. Cubic metre per hour has a dimension of LT where L is length, and T is time. It can be converted to the corresponding standard International System of Units (SI) unit m/s by multiplying its value by a factor of 0.00027777777.

A measure of concentration. The number of cubic metres of a fluid contained within one tonne of host material. Cubic metres per tonne (m/t) is a unit of measurement used to express the density or specific volume of a substance. It represents the volume of a substance in cubic metres (m) per metric tonne (1000 kilograms) of that substance. It is commonly used in various fields, including chemistry, engineering and materials science, to quantify how much space or volume a substance occupies in relation to its weight or mass.
A metric measure of volume or capacity equal to a cube 1 mm on each edge.

The curie (symbol Ci) is a non-International System of Units (SI) unit of radioactivity, named after Marie and Pierre Curie. It is defined as1Ci=3.710 decays per second. Its continued use is discouraged. One curie is roughly the activity of 1 gram of the radium isotope Ra, a substance studied by the Curies. The SI derived unit of radioactivity is the becquerel (Bq), which equates to one decay per second. Therefore:1Ci=3.7  10Bq and 1Bq=2.70310Ci.

A darcy (D) is a measure of permeability. A medium with a permeability of 1 D permits a flow of 1 cm/s of a fluid with viscosity 1 cP (1 mPas) under a pressure gradient of 1 atm/cm acting across an area of 1 cm.
Mean solar day.
A fraction whose denominator is a power of ten and whose numerator is expressed by figures placed to the right of a decimal point.
A decimetre is a tenth of a metre.

A degree (in full, a degree of arc, arc degree, or arcdegree), usually denoted by  (the degree symbol), is a measurement of plane angle, representing 1/360 of a full rotation; one degree is equivalent to 2/360 rad, 0.017453 rad. It is not an International System of Units (SI) unit, which for angles is the radian, but is an accepted non-SI unit.

Celsius, also known as centigrade, is a scale and unit of measurement for temperature. It can refer to a specific temperature on the Celsius scale as well as a unit to indicate a temperature interval, a difference between two temperatures or an uncertainty. This definition fixes the magnitude of both the degree Celsius and the kelvin as precisely 1 part in 273.16 (approximately 0.00366) of the difference between absolute zero and the triple point of water. Thus, it sets the magnitude of one degree Celsius and that of one kelvin as exactly the same. Additionally, it establishes the difference between the null points of the two scales' as precisely 273.15 C.
Degree Fahrenheit is an imperial unit for thermodynamic temperature expressed as F.
Degrees Celsius per gigapascal is a measure of geothermal gradient, expressed as temperature in degrees Celsius (C) divided by pressure in gigapascal (GPa).
Degrees Celsius per kilobar is a measure of geothermal gradient, expressed as temperature in degrees Celsius (C) divided by pressure in kilobars (kbar).

Degrees Celsius per kilometre is a measure of geothermal gradient, expressed as temperature in degrees Celsius (C) divided by depth in kilometres (km). Use of degree Celsius per kilobar (or per gigapascal) is preferred, as the conversion from pressure to kilometre (depth) requires the rock density to be known.
A measure of curvature. The deviation (in degrees) of a line over an arc length of 1 ft.
A measure of curvature. The deviation (in degrees) of a line over an arc length of 100 ft.
A measure of curvature. The deviation (in degrees) of a line over an arc length of 1 m.
A measure of curvature. The deviation (in degrees) of a line over an arc length of 30 m.

2 is the variation in angle between incident and reflected X-rays during X-Ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. XRD plots provide information on the angles and intensities of refracted beams that allow scientists to construct a 3D model of the crystalline structure of minerals (e.g. illite). The focus of an XRD plot is the main peak. The width of the peak at one half of its height is measured and this angle (recorded with units of  2), can be plotted on a chart with metamorphic zones and facies. More specifically,  is the angle between incident beam and the crystallographic reflecting plane, and is also equal to the angle between reflected beam and the crystallographic plane; 2 is the angle between transmitted beam and reflected beam.
Maximum fluidity measure of coal which is determined against temperature.

An electron volt is the measure of an amount of kinetic energy gained by a single electron accelerating from rest through an electric potential difference of one volt in vacuum. When used as a unit of energy, the numerical value of 1 eV in joules (symbol J) is equivalent to the numerical value of the charge of an electron in coulombs (symbol C). Under the 2019 redefinition of the International System of Units (SI) base units, this sets 1 eV equal to the exact value 1.60217663410 J.

The eotvos is a unit of acceleration divided by distance and is used as a measurement of gravity gradient, being 1 nm/s/m and equivalent to a gradient of 1 mGal over 10 km. The eotvos was used in conjunction with the older CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system of units and is defined as 10 galileos per centimetre. The symbol of the eotvos unit is E.

The exabyte is a multiple of the unit byte for digital information. In the International System of Units (SI), the prefix exa indicates multiplication by the sixth power of 1000 (10). Therefore, one exabyte is one quintillion bytes (short scale).
A fine ounce is a troy ounce of pure gold content in a gold bar, computed as fineness multiplied by gross weight.

A foot (plural feet) is a unit of length defined as being exactly 0.3048 m and used in the imperial system of units and US customary units. It is subdivided into 12 in. The foot is still officially used in Canada and still commonly used in the UK, although the latter has partially metricated its units of measurement.
Foot per hour (plural feet per hour) is an imperial unit for linear velocity expressed as ft/hr.

Foot per second (plural feet per second) is a unit of both speed (scalar) and velocity (vector quantity, which includes direction). It expresses the distance in feet (ft) travelled or displaced, divided by the time in seconds (s). The corresponding unit in the International System of Units (SI) is the metre per second.

Thegalileo (or Gal) is the unit of acceleration of free fall used extensively in the science of gravimetry. The galileo is defined as1 cm/s. Unfortunately, the galileo is often denoted with the symbol Gal, not to be confused with the gallon that also uses the same symbol (gal).
A proportional concentration ratio typically used for cement mixtures. The number of gallons of water added to 50 kg of additive(s).
Gamma is the CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system unit for magnetic field.
The gauss is the CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system unit for magnetic flux density (B).

The gigabyte is a multiple of the unit byte for digital information storage. The prefix giga means 10 in the International System of Units (SI), therefore 1 GB is 1000000000 B. The unit symbol for the gigabyte is GB or Gbyte, but not Gb (lowercase b) which is typically used for the gigabit. Historically, the term has also been used in some fields of computer science and information technology to denote the gibibyte, or 1073741824 B.
The gigajoule (GJ) is equal to one billion (10) joules. 6 GJ is about the chemical energy of combusting 1 barrel (159 l) of crude oil.
A measure of energy density defined as the energy in gigajoules per million litres.

The gigalitre (Gl) is a multiple of the unit litre (l), a non-International System of Units (SI) metric system unit of volume, equivalent to one billion or 10 litres. Also defined as 1 000 000 000-fold of the unit litre.
1000000000-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit pascal.
Grad is a unit for plane angle.

A grain is a unit of measurement of mass that is nominally based upon the mass of a single seed of a cereal. The grain is the only unit of mass measure common to the three traditional English mass and weight systems; the obsolete Tower grain was, by definition, exactly 1/64 of a troy grain. Since 1958, the grain or troy grain measure has been defined in terms of units of mass in the International System of Units (SI) as precisely 64.79891 mg. Thus,1gram15.4323584grains. There are precisely 7000 grains per avoirdupois pound in the imperial and US customary units, and 5760 grains in the troy pound.

The gram (g) is a unit of mass in the metric system. The name comes from the Greek gramma, a small weight identified in later Roman and Byzantine times with the Latin scripulum or scruple (the English scruple is equal to about 1.3 g). The gram was originally defined to be the mass of one cubic centimetre of pure water, but to provide precise standards it was necessary to construct physical objects of specified mass. One gram is now defined to be 1/1000 of the mass of the standard kilogram, a platinumiridium bar carefully guarded by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures in Paris for more than a century. (The kilogram, rather than the gram, is considered the base unit of mass in the International System of Units [SI].) The gram is a small mass, equal to about 15.432 grains or 0.035273966 oz.

Gram per cubic centimetre is an International System of Units (SI) derived unit of density, defined by mass in grams divided by volume in cubic centimetres. The official SI symbol is g.cm, or equivalently g/cm. Also defined as 0.001-fold of the SI base unit kilogram divided by the 0.000 001-fold of the power of the SI base unit metre with the exponent 3.
Gram per cubic metre is an International System of Units (SI) derived unit of density, defined by mass in grams divided by volume in cubic metres. The official SI symbol is g.m (or g/m).

Gram per litre is an International System of Units (SI) derived unit of density, defined by mass in grams divided by volume in litres. The official SI symbol is g/l (or g.l). Also defined as 0.001-fold of the SI base unit kilogram divided by the unit litre.
A measure of concentration. The number of grams of a material of interest within the mass of one short ton of total material.
Grams per kilogram (g/kg) is a measure of concentration. The number of grams of a material of interest within the mass of 1kg of total material.

Grams per millilitre (g/ml) is a measure of concentration. The number of grams of a material of interest within the volume of one millilitre of total material. Also defined as 0.001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram divided by the 0.001-fold of the unit litre

Grams per tonne (g/t) is a measure of concentration. The number of grams of a material of interest within the mass of one tonne of total material. In mining, it is also equivalent to one part per million, expressed as ppm.
