The International System of Units (SI) unit of radiation dose. Radiation carries energy, and when it is absorbed by matter the matter receives this energy. The dose is the amount of energy deposited per unit of mass. One gray is defined to be the dose of one joule of energy absorbed per kilogram of matter, or 100 rad. The unit is named for the British physician L Harold Gray (190565), an authority on the use of radiation in the treatment of cancer.

The US customary metric unit of land area, equal to 100 acres. One hectare is a square hectometre, that is, the area of a square 100 metres on each side: exactly 10 000 m or approximately 107 639.1 ft, 11 959.9 yd, or 2.471054 acres.
A metric system unit of mass equal to 100 times the metric tonne.

The hertz (Hz) is the International System of Units (SI) unit of frequency defined as the number of cycles per second of a periodic phenomenon. One of its most common uses is the description of the sine wave, particularly those used in radio and audio applications, such as the frequency of musical tones. The unit is named for Heinrich Rudolf Hertz, who was the first to conclusively prove the existence of electromagnetic waves.

The hour (common symbol: h or hr) is a unit of measurement of time. In modern usage, an hour comprises 60 min, or 3600 s. It is approximately 1/24 of a mean solar day. An hour in the Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) time standard can include a negative or positive leap second, and may therefore have a duration of 3599 or 3601 seconds for adjustment purposes. Although it is not a standard defined by the International System of Units (SI), the hour is a unit accepted for use within the SI, represented by the symbol h.
An imperial unit for linear velocity. Used in borehole drilling to describe the rate of penetration and describes the number of hours taken to penetrate 1ft of material.
A unit for linear velocity. Used in borehole drilling to describe the rate of penetration and describes the number of hours taken to penetrate 1m of material.
A measure of rotation of angular velocity. The number of revolutions of an object relative to a fixed frame of reference in 1 min, divided by 100.
Imperial gallon is an imperial unit for liquid volume, expressed as gal{Imp}. It corresponds to 4.5609 litres.

The exact length of the land mile (mi) varied slightly among English-speaking countries until the international yard and pound agreement in 1959 established the yard as exactly 0.9144 m, giving a mile of exactly 1609.344 m. The US adopted this international mile for most purposes, but retained the pre-1959 mile for some land-survey data, terming it the US survey mile. In the US, statute mile formally refers to the survey mile, about 3.219 mm (1/8 in) longer than the international mile (the international mile is exactly 0.0002% less than the US survey mile).

An inch (in) is the name of a unit of length in a number of different systems, including imperial units, and US customary units. There are 36 in in a yard and 12 in in a foot, and 1in equals 25.4 mm. The difference between a US customary inch and an imperial inch is insignificant for most applications (the accepted value of 25.4 mm is 1.7 millionths of an inch longer than the old imperial inch and 2 millionths of an inch shorter than the old US inch). Corresponding units of area and volume are the square inch and the cubic inch.
A measure of compressibility. The inverse of one pascal.

The joule (J) is the International System of Units (SI) unit for work or energy, defined to be the work done by a force of 1 N acting to move an object through a distance of 1 m in the direction in which the force is applied. Equivalently, since kinetic energy is one half the mass times the square of the velocity, 1 J is the kinetic energy of a mass of 2 kg moving at a velocity of 1 m/s.

Joule per square centimetre (J/cm) is a measure of energy density. This unit is commonly used in the International System of units (SI). Also defined as derived SI unit joule divided by the 0.0001-fold of the power of the SI base unit metre by exponent 2.

The International System of Units (SI) base unit of temperature, previously called the degree kelvin. One kelvin (K) represents the same temperature difference as one degree Celsius. In 1967, the General Conference on Weights and Measures defined the temperature of the triple point of water (the temperature at which water exists simultaneously in the gaseous, liquid, and solid states) to be exactly 273.16 K. Since this temperature is also equal to 0.01 C, the temperature in kelvins is always equal to 273.15 plus the temperature in degrees Celsius. The kelvin equals exactly 1.8 F. The unit is named for the British mathematician and physicist William Thomson (18241907), later known as Lord Kelvin after he was named Baron Kelvin of Largs.
Kilo electron volt is a unit for energy and work expressed as keV, and is a multiple of the electron volt (eV), where 1 keV = 1000 eV.

The kilobar (kbar) is derived from the bar and is equivalent to 1000 or 10 bars. It is not an International System of Units (SI) or CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) unit, but is accepted for use with the SI.

The kilobyte is a multiple of the unit byte for digital information equivalent to 1000 bytes. Although the prefix kilo means 1000, the term kilobyte and symbol kB have historically been used to refer to either 1024 (2) bytes or 1000 (10) bytes, dependent upon context, in the fields of computer science and information technology. This ambiguity is removed in the Quantities, Units, Dimensions and Types Ontology (QUDT), with kibibyte (KiB) used to refer to 10 bytes.

The kilogram (kg), also known as the kilo, is the base unit of mass in the International System of Units (SI) and is defined as being equal to the mass of the International Prototype Kilogram (IPK), which is almost exactly equal to the mass of 1 litre of water. The avoirdupois (or international) pound, used in both the imperial system and US customary units, is defined as exactly 0.45359237 kg, making 1 kg approximately equal to 2.2046 avoirdupois pounds.
Kilogram per cubic metre is an International System of Units (SI) derived unit of density, defined by mass in kilograms divided by volume in cubic metres. The official SI symbol is kg.m (or kg/m).

Kilogram per litre is an International System of Units (SI) derived unit of density, defined by mass in kilograms divided by volume in litres. The official SI symbol is kg/l (or kg.l). Also defined as the SI base unit kilogram divided by the unit litre.

Kilogram per metre (kg/m) is a unit of linear mass density. This unit is commonly used in the International System of Units (SI). Kilogram per metre (kg/m) has a dimension of ML where M is mass, and L is length. This unit is the standard SI unit in this category.
A measure of concentration. The number of kilograms of a material of interest within the mass of 1 t of total material.
The kilojoule is a multiple of the unit joule, the unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI), equivalent to 1000 or 10 joules. Also defined as 1000-fold of the SI derived unit joule.
The kilolitre is a multiple of the unit litre, a non-International System of Units (SI) metric system unit of volume, equivalent to 1000 or 10 litres.
A measure of volume flow rate. Thousands of litres divided by number of days.

The kilometre (km) is a common metric unit of length or distance. 1 km equals exactly 1000 m, about 0.62137119 mi, 1093.6133 yd, or 3280.8399 ft. Oddly, higher multiples of the metre are rarely used; even the distances to the farthest galaxies are usually measured in kilometres.
The kilonewton (kN) is a multiple of the unit newton (N), the International System of Units (SI) unit of force.
Kilopascal (kPa) is a unit of pressure. 1 kPa is approximately the pressure exerted by a 10 g mass resting on a 1cm area. 101.3 kPa = 1 atm. There are 1000 Pa in 1 kPa.
A measure of mass equivalent to 1000 t.

Latitude degrees are theunits of measurement for the angular distance of a place north or south of the earth's equator.Lines of constant latitude run east and west, parallel to the equator, and range from 0 degrees at the equator to 90 degrees at the North or South poles.There are different kinds of latitude  geocentric, astronomical, and geographic (or geodetic)  but there are only minor differences between them. In most common references, geodetic latitude is implied. Geodetic latitude is the arc subtended by the equatorial plane and the normal line that can be drawn at a given point on Earths surface. It is measured in degrees, minutes and seconds or decimal degrees, north or south of the equator. Geodetic latitude angles are usually denoted by the Greek lowercase letter phi ( or ), with uppercase N or S to indicate whether the location is in the Northern or Southern hemisphere. One degree of latitude covers about 111 km (69 mi) and can be further divided into 60 minutes and 60 seconds.
A unit of length defining the distance, in metres, that light travels in a vacuum in one year.

The litre (l or L) is a non-International System of Units (SI) metric system unit of volume equal to 1 dm, 1000 cm or 1/1000 m. If the lowercase "l" is used as the symbol, it is sometimes rendered as a cursive "l" to help distinguish it from the capital "I", although this usage has no official approval by any international bureau.
The unit litre (l) divided by the unit day (d).
The unit litre (l) divided by the unit hour (h).
The unit litre (l) divided by the unit minute (min).
A proportional concentration ratio typically used for cement mixtures. The number of litres of water added to 50 kg of additive(s).
A measure of concentration ratio. The number of litres of a subject fluid per tonne of total material.

Long ton is the name for the unit called the 'ton' in the avoirdupois or imperial system of measurements, as used in the UK and several other Commonwealth countries. 1 lt is equal to 2240 lb (1016 kg), 1.12 times as much as a short ton, or 35 ft (0.9911 m) of salt water with a density of 64 lb/ft (1.025 g/ml).

Longitude degrees are theunits of measurement for the angular distance of a place east or west of the International Reference Meridian (IRM, or prime meridian), a specially designated imaginary northsouth line that passes through both geographic poles and Greenwich, London. The prime meridian defines 0 longitude. Longitude is measured in degrees, minutes and seconds or in decimal degrees, and corresponds to the amount of arc created by drawing first a line from Earths centre to the intersection of the Equator and the prime meridian and then another line from Earths centre to any point elsewhere on the Equator. Longitude is measured 180 both east and west of the prime meridian.Longitude angles are usually denoted by the Greek lowercase letter lambda (), One degree of latitude covers about 111 km (69 mi) and can be further divided into 60 minutes and 60 seconds. The distance per degree of longitude at the Equator is about 111.32 km (69.18 mi) and at the poles, 0.
The megabyte is defined here as 1 000 000 bytes.

The megajoule (MJ) is a multiple of the unit joule (J), the unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI), equivalent to one million or 10 joules. Also defined as 1000000-fold of the derived unit joule.

The megalitre (Ml) is a multiple of the unit litre (l), a non-International System of Units (SI) metric system unit of volume, equivalent to one million or 10 litres. Also defined as 1 000 000-fold of the unit litre.
A measure of volume flow rate. Millions of litres (Ml) divided by number of days (d).

The megapascal (MPa) is a multiple of the pascal (Pa), the International System of Units (SI) unit of pressure. 1 MPa equals 1 000 000 or 10 pascals. Also defined as 1000000-fold of the derived unit pascal.

Megapound force (Mlbf) is a multiple of the unit pound force (lbf), a unit of force used in some systems of measurement, including English Engineering units and the footpoundsecond system. 1 Mlbf is equivalent to 1 000 000 lbf.
A measure of mass equivalent to one million (or 10) tonnes.

The metric and International System of Units (SI) base unit of distance. The 17th General Conference on Weights and Measures in 1983 defined the metre as that distance that makes the speed of light in a vacuum equal to exactly 299 792 458 m/s. The speed of light in a vacuum, c, is one of the fundamental constants of nature. The metre is equal to approximately 1.0936133 yd, 3.280840 ft, or 39.370079 in.

Metre per hour (m/h) is a metric unit of both speed (scalar) and velocity (vector quantity which specifies both magnitude and a specific direction). By definition, an object travelling at a speed of 1 m/h for an hour would move 1 m.

Metre per second (m/s) is an International System of Units (SI) derived unit of both speed (scalar) and velocity (vector quantity which specifies both magnitude and a specific direction), defined by distance in metres divided by time in seconds. The official SI symbol is ms (or m/s).

Metre per square secondis the unit of acceleration in the International System of Units (SI). As a derived unit it is composed from the SI base units of length, the metre, and the standard unit of time, the second. Its symbol is written in several forms asm/s, orms. As acceleration, the unit is interpreted physically as change in velocity or speed per time interval, that is,metre per second per second.
A measure of compressibility equivalent to the inverse of 1 Pa.
A measure of velocity. The number of metres traversed in the time of 1 ms.
Microgal (Gal) is a unit of acceleration equal to one-millionth of one Gal or 10 Gals.
Microgram (g) is a unit of mass equal to one-millionth of 1 g or 10 g. Also defined as 0.000000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram.

A measure of concentration. The number of micrograms (g) of a material of interest within the mass of 1 kg of total material. Also defined as mass ratio of 0.000000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram divided by the SI base unit kilogram.

A measure of concentration. The number of micrograms (g) of a material of interest within the volume of one litre (l) of total material. Also defined as 0.000000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram divided by the unit litre.

A measure of concentration. The number of micrograms (g) of a material of interest within the mass of 1 g of total material. Also defined as one part per 10 (million) by mass of the measurand in the matrix.

The micrometre (m), also commonly known by the non-International System of Units (SI) term micron, is a unit of length in the SI equalling 110 metre; that is, one millionth of a metre (or one thousandth of a millimetre, 0.001 mm, or about 0.00004 in).

Themicrometre per square second (m/s)is a unit of acceleration and is often called the 'gravity unit'. As acceleration, the unit is interpreted physically as change in velocity or speed per time interval, that is,micrometre per second per second.

Microsiemens (S) is a unit of electrical conductance, susceptance and admittance equal to one-millionth of a siemens or 10 siemens. Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit siemens.

A measure of conductivity. The number of microsiemens divided by the number of centimetres. Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit Siemens divided by the 0.01-fold of the SI base unit metre.

A measure of conductivity. The number of microsiemens divided by the number of metres. Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit Siemens divided by the SI base unit metre.
The microsievert is a measure of dose equivalent for ionizing radiation, equal to one-millionth of one sievert or 10 sievert.

A volumetric measure of the rate of radiogenic heat production, corresponding to 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit watt divided by the power of the SI base unit metre with the exponent 3.

A measure of permeability. A medium with a permeability of 1 millidarcy (mD) permits a flow of 0.001cm/s of a fluid with viscosity 1cP (1 mPas) under a pressure gradient of 1atm/cm acting across an area of 1cm.
0.001-fold of the unit of acceleration called Gal according to the CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system of units.
Milligram (mg) is a unit of mass equal to one-thousandth of one gram or 10 grams. Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram.

A measure of concentration. The number of milligrams (mg) of a material of interest within the mass of 1 kg of total material. Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram divided by the SI base unit kilogram.

A measure of concentration. The number of milligrams (mg) of a material of interest within the volume of one litre (l) of total material. Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram divided by the unit litre.

A measure of concentration. The number of milligrams of material of interest per gram of total material in a sample. Also defined as the 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit kilogram divided by the 0.001-fold of the SI base unit kilogram.
A measure of concentration. The number of milligrams of a material of interest within the mass of 1 t of total material.

The amount of energy produced by the complete combustion of a material or fuel. Measured in millijoules per kilogram (mJ/kg). Also defined as 0.000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit joule divided by the unit kilogram.
The CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system unit of volume, equal to 10 cubic metre, 10 litre, or about 0.0610237 in. Also defined as 0.001-fold of the unit litre.

The millimetre (mm) is a unit of length in the metric system, equal to one thousandth of a metre, which is the International System of Units (SI) base unit of length. It is equal to 1000 m or 1000000 nm. A millimetre is equal to exactly 5/127 (approximately 0.039370) of an inch.
A measure of energy defined as the energy equivalent to 1 000 000 barrels of oil (6.117863210 J).

concepts.prefLabel: million barrel of oil equivalent per megalitre
concepts.definition: A measure of oil quality or energy density defined as the energy equivalent to 1 000 000 barrel of oil equivalents (6.117863210 J) per million litres.
A unit equivalent in volume to 1 000 000 barrels.
An imperial measure unit of energy, defined as 1 000 000 British thermal units (BTU).

concepts.prefLabel: million British thermal units per megalitre
concepts.definition: A measure of oil quality or energy density defined as the energy in 1 000 000 British thermal units (BTU) (1055000000J) per million litres.
A multiple of the unit carat (ct). Equal to 1 000 000 (or 10) carats, and with a mass of 200kg.
An imperial measure of volume equivalent to 1 000 000 ft.
A measure of volume flow rate. Millions of cubic feet divided by number of days.
A measure of volume equivalent to 1 000 000 m.
A measure of mass equivalent to 1 000 000 lt (weight ton or imperial ton).
The number of years divided by 1 000 000. Commonly used in disciplines that describe events over long periods, such as astronomy and geology. The symbol Myr is deprecated in geology.
A milliradian is a unit of angular measure, equivalent to one-thousandth of one radian, or 10 radians.
Millisecond (ms) is an imperial unit for time, equivalent to one-thousandth of one second, or 10 seconds.
A measure of conductivity. Expressed as time in milliseconds divided by distance in centimetres.

Millisiemens (mS) is a unit of electrical conductance, susceptance and admittance equal to one-thousandth of a siemens or 10 siemens. Also defined as 0.001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit siemens.

A measure of the rate of heat flow, as determined or estimated through an area at or below the Earth's surface (crustal or mantle heat flow). It corresponds to 0.001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit watt divided by the power of the SI base unit metre with the exponent 2.

A minute is a unit of measurement of time. The minute is a unit of time equal to 1/60 (the first sexagesimal fraction) of an hour or 60 s. In the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) time scale, a minute on rare occasions has 59 or 61 seconds. The minute is not an International System of Units (SI) unit; however, it is accepted for use with SI units. The SI symbol for minute or minutes is min (for time measurement) or the prime symbol after a number, e.g. 5' (for angle measurement, even if it is informally used for time).

The mole (mol) is a unit of measurement used in chemistry to express amounts of a chemical substance (as distinct from its mass or weight). The official definition, adopted as part of the International System of Units (SI) in 1971, is that 1 mol of a substance contains just as many elementary entities (atoms, molecules, ions, or other kinds of particles) as there are atoms in 12 g of carbon-12 (carbon-12 is the most common atomic form of carbon, consisting of atoms having 6 protons and 6 neutrons). This corresponds to a value of 6.02214179(30)  10 elementary entities of the substance.
Percentage of the total moles that is of a particular component.
A unit of time corresponding approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, or about 30 days or 4 weeks. Also known as the 'Synodic Month' and calculated as 29.53059 days.
A nanogram (ng) is a unit of mass equivalent to 10 grams or one 10 of the International System of Units (SI) standard unit of mass (kilogram).
Nanogram per litre (ng/L) is a measurement of mass density, expressed as nanograms divided by number of litres.

A measure of radiation dose, expressed as nanograys per hour. The gray (Gy) is an International System of Units (SI) unit for the measurement of radiation exposure, equivalent to the energy 'deposited' in a kilogram of a substance by the radiation. Exposure is also referred to as absorbed dose. The important concept is that exposure is measured by what radiation does to substances, not anything particular about the radiation itself. The gray is a large unit and for normal radiation protection levels a series of prefixes are used: nanogray (nGy) is one billionth of a gray (1/1000000000), microgray (Gy) is one millionth of a gray (1/1000000), milligray (mGy) is one thousandth of a gray (1/1000).
A nanometre (nm) is a unit of length equivalent to one-billionth of one metre or 10 metres. Also defined as 0.000000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit metre.
A nanosecond is an International System of Units (SI) unit of time equal to one-billionth of one second (10 or 1/1000000000s). One nanosecond is to one second as one second is to 31.69 years.

A measure of flux density (or field intensity) for magnetic fields (also called the magnetic induction). A nanotesla is 0.000000001-fold of the International System of Units (SI) derived unit tesla. A nanotesla is equivalent to one gamma, a unit originally defined as 10 gauss, which is the unit of magnetic field in the CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system.

A unit of distance used primarily at sea and in aviation. The nautical mile (nmi) is defined to be the average distance on the Earth's surface represented by one minute of latitude. In 1929, an international conference in Monaco redefined the nautical mile to be exactly 1852 m or 6076.11549 ft, a distance known as the international nautical mile. The international nautical mile equals about 1.1508 statute miles. There are usually 3 nautical miles in a league. The unit is designed to equal 1/60 degree, although actual degrees of latitude vary from about 59.7 to 60.3 nautical miles. (Note: using data from the Geodetic Reference System 1980, the 'true' length of a nautical mile would be 1852.216 m).

The newton (N) is the International System of Units (SI) unit of force. A force of 1 N will accelerate a mass of 1 kg at the rate of 1 m per second per second. The newton is named for Isaac Newton (16421727), the British mathematician, physicist, and natural philosopher. He was the first person to understand clearly the relationship between force (F), mass (m), and acceleration (a) expressed by the formula F = ma.
Gravitational field strength at a point is the gravitational force per unit mass at that point. It is a vector and its International System of Units (SI) unit is N/kg.

Newton per metre (N/m) is a unit in the category of surface tension. This unit is commonly used in the International System of Units (SI). Newton per metre has a dimension of MT where M is mass, and T is time. This unit is the standard SI unit in this category.

Reserved for all those instances where results of qualitative nature are submitted in conjunction with quantitative results, e.g. as part of statutory requirements. For example, non-numeric results used to indicate if a soil sample fizzed when tested with acid, records of colour or other physical properties.

The ohm (represented by the uppercase Greek letter omega, ) is the unit of electrical resistance in the International System of Units (SI). The ohm is defined as an electrical resistance between two points of a conductor when a constant potential difference of one volt (V), applied to these points, produces in the conductor a current of one ampere (A), the conductor not being the seat of any electromotive force. It is named after German physicist Georg Simon Ohm (17891854).
The ohm metre is the International System of Units (SI) unit of electrical resistivity (m). It measures the electrical resistance of a material or how strongly it resists electric current.
An ounce of mass is 1/16th of a pound of mass or 28.349523125 g, based on the international standard definition of the pound as exactly 0.45359237 kg.
Unit ounce according to the avoirdupois system of units divided by the power of the unit yard according to the AngloAmerican and the imperial system of units with the exponent 3.
A measure of concentration. The number of ounces of a material of interest within the mass of 1 t of total material.
A measure of concentration. The number of ounces of a material of interest within the mass of 1 t of total material.
Dimensionless unit for concentration. Recommended practice is to use specific units such as g/l, but note that parts per billion is a common standard for reporting geochemical analyses.

Dimensionless unit for concentration. Recommended practice is to use specific units such as g/l, but note that parts per million is a standard for reporting geochemical analyses. In mining, it is also equivalent to one gram per metric ton, expressed as g/t.

Dimensionless unit for concentration. Recommended practice is to use specific units such as g/l, but note that parts per thousand is a common standard for reporting geochemical analyses. Often referred to as per mille () when reporting the results of isotope analyses.
Dimensionless unit for concentration. Recommended practice is to use specific units such as g/l, but note that parts per trillion is a common standard for reporting geochemical analyses.

The International System of Units (SI) unit of pressure. The pascal is the standard pressure unit in the metrekilogramsecond (MKS) metric system, equal to one newton per square metre or one kilogram per metre per second per second. The unit is named for Blaise Pascal (16231662), French philosopher and mathematician, who was the first person to use a barometer to measure differences in altitude.
A rate of change of pressure measured as the number of pascals in a period of 1 s.
The International System of Units (SI) unit of dynamic viscosity, equal to 10 poises or 1000 centipoises.

Penny weight (dwt) is a non-International System of Units (SI)-conforming unit of mass which comes from the AngloAmerican Troy or Apothecaries' Weight System of units according to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) of 1 dwt = 1.555174 10 kg.

altLabels: Penny weight per cubic imperial yard
concepts.definition: A measure of density expressed as penny weight divided by cubic yards.

altLabels: Penny weight Per Long Imperial Ton
concepts.definition: A measure of concentration. The amount of penny weight of a material of interest within the mass of one long ton of total material.

altLabels: Penny weight Per Short Imperial Ton
concepts.definition: A measure of concentration. The amount of penny weight of a material of interest within the mass of one short ton of total material.
Percent is a unit for 'Dimensionless Ratio' expressed as %.
The proportion of the volume of a material of interest within the volume of a total sample expressed as a percentage.
The proportion of the weight or mass of a material of interest within the weight or mass of a total sample expressed as a percentage.

A petabyte (PB) is a unit of information equal to one quadrillion bytes, or 10 TB. The prefix peta (P) indicates the fifth power to 1000: 1 PB = 1 000 000 000 000 000 B, 1 000 000 GB = 1000 TB. The pebibyte (PiB), using a binary prefix, is the corresponding power of 10, which is more than 12% greater (2 B = 1125899906842624 B).

The petajoule (PJ) is equal to one quadrillion (10) joules. 210 PJ is about 50 megatons of TNT (trinitrotoluene) which is the amount of energy released by the Tsar Bomba, the largest man-made explosion ever. Also defined as the 1000000000000000-fold of the derived International System of Units (SI) unit joule.
A measure of energy density defined as the energy in petajoules per million litres.

Poise (P) is a CentimetreGramSecond (CGS) system unit for dynamic viscosity. The SI derived unit for dynamic viscosity is the pascal second (Pa.s); 1 Pa.s is equal to 10 P. It is named after Jean Louis Marie Poiseuille.
Pound force is an imperial unit for force expressed as lbf.
A pound of mass, based on the international standard definition of the pound as exactly 0.45359237 kg.
Pound per cubic foot is an imperial unit for density.
Pound per foot is an imperial unit for mass per length.
Pound per gallon is an imperial unit for density.

Pounds of force per square inch, the unit for pressure as a compounded unit pound-force according to the AngloAmerican system of units divided by the power of the unit inch according to the AngloAmerican and imperial system of units by exponent 2.
Pounds force per 100 square feet (lbf/100ft) is a British (imperial) and US pressure unit. The number of pounds force applied to an area of 100 ft.
Pounds per 100 square feet (lb/100ft) is a British (imperial) and US pressure unit. The force equivalent to the number of pounds mass under standard gravity conditions applied to an area of 100 ft.
A proportional concentration ratio typically used for cement mixtures. The number of pounds of water added to 50kg of additive(s).
A measure of fluid density. The weight in pounds equivalent to one barrel of fluid.
A measure of the resistance offered by an elastic body to deformation. The length change of a body, in inches, relative to the force applied, in pounds force.

Theradis a deprecated unit of absorbed radiation dose, defined as1rad=0.01Gy=0.01J/kg. It was originally defined in CGS units in 1953 as the dose causing 100 ergs of energy to be absorbed by one gram of matter. It has been replaced by the gray in most of the world. A related unit, theroentgen, was formerly used to quantify the number of rad deposited into a target when it was exposed to radiation. The F-factor can used to convert between rad and roentgens. The material absorbing the radiation can be human tissue or silicon microchips or any other medium (for example, air, water, lead shielding, etc.).

The radian is the standard unit of angular measure in the International System of Units (SI), and is used in many areas of mathematics. It describes the plane angle subtended by a circular arc as the length of the arc divided by the radius of the arc. Angles without explicitly specified units are generally assumed to be measured in radians, especially in mathematical writing, and when degrees are meant the symbol degree () is used.
The quantitative relation between two amounts showing the number of times one value contains or is contained within the other. The ratio has no symbol.

Reciprocal of the 0.01-fold of the International System of Units (SI) base unit metre. It is used to measure wavenumber in spectroscopy and most chemistry fields, and is defined as the number of wavelengths per unit distance, typically centimetres (cm).

A rem is a deprecated unit used to measure the biological effects of ionizing radiation. The rem is defined as equal to 0.01sievert, which is the more commonly used unit outside of the United States. Equivalent dose, effective dose and committed dose can all be measured in units of rem. These quantities are products of the absorbed dose in rads and weighting factors. These factors must be selected for each exposure situation; there is no universally applicable conversion constant from rad to rem. A rem is a large dose of radiation, so the millirem (mrem), which is one thousandth of a rem, is often used for the dosages commonly encountered, such as the amount of radiation received from medical x-rays and background sources.
Revolution per hour is a measure of angular velocity expressed as rev/h.
Revolution per minute is a measure of angular velocity expressed as rev/min.
Not to be confused with roentgen equivalent man or roentgen equivalent physical. The roentgen (symbol R) is an obsolete unit of measurement for the kerma of X-rays and gamma rays up to 3MeV.
The second (s) is the base unit of time in the International System of Units (SI) and is also a unit of time in other systems of measurement.

The short ton (st) is a unit of mass equal to 2000 lb (907.18474 kg). In the US it is often called simply ton without distinguishing it from the metric ton (tonne, 1000 kg / 2204.62262 lb) or the long ton (2240 lb / 1016.0469088 kg); rather, the other two are specifically noted. There are, however, some US applications for which unspecified tons normally means long tons.
The number of perforation shots in a borehole casing or liner per foot.
The number of perforation shots in a borehole casing or liner per metre.

A siemens (S) is the International System of Units (SI) unit of electric conductance, susceptance and admittance. The most important property of a conductor is the amount of current it will carry when a voltage is applied. Current flow is opposed by resistance in all circuits, and by also by reactance and impedance in alternating current circuits. Conductance, susceptance and admittance are the inverses of resistance, reactance and impedance, respectively. To measure these properties, the siemens is the reciprocal of the ohm (). In other words, the conductance, susceptance or admittance, in siemens, is simply 1 divided by the resistance, reactance or impedance, respectively, in ohms. The unit is named for the German electrical engineer Werner von Siemens (18161892).

A measure of dose equivalent, a computed average measure of the radiation absorbed by a fixed mass of biological tissue, that attempts to account for the different biological damage potential of different types of ionizing radiation. Although the sievert has the same dimensions as the gray (i.e. joules per kilogram), it measures a different quantity. To avoid any risk of confusion between the absorbed dose and the equivalent dose, the corresponding special units, namely the gray instead of the joule per kilogram for absorbed dose and the sievert instead of the joule per kilogram for the dose equivalent, should be used.
A unit of area equal to that of a square of sides 1cm.

The square foot is an imperial unit and US customary unit of area, used mainly in the US, Canada, UK, Hong Kong, Bangladesh, India, Pakistan and Afghanistan. It is defined as the area of a square with sides of 1 ft in length.
A unit of area equal to that of a square of sides 1km.
The International System of Units (SI) unit of area is the square metre. A unit of area equal to that of a square of sides 1m.

The square mile is an imperial and US unit of measure for an area equal to the area of a square of one statute mile. It should not be confused with miles square, which refers to the number of miles on each side squared. For instance, 20 miles square (20  20 mi) is equal to 400 square miles. One square mile is equivalent to: 4014489600 in, 27878400 ft, 3097600 yd, 640 acres, 258.9988110336 ha, 2560 roods, 25899881103.36 cm, 2589988.110336 m, 2.589988110336 km. When applied to a portion of the Earth's surface, which is curved rather than flat, 'square mile' is an informal synonym for section.
A unit of area equal to that of a square of sides 1mm.

The standard atmosphere (atm) is an international reference pressure defined as 101.325kPa and formerly used as unit of pressure. For practical purposes it has been replaced by the bar which is 100kPa. The difference of about 1% is not significant for many applications, and is within the error range of common pressure gauges.
A measure of concentration or gas content. Typically used in the resource industry to refer to the number of cubic feet of a gas contained within 1 t of host material.

The standard cubic metre (SCM) is a unit representing the amount of gas (such as natural gas) contained in a volume of one cubic metre at reference temperature and pressure conditions. As such, it is a measure of the actual amount of gas, not the volume of the gas. The reference conditions for standard cubic metre are 0 degrees Celsius and 101.325 kilopascals (kPa) of pressure.

The standard cubic metre per day (SCMD or SM/d) is the molar flow rate of a gas (such as natural gas) contained in a volume of one cubic metre at reference temperature and pressure conditions. As such, it is a measure of the actual amount of gas, not the volume of the gas. The reference conditions for standard cubic metre per minute are 0 degrees Celsius and 101.325 kilopascals (kPa) of pressure.

The terabyte (TB) is a multiple of the unit byte for digital information. The prefix tera means 10 in the International System of Units (SI), and therefore 1 TB is 1000000000000B (1 trillion bytes) or 1000 GB. 1 TB in binary prefixes is 0.9095 tebibytes, or 931.32 gibibytes. The unit symbol for the terabyte is TB or TByte, but not Tb (lowercase b) which refers to terabit.

The terajoule is a multiple of the unit joule, the unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI), equivalent to 1000000000000 or 10 J. Also defined as 1000000000000-fold of the SI derived unit joule.

The International System of Units (SI) unit of flux density (or field intensity) for magnetic fields (also called the magnetic induction). The intensity of a magnetic field can be measured by placing a current-carrying conductor in the field. The magnetic field exerts a force on the conductor, a force which depends on the amount of the current and on the length of the conductor. One tesla (T) is defined as the field intensity generating 1 N of force per ampere of current per metre of conductor. Equivalently, 1 T represents a magnetic flux density of 1 weber (Wb) per square metre of area. A field of 1 T is quite strong: the strongest fields available in laboratories are about 20 T, and the Earth's magnetic flux density, at its surface, is about 50 T. The tesla, defined in 1958, honours the SerbianAmerican electrical engineer Nikola Tesla (18561943), whose work in electromagnetic induction led to the first practical generators and motors using alternating current.
A unit equivalent in volume to 1000 barrels.

concepts.prefLabel: thousand barrels of oil equivalent per megalitre
concepts.definition: A measure of oil quality or energy density defined as the energy equivalent to 1000 barrel of oil equivalents (6.117863210 J) per million litres.
An imperial measure unit of energy, defined as 1000 BTU (British Thermal Units).

concepts.prefLabel: thousand British thermal units per megalitre
concepts.definition: A measure of oil quality or energy density defined as the energy in 1000 BTU (British Thermal Units; 1055000 J) per million litres.
A multiple of the unit carat (ct). Equal to 1000 carats or 10 carats, and with a mass of 200g.
Thousand cubic feet is a unit of volume, used in the US and the UK. It is defined as the volume of a cube with sides of 1000 ft in length.
Thousand cubic metres is a unit of volume, defined as the volume of a cube with sides of 1000 m in length.
A mass equivalent to 1000 lb.
A US customary unit of force. It equals 1000 lbf, used primarily by US architects and engineers to measure engineering loads.
A scaled unit derived from psi, equivalent to a thousand psi (1000 lbf/in).
A measure of rotation or angular velocity. The number of revolutions of an object relative to a fixed frame of reference in 1 min, divided by 1000.
The number of years divided by 1000. Commonly used in disciplines that describe events over long periods, such as astronomy and geology.

The tonne (t) is a metric system unit of mass equal to 1000 kg (2204.6 lb). It is a non-International System of Units (SI) unit accepted for use with the SI. To avoid confusion with the ton, it is also known as the metric tonne and metric ton in the US and occasionally in the UK. In SI units and prefixes, the tonne is a megagram (Mg), a rarely used symbol, easily confused with mg, for milligram.

The tonne of oil equivalent (toe) is a unit of energy: the amount of energy released by burning 1 t of crude oil, approximately 42 GJ (as different crude oils have different calorific values, the exact value of the toe is defined by convention; unfortunately there are several slightly different definitions). The toe is sometimes used for large amounts of energy, as it can be more intuitive to visualise, say, the energy released by burning 1000 t of oil than 42000 billion joules (the International System of Units [SI] unit of energy).
A measure of mass density, expressed by the unit tonne divided by the power of the International System of Units (SI) base unit metre with the exponent 3.

The troy ounce is an obsolete metric used in weighing precious metals. The troy ounce is 1/12th of a troy pound. Based on the international definition of a troy pound as 5760 grains, the troy ounce is exactly 480 grains, or 0.0311034768 kg (or 31.1034768 g).

altLabels: Troy Ounce Per Long Imperial Ton
concepts.definition: A measure of concentration. The number of troy ounces of a material of interest within the mass of 1 lt of total material.

altLabels: Troy Ounce Per Short Imperial Ton
concepts.definition: A measure of concentration. The number of troy ounces of a material of interest within the mass of 1 st of total material.
An obsolete unit of mass; the troy pound has been defined as exactly 5760 grains, or 0.3732417216 kg. A troy ounce is 1/12th of a troy pound.
An explicit unit to describe a value with no units.
The unit for a given value is unknown.
A measure of flow rate, typically used for oil production. The number of standard US barrels flowing past a given point per hour.
A measure of flow rate, typically used for oil production. The number of standard US barrels flowing past a given point per minute.
United States (US) Gallon is a unit for liquid volume, corresponding to 3.78541178 litres.

The International System of Units (SI) unit of power. Power is the rate at which work is done, or (equivalently) the rate at which energy is expended. One watt (W) is equal to a power rate of 1 J of work per second of time. This unit is used both in mechanics and in electricity, so it links the mechanical and electrical units to one another. In mechanical terms, one watt equals about 0.001 341 02 horsepower (hp) or 0.737 562 foot-pound per second. In electrical terms, 1 W is the power produced by a current of 1 A flowing through an electric potential of 1 V. The name of the unit honours James Watt (17361819), the British engineer whose improvements to the steam engine are often credited with igniting the Industrial Revolution.
Mean solar week. A week is a unit of time equal to seven days. It is the standard time period used for short cycles of days in most parts of the world.

A yard (yd) is a unit of length in several different systems including US customary units, imperial units and the former English units. It is equal to 3 ft or 36 in. Under an agreement in 1959 between Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa, the UK and the US, the yard (known as the 'international yard' in the US) was legally defined to be exactly 0.9144 m.

A year is any of the various periods equated with one passage of Earth about the Sun, and hence of roughly 365 days. The familiar calendar has a mixture of 365- and 366-day years, reflecting the fact that the time for one complete passage takes about 365 days; the precise value for this figure depends on the manner of defining the year.

Carlisle is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area. The site includes several buildings encompassing separate functions of the Geological Survey of Western Australia, and is located at 37 Harris St, Carlisle WA 6101.

The Carlisle laboratory is a Geological Survey of Western Australia facility undertaking in-house sample processing (mainly for geochronology) that also houses the Petrographic slide collection. The building is located on the Carlisle site at 37 Harris St, Carlisle WA 6101.

The Carlisle Records building is a Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety facility housing various key collections, including departmental Records (physical and digital), library assets and geological slides. The building is located on the Carlisle site at 37 Harris St, Carlisle WA 6101.

The field logistics building is a Geological Survey of Western Australia facility housing field vehicles and equipment, plus physical assets relating to the petroleum relinquishment and paleontology collections. The building is located on the Carlisle site at 37 Harris St, Carlisle WA 6101.
The Harry Butler Research Centre houses the collections and research staff of the Western Australian Museum. The building is located at 49 Kew St, Welshpool WA 6106.

concepts.prefLabel: Iron Mountain Australia Group storage facility
concepts.definition: The building mainly stores Western Australian petroleum seismic cartridges submitted by petroleum companies for archiving and future retrieval and processing of data. The building is located at 2224 Ledgar Road, Balcatta WA 6021.

The JH (Joe) Lord Core Library is one of two Geological Survey of Western Australia storage and viewing facilities housing geological exploration materials (predominantly drillcores and samples) and related media. The building is located on the Kalgoorlie site at the corner of Hunter and Broadwood Sts, West Kalgoorlie WA 6430.

The Kalgoorlie regional office is a facility of the Geological Survey of Western Australia primarily housing staff, but also hosting some small collections. The building is located on the Kalgoorlie site at the corner of Hunter and Broadwood Sts, West Kalgoorlie WA 6430.

Mineral House is one of several offices maintained by the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety within the Perth metropolitan area, and is the department's main administrative office. The building is located at 100 Plain St, East Perth WA 6004.

The foyer of Mineral House has display cabinets for sections of the GSWA's rock and mineral collections. The venue is open to the public during office hours and can be accessed via the main entrance to the building at 100 Plain St, East Perth WA 6004.

The Mineral House Library houses the main collections of scientific literature (books and journals) and key historical images, documents and assets belonging to the Department of Energy, Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety. The Library is located on Level 1 of Mineral House, 100 Plain St, East Perth WA 6004.

Collections belonging to the Geological Survey of Western Australia are housed on various floors within Mineral House, including the ground floor (foyer), and levels 1, 4 and 5. Mineral House is located at 100 Plain St, East Perth WA 6004.

The Museum of the Goldfields is a regional branch of the Western Australian Museum, focused on the geology, biology and culture of the Goldfields region. The building is located at 17 Hannan Street, Kalgoorlie WA 6430.

The Perth Core Library is one of two Geological Survey of Western Australia storage and viewing facilities housing geological exploration materials (predominantly drillcores and samples) and related media. The building is located on the Carlisle site at 37 Harris Street, Carlisle WA 6101.

The Perth Mint is a State-owned, precious-metal refinery and tourist venture. The Perth Mint's main administrative office, plus historical displays and collections, are housed at 310 Hay St, East Perth WA 6004.

WA Museum Boola Bardip houses the Western Australian Museum's primary displays in Perth (including Earth and planetary sciences, terrestrial biology and cultural displays). The building is located in the Perth Cultural Centre, Perth WA 6000.

The Western Australian Museum manages the State's primary archive of cultural and natural history assets. Established in 1891, the Western Australian Museum now comprises six public sites and a research and collections centre. The Museum is managed by the Department of Local Government, Sport and Cultural Industries.
A special term for a variety of granite in which plagioclase is less than 10% of the total feldspar. Now defined modally in QAPF field 2 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 52)
A special term for a variety of syenite in which plagioclase is less than 10% of the total feldspar. Now defined modally in QAPF field 6 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 52)

Gneissose or granofelsic metamorphic rock mainly consisting of green, brown or black amphibole and plagioclase (including albite) and derived from an unspecified intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic protolith. Amphibole and plagioclase combined form more than 75% of the rock, with both being present as major constituents; the amphibole constitutes more than 50% of the total mafic constituents and is present in an amount of 30%. Other common minerals include quartz, clinopyroxene, garnet, epidote-group minerals, biotite, titanite and scapolite. Amphibolites are mostly present in amphibolite-facies metamorphic complexes, or in the highest subfacies of the greenschist facies. Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 128).

Gneissose or granofelsic metamorphic rock mainly consisting of green, brown or black amphibole and plagioclase (including albite) and derived from an intrusive protolith. Amphibole and plagioclase combined form more than 75% of the rock, with both being present as major constituents; the amphibole constitutes more than 50% of the total mafic constituents and is present in an amount greater than or equal to 30%. Other common minerals include quartz, clinopyroxene, garnet, epidote-group minerals, biotite, titanite and scapolite. Amphibolites are mostly present in amphibolite-facies metamorphic complexes, or in the highest subfacies of the greenschist facies. Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 128).

Gneissose or granofelsic metamorphic rock mainly consisting of green, brown or black amphibole and plagioclase (including albite) and derived from a volcanic protolith. Amphibole and plagioclase combined form more than 75% of the rock, with both being present as major constituents; the amphibole constitutes more than 50% of the total mafic constituents and is present in an amount of greater or equal to 30%. Other common minerals include quartz, clinopyroxene, garnet, epidote-group minerals, biotite, titanite and scapolite. Amphibolites are mostly present in amphibolite-facies metamorphic complexes, or in the highest subfacies of the greenschist facies. Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 128). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of amphiboles. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of amphiboles. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154155).
A granofels/hornfels distinguished by the abundance of amphiboles. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a granofels/hornfels for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A schist distinguished by the abundance of amphiboles. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

An intermediate volcanic rock, usually porphyritic, consisting of plagioclase (frequently zoned from labradorite to oligoclase), pyroxene, hornblende and/or biotite. Now defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 (Fig. 2.11, p. 31) and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field O2 (Fig. 2.14, p. 35). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 56). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.
An evaporite consisting predominantly of the mineral anhydrite, i.e. of anhydrous calcium sulfate (CaSO).

A leucocratic intrusive rock consisting essentially of plagioclase commonly with small amounts of pyroxene. Now defined modally in QAPF field 10 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). The term is synonymous with plagioclasite. (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 57)

Coal of the highest metamorphic rank, in which fixed-carbon content is between 92% and 98% and less than 14% volatile matter (on a dry, mineral-matter-free basis). It is hard and black, and has a semi-metallic lustre and semi-conchoidal fracture. Anthracite ignites with difficulty and burns with a short blue flame, without smoke. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A general term used for well-sorted, consolidated sedimentary rocks composed of sand-sized fragments (irrespective of composition) with a pure or nearly pure chemical cement and less than 10% argillaceous matrix; as distinguished from wacke. Further subdivision is based on proportions of quartz (Q), feldspar (F) and rock/lithic fragments (R/L). Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011)

A feldspar-rich sandstone, commonly coarse-grained and pink or reddish, that is typically composed of angular to subangular grains that may be either poorly or moderately well sorted, is usually derived from the rapid disintegration of granite or granitic rocks, and often closely resembles granite. Quartz is usually the dominant mineral, with feldspars constituting at least 25%. Cement (silica or calcite) is commonly rare, and matrix material (usually less than 15%) includes clay minerals (especially kaolinite), mica, and iron oxide; fine-grained rock fragments are often present. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

Banded iron-formation (BIF) is an iron formation that shows marked banding, generally of iron-rich minerals and chert or fine-grained quartz. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A mappable concentration of the mineral baryte, a white, yellow, or colourless orthorhombic barium sulfate (BaSO4). Baryte occurs in tabular crystals, in granular form, or in compact masses resembling marble, deposited via either biogenic or evaporitic processes. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).
A rock comprising baryte of pegmatitic or hydrothermal origin, as vein-filling material.

A dark-coloured volcanic rock consisting essentially of calcic plagioclase and pyroxene. Olivine and minor foids or minor interstitial quartz may also be present. Now defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 (Fig. 2.11, p. 31) and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field B (Fig. 2.14, p. 35). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 60). The GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

A volcanic rock with plagioclase of variable composition and the ferromagnesian minerals more commonly found in basalts, e.g. olivine. Now defined chemically in TAS field O1. Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 61). The GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

Coal that ranks between sub-bituminous coal and anthracite, contains more than 14% volatile matter (on a dry, ash-free basis) and has a calorific value of more than 11,500 BTU/lb (26.75 MJ/kg) (moist, mineral-matter-free) or more than 10 500 BTU/lb (24.42 MJ/kg) if agglomerating. It is dark brown to black in colour and burns with a smoky flame. Bituminous coal is the most abundant rank of coal. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

Fault rock that is cohesive and characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size for more than 90% of the rock volume, and displays a significant degree of grain growth related to or following deformation. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 134).

Schist whose bluish colour is due to the presence of sodic amphibole. More precise terms should be used wherever possible (e.g. glaucophane schist). The term is also used as a facies name and if used in this sense the facies context should be made clear by saying blueschist-facies rock (or schist, or gneiss, or granofels). (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 135)
A consolidated rock consisting mainly of boulders (clasts greater than 256 mm or -8 phi units in size). Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A gneissose rock mainly composed of calc-silicate minerals (i.e. calcium-rich silicate minerals) and containing less than 5% volume of carbonate minerals (calcite and/or aragonite and/or dolomite). Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 137).

A granofels/hornfels mainly composed of calc-silicate minerals (i.e. calcium-rich silicate minerals) and containing less than 5% volume of carbonate minerals (calcite and/or aragonite and/or dolomite) (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 137). A calc-silicate rock formed by contact metasomatism of a carbonate or marly rock (i.e. a calc-silicate hornfels) is also referred to as tactite (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 199).

Metamorphic rock mainly composed of calc-silicate minerals (i.e. calcium-rich silicate minerals) and containing less than 5% volume of carbonate minerals (calcite and/or aragonite and/or dolomite). Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 137)

A schistose rock mainly composed of calc-silicate minerals (i.e. calcium-rich silicate minerals) and containing less than 5% volume of carbonate minerals (calcite and/or aragonite and/or dolomite). Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 137)

A limestone consisting predominantly (more than 50%) of sand-size, detrital carbonate grains; a consolidated calcareous sand. The term was introduced by Grabau (1903). (Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011)
A terrigenous sandstone that is cemented with calcite. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A limestone consisting predominantly (more than 50%) of detrital calcite particles of silt and/or clay size; a consolidated carbonate mud. The term was introduced by Grabau (1903). Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A limestone consisting predominantly (more than 50%) of detrital calcite particles larger than sand size (larger than 2 mm in diameter), and commonly also cemented with calcareous material; a consolidated calcareous gravel or rubble, or a limestone conglomerate or breccia. The term was introduced by Grabau (1903). Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).
An evaporite consisting predominantly of the mineral calcite, i.e. of anhydrous calcium carbonate (CaCO).
A rock comprising calcite of hydrothermal origin, as vein-filling material.

A variety of carbonatite in which the main carbonate is calcite (section 2.3, p. 10). If the rock is coarse-grained it may be called svite; if medium- to fine-grained, alvikite. Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 10, 66, 53 and 143).

A variety of lamprophyre composed of phenocrysts of combinations of olivine, kaersutite, titanian augite, and Ti-rich biotite in a matrix of the same minerals (minus olivine) with plagioclase and sometimes subordinate alkali feldspar and feldspathoids. A volatile-rich basanite or alkali basalt. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 67)
Limestone and/or dolomite interleaved with siliciclastic rocks at outcrop scale.

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of carbonate mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of carbonate mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154155).

A metamorphosed sedimentary carbonate rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss derived from a sedimentary rock consisting mostly of carbonates. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154155).

A granofels/hornfels distinguished by the abundance of carbonate mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a granofels/hornfels for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A metamorphosed sedimentary carbonate rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from a sedimentary rock consisting mostly of carbonates. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).
A sedimentary rock consisting of more than 50% by weight of carbonate minerals, otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A sedimentary rock consisting of more than 50% by weight of carbonate minerals, otherwise uncategorised (adapted from Glossary of geology (2011, 5th edition revised). GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

A schist distinguished by the abundance of carbonate mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

A metamorphosed sedimentary carbonate rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from a sedimentary rock consisting mostly of carbonates. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154155).

A mafic igneous rock affected by carbon dioxide metasomatism, whereby the interaction of the rock with CO2 fluids has resulted in the formation of carbonate minerals (such as calcite and dolomite), and for which an intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic protolith cannot be conclusively identified. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

A mafic volcanic rock affected by carbon dioxide metasomatism, whereby the interaction of the rock with CO fluids has resulted in the formation of carbonate minerals (such as calcite and dolomite). There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

A collective term for an igneous (intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic) rock in which the modal amount of primary carbonate minerals is greater than 50%, but otherwise uncategorized (section 2.3, p. 10). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 68).

An igneous (intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic) carbonate-rich rock, otherwise uncategorized. GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of angular fragments greater than 2 mm in size consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of angular fragments ranging in size from sand (0.0625  2 mm) and above, consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion w, and with an overall mafic composition.

A conglomerate consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A breccia composed mostly of angular fragments ranging in size from granule (24 mm) to pebble (432 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A mudstone (grain size ranging from silt to clay (i.e. less than 0.0625 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A volcaniclastic rock consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin and with more than 50% modal carbonates, but otherwise uncategorized. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A sandstone (grain size 0.0625  2 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of fragments ranging in size from sand (0.0625  2 mm) to silt (0.0039  0.0625 mm) of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with more than 50% modal carbonates. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A commonly monomictic breccia with more than 50% modal carbonates composed of angular, coarse igneous fragments cemented by a fine-grained matrix that is clastic though not necessarily strictly sedimentary in origin. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes between 50 and 90% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 138).

A soft, pure, earthy, fine-textured, usually white to light grey or buff limestone of marine origin, consisting almost wholly (9099%) of calcite, formed mainly by calcareous tests of floating microorganisms (chiefly foraminifers) and of comminuted remains of calcareous algae (such as coccoliths and rhabdoliths), set in a structureless matrix of very finely crystalline calcite. The rock is porous, somewhat friable, and only slightly coherent. It may include the remains of bottom-dwelling organisms (e.g. echinoderms and bivalves), and nodules of chert and pyrite. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A sedimentary rock composed primarily of material formed directly by (a) precipitation from solution or colloidal suspension (as by evaporation), (b) by the deposition of insoluble precipitates (as by mixing solutions of two soluble salts), or (c) resulting directly or indirectly from the chemical processes and activities of living organisms  otherwise uncategorised. It generally has a crystalline texture. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A sedimentary rock composed primarily of material formed by precipitation from solution or colloidal suspension, by the deposition of insoluble precipitates, or resulting from the chemical processes and activities of living organisms  otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

A hard, extremely dense or compact, dull to semivitreous, microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline sedimentary rock, consisting dominantly of interlocking crystals of quartz less than about 30 m in diameter; it may contain amorphous silica (opal) or cryptocrystalline quartz (chalcedony). It sometimes contains impurities such as calcite, iron oxide, and the remains of siliceous and other organisms. It has a tough, splintery to conchoidal fracture, and may be white or variously coloured grey, green, blue, pink, red, yellow, brown, and black. Chert occurs principally as nodular or concretionary segregations (chert nodules) in limestones and dolomites, and as areally extensive layered deposits (bedded chert ); it may be an original organic or inorganic precipitate or a replacement product. The term flint is essentially synonymous, although it has been used for the dark variety of chert. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of chlorite minerals. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of chlorite minerals. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154155).
A granofels/hornfels distinguished by the abundance of chlorite minerals. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a granofels/hornfels for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

A schist distinguished by the abundance of chlorite minerals. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).
An ultramafic rock consisting essentially of chromite (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 69).

An indurated mud with 66% or more clay-sized minerals, and the composition of shale but lacking its fine lamination or fissility; a massive mudstone in which clay predominates over silt; a nonfissile clay shale. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A gabbro sensu strictu, i.e. a mafic intrusive rock (or the coarse-grained part of an extrusive succession) defined modally in QAPF field 10 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22) and consisting of plagioclase more calcic than An50 and clinopyroxene (augite), with less than 5% each of olivine and orthopyroxene in its mode (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 2425).
An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting almost entirely of clinopyroxene. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 69)

A readily combustible rock containing more than 50% by weight and more than 70% by volume of carbonaceous material including inherent moisture, formed from compaction and induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those in peat. Differences in the kinds of plant materials (type), in degree of metamorphism (rank), and in the range of impurity (grade) are characteristic of coal and are used in classification. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A consolidated rock consisting mainly of cobbles (64256 mm or -4 to -8  phi units) being somewhat rounded or otherwise modified by abrasion in the course of transport. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A coarse-grained clastic sedimentary rock, composed of rounded to subangular fragments larger than 2 mm in diameter (granules, pebbles, cobbles, boulders) typically containing fine-grained particles (sand, silt, clay) in the interstices, and commonly cemented by iron oxide, silica, carbonate or hardened clay; the consolidated equivalent of gravel both in size range and in the essential roundness and sorting of its constituent particles. The rock or mineral fragments may be of varied composition and range widely in size. Conglomerates may be classified according to nature or composition of fragments, proportion of matrix, degree of size sorting, type of cement, and agent or environment of formation. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).
Conglomerate interleaved with other siliciclastic rocks/beds/intervals at outcrop scale.
Conglomerate and sandstone beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

A detrital limestone composed wholly or chiefly of mechanically sorted fossil debris that experienced abrasion and transport before reaching the depositional site. The term is derived from the Spanish word for "cockle" and "shellfish". Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A cohesive fault breccia formed by deformation that caused the fragmentation of the rock in place or nearly in place. In the classification of Fossen (2016) crush breccia specifically refers to occurrences where fragments are larger than 5 mm; GSWA usage of the term is for rocks of unknown protolith, and includes 'fine crush breccia' (fragments between 1 and 5 mm) and 'crush microbreccia' (fragments less than 1 mm). Crush breccias have less than 10% matrix and fragments are usually glued together by cement (typically quartz or calcite) and/or microfragments of minerals that have been crushed during faulting. Adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 143).

A dolomitic sedimentary rock in which the depositional texture is not recognizable, owing to recrystallization and replacement. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A calcitic sedimentary rock in which the depositional texture is not recognizable, owing to recrystallization and replacement. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

A volcanic rock composed of quartz and sodic plagioclase with minor amounts of biotite and/or hornblende and/or pyroxene. The volcanic equivalent of granodiorite and tonalite. Now defined modally in QAPF fields 4 and 5 (Fig. 2.11, p. 31) and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field O3 (Fig. 2.14, p. 35). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 72). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

A comprehensive, nongenetic term for an unsorted or poorly sorted, noncalcareous, terrigenous sedimentary rock that contains a wide range of particle sizes, such as a rock with sand and/or larger particles in a muddy matrix; e.g. a tillite or a pebbly mudstone. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).
Diamictite and other siliciclastic rocks/beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

A light-coloured, soft, friable, siliceous sedimentary rock, consisting chiefly of opaline diatom frustules, typically white, but also pale yellow, grey, or tan.
