It should be noted, though, that although traditionally defined as undeformed, hornfels facies rocks exhibiting deformation features have been documented in the geological record. The facies corresponds to temperatures of about 300450 C at pressures less than about 2 kbar. It is typical of metamorphism in the outer parts of contact aureoles, under ultrahigh (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions. Numerous studies do not give facies status to albite-epidote hornfels.

Metamorphic facies representing moderate pressure and temperature conditions. It lies between the epidoteamphibolite (or greenschist) and granulite facies. Amphibolite facies mineral assemblages in metabasic rocks are represented by hornblendeplagioclase, the plagioclase being oligoclaseandesine or more calcic varieties (Eskola, 1939), with epidote and almandine garnet common. Metapelitic rocks are characterized by diagnostic mineral assemblages containing micas associated with garnet, staurolite, kyanite or sillimanite at higher pressures, and andalusite or cordierite at lower pressures within the facies. Amphibolite facies is typical of regional metamorphism at pressures of about 4.5  15kbar and of regional or contact metamorphism at pressures less than about 4.5kbar. Temperatures span the range 450700 C, and in situ partial melting of rocks occurs in the upper part of this range (above about 650C). The facies encompasses moderate to high (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow typical of many tectonic environments, and it is thus is a common metamorphic facies for metamorphosed rocks.

A metamorphic facies diagnostic of high-pressure (>2 GPa), low-temperature (<500 C) metamorphism of mafic rocks. Mafic rocks at blueschist facies are represented by combinations of the diagnostic sodic amphibole (e.g. glaucophane, crossite) and lawsonite, sodic pyroxene, aragonite, epidote, and garnet. The mineral pair jadeitequartz is also diagnostic. Blueschist facies metasiliciclastic rocks may contain diagnostic mineral assemblages involving carpholite, chloritoid, talc, kyanite and phengitic white mica. The facies represents lower temperatures and higher pressures than the greenschist and prehnitepumpelleyite facies, lower pressures than eclogite facies, and temperatures less than the amphibolite facies (less than about 500C). At depths indicative of blueschist facies, lower temperatures are not realised in Earth. Blueschist facies metamorphism is associated with tectonic environments in which rocks experience near isothermal compression followed by near isothermal decompression, such as at subduction zones (i.e. unusually low (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow). The term blueschist can also be used as a rock type, so when used as a facies name, the facies context should be made clear (i.e. blueschist-facies rock).

Metamorphic facies corresponding to high grade and middle to high P/T values, and bounded (in rocks of suitable composition) by the omphacitegarnet-in reactions. Metabasic rocks are represented by omphacitic pyroxene and almandinepyrope garnet, and lawsonite in the coolest rocks. Also common, but not essential, is the association pyropeolivinediopsideenstatite. At ultra-high pressures (minimum 28kbar at 600C), coesite, diamond or majoritic garnet occur in metabasic rocks. Metapelitic rocks are not typically reported as having recorded eclogite-facies conditions and therefore diagnostic mineral assemblages are not reported for them. The facies represents the highest pressures possible for metamorphism in Earth's crust and upper mantle. It occurs to higher pressure than the blueschist, amphibolite and granulite facies (approximately >15kbar), and over a broad range of temperatures (approximately >500C). The facies encompasses low to moderate (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow, and subduction environments are typical for the lower temperature part of the eclogite facies.

Metamorphic facies formed at low to moderate temperatures and pressures, considered to be transitional between the greenschist facies and the amphibolite facies. It is characterized by temperatures of about 400450C and spans low to moderate (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow. In metabasic rocks, the facies is represented by hornblendealbiteepidote, where plagioclase has an anorthite content <17 (albiteoligoclase). Given the presence of epidoteplagioclase (An<17), it is considered by some workers as a high grade subfacies of the greenschist facies.

Metamorphic facies representing the highest grades of metamorphism; it forms at high temperature and at medium and high pressure/temperature values and lies between the eclogite and pyroxene-hornfels facies. It is characterized by clinopyroxene (diopside)  orthopyroxene (hypersthene)  plagioclase assemblages with minor and usually Ti-rich amphibole in rocks of basaltic composition. Almandine-rich garnet is characteristic of metabasic and metapelitic rocks. Metapelitic mineral assemblages show the association of sillimanite or kyanite with perthitic feldspar and garnet at higher pressures, and cordierite and orthopyroxene at lower pressures; muscovite is absent and biotite abundance is low. At the highest temperatures, diagnostic minerals are sapphirine and osumilite in Mg-rich metasiliciclastic rocks. The presence of leucosomes due to in situ partial melting is common. The facies occurs at higher temperature than the amphibolite facies. The facies is typical of regional or high-temperature contact metamorphism at pressures of about 217kbar in excess of about 700750C. The facies encompasses moderate to high (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow typical of many tectonic environments, and it is thus a common metamorphic facies for metamorphosed rocks.

Metamorphic facies representing low grades of metamorphism. At greenschist facies, metabasic rocks are represented by actinolitealbiteepidotechlorite (Eskola, 1939). Chlorite, white mica, biotite and chloritoid are typical minerals in metasiliciclastic rocks. Greenschist facies develops at low to medium temperatures and pressures, and lies between the epidoteamphibolite and subgreenschist facies. It corresponds to temperatures in the range 300450C and spans a large range from low to high apparent thermal gradients typical of many tectonic environments, meaning it is a common metamorphic facies for metamorphosed rocks.

The upper range of pressure conditions for the amphibolite facies, typically characterized by the presence of kyanite and garnet in metapelitic rocks, and garnet and increasingly sodic clinopyroxene in metabasic rocks.

High-pressure subset of the granulite facies, reserved for rocks within the kyanite stability field, but below pressures corresponding to the stability of jadeitequartz of the eclogite facies. It is typical of high-grade regional metamorphism of deep crust under moderate (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions. The highest temperature high-pressure granulite facies rocks probably require rocks to be pre-conditioned (refractory) in order for such thermal conditions to be attained.

A metamorphic facies representing moderate to high temperatures and low or very low pressures, with temperature lower than the pyroxene hornfels facies and pressure lower than the amphibolite facies. Metabasic rocks are represented by the assemblage hornblendeplagioclasediopsideanthophyllite/cummingtonitequartz, analogous to that of the amphibolite facies. Metapelitic rocks exhibit the association of muscovitebiotiteandalusitecordieritequartzplagioclase, analogous to the lower pressure part of the amphibolite facies. The distinction between the greenschist and hornblende facies is textural  undeformed hornfels versus foliated schists  rather than mineralogical. It should be noted, though, that although traditionally defined as undeformed, hornfels facies rocks exhibiting deformation features have been documented in the geological record. The facies corresponds to temperatures of about 450700 C at pressures less than about 2 kbar. It is typical of metamorphism in the middle to outer parts of contact aureoles, under ultrahigh (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.
The lower range of temperature conditions for the amphibolite facies, typically characterised by staurolite, garnet and chloritoid in metapelitic rocks.
The lower range of temperature conditions that greenschist facies can form in, transitional with and overlapping with the prehnitepumpellyite facies.
The mid range of temperature conditions for the amphibolite facies, typically characterized by the presence of staurolite, andalusite and kyanite in metapelitic rocks.

A metamorphic facies representing very low grades of metamorphism. It is defined by the diagnostic mineral assemblage of albitequartzprehnitepumpellyitechloritesphene (Coombs et al., 1959), and the absence of zeolites, lawsonite or jadeite. The mineral assemblage is best developed in metagraywackes. The facies is considered to represent pressuretemperature conditions of about 300C, between those of the zeolite facies and the greenschist facies.

A metamorphic facies representing very high temperatures and low or very low pressures, with temperature lower than the sanidinite facies and pressure lower than the granulite facies. Metabasic rocks are represented by the assemblage clinopyroxene (diopside)  orthopyroxene (hypersthene)  plagioclase, with hornblende typically absent. Metapelitic rocks exhibit the association of sillimanite (or andalusite) and cordierite with potassium feldspar; muscovite is absent. Marbles contain wollastonite and calciteforsteritepericlase (Turner, 1968). The facies corresponds to temperatures in excess of about 700 C at pressures less than about 2 kbar. It is typical of high-grade thermal metamorphism, for example in the inner parts of contact aureoles, under ultrahigh (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions. Although traditionally defined as undeformed, hornfels facies rocks exhibiting deformation features are present in the geological record.

Metamorphic facies representing extreme high temperatures and low or very low pressures. It lies below the granulite facies. It is characterized by the occurrence of especially high-temperature varieties and polymorphs of minerals, for example tridymite, mullite, monticellite, larnite, sanidine, K-rich labradorite and pigeonite. The facies encompasses occurrences of metamorphism at very high temperature and very low pressure conditions, e.g. xenoliths in basic lavas, fragments in tuffs, or narrow contact zones bordering shallow mafic intrusive pipes. Many rocks show evidence of partial to complete fusion (e.g. buchite). The facies occurs at lower pressure than the granulite facies, and represents the highest temperature part (>800C) of crustal metamorphism under ultrahigh (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

A broad term encompassing rocks of very low metamorphic grade that likely correspond to either the low-greenschist facies or prehnitepumpellyite facies of metamorphism. Commonly used for field-based descriptions.

Highest temperature subset of the granulite facies, reserved for temperatures >900C, and typically at pressures approximately 5kbar and bound at higher pressure by the kyanitesillimanite reaction. Diagnostic mineral assemblages include orthopyroxenesillimanite, sapphirine or osumilite in metasedimentary rock types. It is typical of high-grade regional metamorphism of deep crust and requires rocks to be pre-conditioned (refractory) in order for such thermal conditions to be attained.
The specific metamorphic facies of a rock is not specified, typically due to the rock mineralogy being non-diagnostic of metamorphic pressuretemperature conditions (e.g. quartzite or metachert).

The upper range of temperature conditions for the amphibolite facies, typically characterized by the presence of kyanite or sillimanite and leucosomes (evidence of partial melting) in metapelitic rocks.

The upper range of temperature conditions for the greenschist facies, characterized by stable oligoclase and actinolite-to-hornblende transition. It overlaps with and includes the lowest temperature range of lower amphibolite facies.

The facies that includes zeolite group minerals such as analcime, heulandite, stilbite, laumontite, and wairakite (Coombs, 1960). It is the lowest grade of metamorphism, at around 200250C, transitional between diagenesis (or unmetamorphosed rock) and the prehnitepumpellyite facies or the greenschist facies. Various zeolite assemblages can be correlated with depth of burial (Miyashiro and Shido, 1970). Diagnostic minerals are best developed in metagraywackes and metabasalts.

Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a PT diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Anticlockwise PT paths are those in which the thermal maximum (peak temperature) is reached prior to the peak pressure being attained. These PT paths generally reflect high (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a PT diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Clockwise PT paths are those in which peak pressure is reached prior to peak temperature being attained. These PT paths generally reflect burial and subsequent heating under low to intermediate (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature decreases (i.e. cooling) over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature increases (i.e. heating) over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant over a period of time (t), during a metamorphic event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while the pressure decreases over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while pressure increases over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic cooling event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic heating event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic compression event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic decompression event.
The pressure(P)temperature(T)time(t) path for a specific metamorphic event is unknown.

Typically reserved for use when: a) overprinting or unclear spatialtextural relationships do not allow discernment of whether all or some of the minerals preserved in the rock are indicative of the highest temperature equilibrium mineral assemblage; or b) the possibility of polymetamorphism is likely. This ambiguity arises, for example, when sluggish reaction kinetics in porphyroblastic minerals at low to moderate pressure/temperature metamorphic conditions lead to metastability.

The mineral assemblage of the rock is tentatively interpreted to represent a (relict) prograde mineral assemblage. This term is used when metamorphic information is cryptically preserved, e.g. within inclusions in porphyroblastic minerals, or there is ambiguity about polymetamorphism.

The mineral assemblage of the rock is tentatively interpreted to represent a (relict) retrograde mineral assemblage. Typically used when the possibility of polymetamorphism is high and/or unclear, i.e. when it cannot be ascertained whether lower temperature metamorphic minerals overprinting a higher grade assemblage formed during the same, single metamorphic cycle, or whether a later, lower temperature event (i.e. retrogressive) overprinted the higher grade assemblage.
Metamorphic conditions taken to be the thermal maximum reached during a metamorphic cycle or evolution, regardless of the PT trajectory.

Metamorphism giving rise to the formation of minerals that are typical of a higher metamorphic grade, i.e. higher temperature, than the former mineral assemblage. That is, a sequential increase in metamorphic grade with time (within a single metamorphic event) that is recognizable or inferred in a rock. It is that part of the metamorphic cycle up to the thermal maximum (peak metamorphic conditions).

Metamorphism giving rise to the formation of minerals that are typical of a lower grade, i.e. lower temperature, than the former mineral assemblage. That is, a sequential decrease in metamorphic grade with time (within a single metamorphic event) that is recognizable or inferred in a rock. It is that part of the metamorphic cycle after the thermal maximum (or peak metamorphic conditions) has been reached.

Metamorphism giving rise to the formation of minerals that are typical of a lower grade, i.e. lower temperature, than the former mineral assemblage. It is distinguished from retrograde metamorphism by the fact that the development of a lower grade mineral assemblage is ascribed to a separate, discrete metamorphic event that takes place at lower temperatures and a later time than the first metamorphic event.

It is not clear what stage of the metamorphic evolution the minerals in the rock represent, usually because of poor preservation of metamorphic minerals due to excessive alteration or weathering, or due to ambiguous mineralogical relationships that are suggestive of polymetamorphism.

High geothermal gradient or high apparent thermal gradient metamorphism, characterized by high heat flow. That is, temperature increases more rapidly than average with depth. Defined by apparent thermal gradients between 77.5 and 150 C/kbar (or 775 and 1500 C/GPa), and encompassing most of what is traditionally referred to as Barrovian style metamorphism. High thermal gradients encompass the middle and lower pressure range of amphibolite facies as well as the pressure range of typical granulites and ultra-high temperature granulites. Thermal gradient is defined in terms of pressure (i.e. thermobarometric ratio) rather than depth in kilometres to avoid assumptions involving density-related conversions.

Intermediate geothermal gradient or intermediate apparent thermal gradient metamorphism, characterized by average heat flow, approximating that of a steady-state geotherm for average thickness continental crust. That is, temperature increases at what is considered a normal rate with depth. Defined by apparent thermal gradients between 37.5 and 77.5C/kbar (or 375 and 775C/GPa), and encompassing, at the higher thermal gradient end of the range, the higher pressure part of what is traditionally referred to as Barrovian-style metamorphism. Intermediate thermal gradients encompass the middle and upper pressure range of amphibolite facies as well as high-pressure granulite (transitional to eclogite) facies. Thermal gradient is defined in terms of pressure (i.e. thermobarometric ratio) rather than depth in kilometres to avoid assumptions involving density-related conversions.

Low geothermal gradient or low apparent thermal gradient metamorphism, characterized by low heat flow (i.e. temperature increases more slowly than average with depth). Defined by apparent thermal gradients between 15 and 37.5C/kbar (or 150 and 375C/GPa). Low thermal gradients encompass most of the blueschist and eclogite facies. Thermal gradient is defined in terms of pressure (i.e. thermobarometric ratio) rather than depth in kilometres to avoid assumptions involving density-related conversions.

Near-surface ultra-high geothermal gradient or near-surface ultra-high apparent thermal gradient metamorphism, characterized by extremely high heat flow. That is, temperature increases extremely rapidly with depth compared to average. Defined by apparent thermal gradients greater than 250C/kbar (or 2500C/GPa). Near-surface ultra-high thermal gradients encompass pyroxene-hornfels and sanidinite facies. Thermal gradient is defined in terms of pressure (i.e. thermobarometric ratio) rather than depth in kilometres to avoid assumptions involving density-related conversions.

Ultra-high geothermal gradient or ultra-high apparent thermal gradient metamorphism, characterized by very high heat flow. That is, temperature increases much more rapidly than average with depth. Defined by apparent thermal gradients between 150 and 250C/kbar (or 1500 and 2500C/GPa), and encompassing most of what is traditionally referred to as Buchan-style metamorphism. Ultra-high thermal gradients encompass low-pressure amphibolite facies (incorporating andalusite stability), low-pressure granulite facies, and rare low-pressure, ultra-high temperature metamorphism. Thermal gradient is defined in terms of pressure (i.e. thermobarometric ratio) rather than depth in kilometres to avoid assumptions involving density-related conversions.

The highest hierarchical level for physiographic units in Australia, based on the classification by Pain et al. (2011). The onshore Australian continent is divided into three physiographic divisions, broadly coincident with a geological subdivision into the western shields, the central basins and the eastern fold belts; divisions are subdivided into several smaller physiographic provinces. Each physiographic division is identified by a name, a text description, and a single digit code (1, 2, and 3 from east to west), converted to a three- or five-digit number for database purposes (i.e. 100 or 10000) to allow better characterization when including physiographic provinces and regions.

The intermediate hierarchical level for physiographic units in Australia, based on the classification by Pain et al. (2011). Physiographic provinces distinguish major physiographic changes across the country and are compiled by grouping regions with similar landforms and geological characteristics at a scale of 1: 2.5M. The onshore Australian continent is divided into 23 physiographic provinces, in turn subdivided into several smaller physiographic regions. Each physiographic province is identified by a name, a text description, and a three-digit aggregate code that includes the parent physiographic division code as the first digit (e.g. 301, 302, etc.); this is converted to a five-digit code for database purposes (i.e. 30100, 30200, etc.) to allow better characterization when including physiographic regions. Descriptors include geology, structure and broad regolith types.

The lowest hierarchical level for physiographic units in Australia, based on the classification by Pain et al. (2011). Physiographic regions are the basic geomorphological subdivisions of Australia, and are internally consistent in terms of their landform morphology, relief, underlying geology and geomorphic origin. The onshore Australian continent is divided into 220 physiographic regions. Each region is identified by a name, a text description, and a five-digit aggregate code incorporating the notation of the parent physiographic division and province (e.g. 30100, where 3 represents the division, 301 the province, and 30100 the region). The primary descriptors for physiographic regions are geographic name and a simple text description including major geologic and geomorphic features.

Analytical blanks are blanks that are processed side-by-side with samples in order to reveal background levels and possible contamination for the entire laboratory process. If analytical blanks are sufficiently below the concentrations measured in samples, the technique is a good fit for the study. If they reveal a significant contribution to one or more component(s) being analysed, then troubleshooting may be necessary.

Coarse 'barren' or 'blank' aggregate material (often quartz) used to scour any remaining sample residue out of crushing/pulverisation equipment prior to the next sample being pulverised. This practice is frequently used in exploration and mining projects immediately after highly mineralised samples to minimise contamination of the next sample in the analytical sequence. This wash material may be discarded or analysed to examine whether the equipment is otherwise being adequately cleaned between samples.

In whole rock or regolith geochemical analysis, blank (informal) typically refers to material that has been analysed many times and is known to contain concentrations below (or very close to) the lower analytical detection limit of elements of interest, e.g. high-purity quartz (SiO).

A reference material submitted by the laboratory customer in a form that is indistinguishable from their samples of unknown compositions, so that the analyst is unaware that it is a reference material and thus allowing the customer to independently assess the accuracy of the analytical results.

A reference material analysed by the laboratory, along with samples of unknown compositions, to allow the laboratory to calibrate their analytical equipment or software. Calibration reference materials can also be used to monitor the accuracy of results and to allow calibration, normalisation and/or correction of unknown results within individual and across multiple analytical sessions. Calibration reference materials should be verified by an official source.

A certified reference material (CRM) is a sample material that has been prepared, typically in commercial volumes, and characterised by analysis across multiple laboratories (sometimes called 'round-robin certification'). The values for CRMs are generally well-known published figures. Elements and isotope ratios that have been characterised in this process are attributed with a certified value and uncertainty, specific to a certain analytical technique. CRMs are used to monitor accuracy and bias at the project laboratory relative to the certified values. They are also used to monitor drift over time within an individual laboratory and to identify significant failures in QC at the analytical batch level caused by abrupt changes in concentration related to re-calibration of instruments or procedural changes at the laboratory. CRMs can also be used to verify new or improved analytical techniques.

A sample that is analysed at a secondary laboratory as a check on the accuracy and precision of the analytical results of the primary laboratory. The methods used in the primary and check laboratories must be known to properly compare the results from the check samples. Check sampling is a common practice in exploration and mining programs to confirm sample grades over the entire range of concentrations in the resource, especially when the range of concentrations requires laboratories to change methods, instrument calibrations, sample weights, etc. to bring a target commodity within measurement range.
A second sample collected from the crushed field sample after the material has been reduced to a gravel (also called 'coarse crush') and analysed in the same analytical batch as the primary sample.

A sample collected or generated under comparable conditions to the primary sample and used as an indicator of relative precision when analysed concurrently, or kept as a reference for future usage. It is useful to distinguish the stage at which the duplicate was collected, i.e. whether in the field (field duplicate) or at any stage of sample-mass reduction (e.g. during crushing and pulverisation for rock or sieving for soil and stream-sediment samples, i.e. coarse-crush duplicate, pulp duplicate, etc.).

Field blanks are samples of natural material with similar characteristics (e.g. hardness, abrasiveness, rock type, sample media) to those being collected in the field that contain acceptably low concentrations of the elements of interest. They are inserted into the sample stream to test for potential cross-contamination, or carry-over, between samples.

A second sample of equal size (mass) to the original, collected as close as possible to the location of the original sample under comparable conditions and using an identical sampling procedure. Field duplicates are typically collected at the same time as the original and analysed within the same analytical batch to ensure that the only difference in the results is related to the sampling variance.

A second sample of equal size (mass) and comparable material to the original, collected at a sample site at a later date and under possibly different conditions but using identical sampling and analytical procedures. Often designed to test environmental factors, such as seasonal effects on surficial samples, or to validate historical results for the purpose of due diligence.
A second weighing of a sample taken from the same container as the original under laboratory conditions and analysed in the same analytical batch.
Reference material analysed by the laboratory, along with samples of unknown compositions, to allow the laboratory and/or their customers to assess the accuracy of the analytical results.

A test to determine the nominal particle size of sample material, typically completed at the final sample preparation stage on the sample material submitted for analysis (i.e. powder in most instances), expressed as a percentage of sample material that passes through a piece of mesh with openings of a certain size.

A second sample collected from the pulverised field sample after the material has been reduced to a powder and analysed in the same analytical batch as the primary sample. Many laboratories identify these as repeats, which is a common source of confusion.

A sample that has been re-assayed having previously been assayed. This may be because previous results were suspected to be spurious or did not return a valid result. Re-assaying is also a standard component of internal quality control procedures in many laboratories.

A reference material is a well-characterised sample used to monitor accuracy and bias of (analytical) measurements at the project laboratory relative to their documented values (see also certified reference materials). These samples may range from International Standards and Certified Reference Materials (CRMs) to locally prepared standard samples for use as project reference standards.

Replicates are aliquots of the same sample analysed repeatedly on the instrument and expected to reproduce results consistently. The standard deviation among replicate samples reflects the precision (or lack thereof) for that particular analysis and that particular sample. For example, if two aliquots of the same digestate are analysed 10 samples apart from each other during analysis with widely different results, a large uncertainty will be associated with that sample that may affect what conclusions can be drawn from the data generated during that analysis.

A sample preparation process where a sample is split into two or more aliquots. Sample splitting occurs after the sample is crushed or pulverised, typically to reduce sample material to a manageable volume. Ideally, a sample is split using a method that collects a compositionally representative aliquot of material for further processing.

Material with known quantity values added to an analytical sample to test the accuracy and validity of the analytical method. The material can be a reference material or a certified reference material. The known quantity value is often a fraction or concentration. Multiple spikes can be added to a sample (e.g. double spike or triple spike) with precisely known proportions to quantify mass fractionation of mass spectrometers (also known as an internal standard).

A sample that is analysed at a third, or umpire, laboratory to resolve discrepancies between primary and secondary laboratories. Commonly used to resolve disputes between the shipper and the receiver of mineral concentrates, and/or to confirm precision and accuracy of laboratory results in situations where small and repeated variations in assay values are likely to have a large effect on interpretation, such as in the case of precious metal resource estimation.

A sample or specimen containing inorganic arsenic, either as an element or a compound (e.g. in sulfide minerals), and forming naturally or as part of storage (e.g. concentration of toxic vapours in enclosed spaces). Inorganic arsenic is a highly toxic and carcinogenic component, known to be harmful to human health if inhaled, ingested or absorbed.

A sample or specimen containing acicular or fibrous asbestos (serpentine or amphibole) minerals, either naturally or as part of storage materials, which can cause internal damage if breathed or ingested.
A sample or specimen containing biologically hazardous materials, whether naturally, as part of storage materials, or due to a fault.

A sample or specimen where the object has been broken during collection, storage or analysis. This differs from multi-part or segmented specimens or samples in that the damage and disaggregation of the object is human-caused and accidental.
A sample or specimen that is vulnerable to damage when exposed to specific chemical compounds. This vulnerability may include one specific chemical class/type, or a wide range of compounds.
A sample or specimen damaged by having a small piece broken off at the edge or on the surface.
A sample or specimen that has been treated to remove dirt, mud and other extraneous particles/substances in preparation for analysis or further usage.

A sample or specimen partially covered with a thin layer of a chemical or compound selected for the purposes of improved visualisation (e.g. resin), analysis (e.g. carbon, oil or quartz coating) or protection (e.g. glass)

A sample or specimen which has undergone past repair by impregnating weakened, crumbling or porous surfaces or sections with a consolidant (e.g. paraloid, resin), where the area of repair may become a future vulnerability or hazard or may impede future study or repair processes.

A sample or specimen weakened or damaged by chemical reaction. Corrosion occurs whenever a gas or liquid chemically attacks an exposed surface, often a metal, and is accelerated by warm temperatures and/or specific chemical compounds such as acids and salts.
A sample or specimen where the loss of object integrity occurs after collection and is due to intrinsic specimen/sample vulnerabilities or improper collection or storage processes.
A sample or specimen that is naturally crumbly or granular and forms fine-grained, abrasive or poisonous particles when disturbed, whether naturally or as part of storage materials.

A sample or specimen fixed firmly and deeply within a supporting/enclosing material. The term can be used to describe specimens embedded in mounting media such as wax, epoxies, acrylics and polyesters, or in thermosetting resins or thermoplastics.
A sample or specimen altered in any way to improve its quality or value, or to emphasize its aesthetic appeal.

A sample or specimen considered of average preservation, quality and/or usefulness, i.e. has early signs of wear or deterioration, though the element is generally structurally sound and performing its intended purpose.
A sample or specimen consisting of or containing fibres, i.e. threads or filaments that can easily break off during handling and potentially be inhaled, absorbed or ingested.
A sample or specimen with smaller parts peeling off from its surface. The term may also refer to the breakage of storage materials (e.g. plastic bags).
A sample or specimen containing inflammable, flammable or flame-sustaining materials, whether naturally, or as part of treatment or storage materials.
A sample or specimen that is physically vulnerable or prone to breakage, whether due to material, form, shape, or condition.
A sample or specimen mounted on and surrounded by a rigid structure that supports it.
A sample or specimen which has undergone past repair by gluing on broken elements or sections, where the area of repair may become a future vulnerability or hazard

A sample or specimen considered of good preservation, quality and/or usefulness, i.e. is intact, structurally sound and performing its intended purpose, with few or no cosmetic imperfections, and needing no repair other than minor/routine maintenance.
A sample or specimen that presents some form of hazard to humans or the storage environment.

A sample or specimen which requires special tools or multiple persons to move due to its mass, or a sample or specimen of greater density than commonly anticipated based on its dimensions, potentially complicating its safe movement.
A sample or specimen (usually core or cuttings) containing natural hydrocarbon (e.g. oil) that can leak while in storage or during handling.
A sample or specimen that is vulnerable to humidity fluctuations, or which has a propensity to absorb or attract water or other fluids from the surrounding environment, resulting in specimen damage.
A sample or specimen representing part of an original whole, due to the loss of part of the object.

A sample or specimen containing mercury, either as an element or a compound (e.g. in sulfide minerals), and forming naturally or as part of storage (e.g. concentration of toxic vapours in enclosed spaces). Mercury is harmful to human health if inhaled, ingested or absorbed.
A sample or specimen fixed permanently or semi-permanently to a surface, pedestal or wall, or in a frame, or encapsulated within a suitable medium.

A sample or specimen that consists of several associated but distinct parts, which should be stored and/or assessed together as a single whole. This differs from broken or segmented samples or specimens in that the multi-part nature is a standard presentation of the object in question, such as disarticulated bones of a single skeleton.
A sample or specimen likely to react (tarnish) and lose its lustre if exposed to air.
A sample or specimen that is vulnerable to degradation when exposed to long-term light or UV exposure.
A sample or specimen that contains minerals harmful to human health when breathed, touched or ingested.
A sample or specimen whose surface is made smooth and shiny to improve its aesthetics, enhance details of its external/internal texture or in preparation for analytical work.

A sample or specimen considered of poor preservation, quality and/or usefulness, i.e. it is no longer performing its intended purpose, shows signs of imminent failure or breakdown and/or requires major repair/replacement.

A sample or specimen, often core, that has been wrapped, sealed, immersed or otherwise conserved separate from other materials, either in preparation for specific analyses or to preserve a specific component or condition.

A sample or specimen with radiation dose quantities greater than 50 Sv/h, requiring assessment for storage suitability and precautionary measures. Samples with readings greater than 100 Sv/h will not be stored in a GSWA collection.
A sample or specimen needing to be preserved at low temperatures, i.e. below room temperature or in freezing conditions (e.g. organic specimens or ice cores).

A sample or specimen which has undergone some form of past restoration, where the point of repair may become a future vulnerability or hazard, or detract from the value (monetary or other) of the sample/specimen.
A sample or specimen containing high levels of salt minerals, including halite or gypsum. Halite can have a corrosive effect on storage materials.

A sample or specimen which has been divided into multiple associated parts as part of collection, storage or analysis. This differs from multi-part samples or specimens in that the segmentation of the object is unnatural; and from broken samples or specimens in that segmentation is intentional and for a stated purpose. Segmentation of material does not necessarily correspond to a degradation of specimen usefulness, and therefore a transition from fair to poor general condition may apply.
A sample or specimen representing part of an original whole, where some parts or components have been split from the item and reside with other individuals or organizations.

A sample or specimen whose original shape (or form) has been modified/altered via one or multiple processes, usually to improve its appearance or increase its value. These includes procedures such as faceting, tumbling, or carving.
A sample or specimen with pointed, sharp or abrasive surfaces, which may become a hazard when contacted without protective equipment.

A sample or specimen that is kept behind a protective surface/enclosure due to its hazardous nature. Typically used for radioactive specimens protected by a lead shield to minimize exposure to radiation, or isolated to contain degassing.
A sample or specimen stored entirely within a liquid (e.g. fresh water or brine) in order to maintain its form, chemistry or physical properties

A sample or specimen that has lost some of its lustre, usually as a result of exposure to air and moisture. Tarnish is a thin layer of corrosion that forms over some metals and minerals as their outermost layer undergoes a chemical reaction when exposed to non-metallic compounds (e.g. oxygen or sulfur dioxide). Tarnish is commonly a metal oxide, and can be referred to as patina when applied to copper-based metals and toning when referring to coins.
A sample or specimen that is vulnerable to temperature fluctuations, or which has a propensity to dry out or freeze in extreme temperature environments, resulting in specimen damage.

A sample or specimen whose packaging or storage materials have been flagged for one-off, periodic or scheduled replacement. One-off replacement is generally required when samples/specimens are transported within materials unsuitable for long-term storage. Periodic or scheduled replacement of storage materials may be required when the sample/specimen has a property that accelerates the decay of storage materials (such as salty core), or for storage materials that are known to degrade over time.

A core whose trays have been flagged for one-off, periodic or scheduled replacement. One-off replacement is generally required when samples/specimens are transported within trays unsuitable for long-term storage or are difficult to maintain. Periodic or scheduled replacement of trays may be required when the sample/specimen has a property that accelerates the decay of storage materials (such as salty core).
A sample or specimen that has not undergone any cleaning or purification process.
A sample or specimen that needs to be preserved in a space devoid of matter, commonly to avoid sample contamination.
A sample or specimen of unusual proportions which may require special tools, multiple persons or careful planning to move safely.
A sample or specimen that is vulnerable to specific forms of non-physical degradation, such as humidity or temperature fluctuations, light conditions, and contacting chemicals or treatments.

A sample or specimen that has been cleaned or purified by rinsing (usually with water), and subsequently dried. The process is typically applied to drillcores and ditch cuttings to remove mud, dirt and dust, but can also refer to the removal of impurities and contaminants from a sample/specimen using a solvent (often water, distilled water or a detergent) in preparation for analysis or further usage.
A sample or specimen where the loss in object integrity is due to physical abrasion either intrinsically, during the collection process, or during storage or analysis procedures.
A sample or specimen held at a storage location in an archived state, i.e. the sample/specimen has been fully assessed, prepared and recorded.
A sample flagged for permanent archiving, but currently in temporary storage awaiting registration.
A sample collected from a sampling location and held in temporary storage prior to examination, analysis, or transfer to permanent or semi-permanent storage.

No part or amount of the sample or specimen remains extant as a result of intentional (e.g. analysis or processing) events. This excludes any child materials developed from the original destroyed sample. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be archived.

A sample or specimen removed from storage or not retained permanently, based on a perceived lack of space, the material's unsuitability for storage (e.g. hazardous), poor condition, and/or limited utility or applicability to ongoing studies. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be archived.

No part or amount of the sample or specimen remains extant as a result of unintentional (e.g. accidental damage) events. This excludes any child materials developed from the original destroyed sample. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be archived.

Sample or specimen has been intentionally removed from formal collections due to a perceived lack of space, the material's unsuitability for storage (e.g. hazardous), poor condition, and/or limited utility or applicability to ongoing studies (e.g. unknown origin/provenance). Disposed material is generally placed in the trash or informally donated due to a lack of value. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be archived.

Sample or specimen has been permanently transferred to another organization through mutual agreement or arrangement. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be archived.
The sample or specimen is being moved between locations.
A sample or specimen moved outside its registered storage facility on the basis of a formal agreement with a person or institution, usually for display or study purposes.
Sample or specimen brought in temporarily from an outside source or organization under a limited-term agreement.

Sample or specimen is outside its registered storage facility on the basis of a loan agreement with an external researcher or organization, where that agreement has a longer than standard duration. This is common for material loaned for display in static galleries, where the loan may be reviewed and renewed periodically in lieu of a fixed-term agreement.
Location of sample or specimen is not known. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be preserved, and retrieved should the sample/specimen be recovered.

A sample or specimen held in a museum or other location for display, education and/or demonstration purposes. Displays can be located indoors or outdoors. May refer to specimens on loan that are on public display.
Sample or specimen is outside its registered storage facility on the basis of a limited-term agreement with an external researcher or organization.
Sample or specimen is outside its registered storage facility on the basis of a limited-term agreement with an internal staff member.

Sample or specimen is outside its registered storage facility on the basis of an agreement with an external researcher or organization, where there is no time limit set on the loan's duration and no program of loan review. Permanent loans are similar to donations, except that the loaning organization retains the right to recall the sample/specimen if required.
The sample or specimen is at a laboratory, university, or other facility external to its registered storage facility to undergo processing or analysis.

A sample or specimen placed in temporary or permanent isolation due to suspected or proven contamination or safety concerns. Isolation can be either spatial (separate cupboard) or engineered (suitable storage material, e.g. lead shield).

Sample or specimen that has been returned to the country or community of origin along with the unconditional rights to that object. This may include digital restitution, i.e. where only images and documentations are returned to the country or community of origin.

A sample collected from material (such as core or cuttings) held in the organization's collections as part of a departmental agreement or permit, normally by an external party for destructive analysis and research. Sampled-under-agreement also applies to any derivative samples/specimens and remnant materials, as well as related data, images and reports  the return/submission of which is a mandatory requirement of the agreement.

A sample or specimen removed without permission or legal right and without any intention of return, and its whereabouts are unknown. Any corresponding records in the collection management system(s) should be preserved, and retrieved should the sample/specimen be recovered.

A sample or specimen that is being stored on a temporary basis, either for a set period or until a specific condition is met. This holding may be in preparation for destruction, transfer to another organization, or as a result of legislative or legal processes (such as confiscation of illegally obtained materials or evidence for an investigation).

An obsolete term, no longer regulated by the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), for a designated specimen of opposite sex to the holotype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN).

A sample or specimen that has been mentioned or listed in a formal (peer-reviewed) scientific publication, but not imaged (drawn or photographed) or formally described. This term is only applicable to non-type samples or specimens.

An obsolete term no longer regulated by the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), formerly used for either syntype or paratype, but that should not now be used in zoological nomenclature. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN).

In the International Mineralogical Association's mineral nomenclature scheme (IMA), specimens (designated by the author) as those used to obtain quantitative data for the original description. Specimens examined only visually should not be considered cotypes.

A sample or specimen to which a name or identification and full description has been applied in a formal (peer-reviewed) publication. 'Described and published' can be interchangeable with 'figured' if a specimen is illustrated in the primary reference; illustration is common in primary descriptions, but is not a requirement, especially where large collections of specimens are being described together.

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a specimen or illustration selected to serve as an interpretative type when the holotype, lectotype, or previously designated neotype, or all original material associated with a validly published name, cannot be identified for the purpose of the precise application of the name to a taxon. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a living isolate obtained from the type of a name when this is a culture permanently preserved in a metabolically inactive state. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

A sample or specimen that has been imaged (drawn or photographed) in a formal (peer-reviewed) scientific publication. Imaging may be in service of demonstrating the specimen's identity, preservation, interpretation, or any other purpose; these specimens are often conserved alongside type specimens due to their highly representative nature, and/or selection to illustrate particular or significant features. 'Figured' is partially interchangeable with 'described and published' and/or 'formally identified' in that specimen illustrations are essentially independent of whether a specimen is mentioned, formally identified and/or fully described within a publication.

A specimen to which a name or identification has been applied in a formal (peer-reviewed) publication, but that was not described in detail in that same publication. 'Formally identified' can be interchangeable with 'figured' if a specimen is illustrated in the same reference, although illustration is more common for cases where material is being formally described.

In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), one or more preparations consisting of directly related individuals representing distinct stages in the life cycle, which together form the name-bearing type in an extant species of protistan. A hapantotype, while a series of individuals, is a holotype that must not be restricted by lectotype selection; however, if a hapantotype is found to contain individuals of more than one species, components may be excluded until it contains individuals of only one species. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), the one specimen or illustration indicated as the nomenclatural type by the author(s) of a name of a new species or infraspecific taxon or, when no type was indicated, used by the author(s) when preparing the account of the new taxon.

In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), the single specimen (except in the case of a hapantotype) designated or otherwise fixed as the name-bearing type of a nominal species or subspecies when the nominal taxon is established.

In the International Mineralogical Association's mineral nomenclature scheme (IMA), a single specimen (designated by the author) from which all the data for the original description were obtained. Where portions of such a specimen have been sent to other museums for preservation, the author will designate each of these as part of the holotype.

A specimen that has never been mentioned, named, described or identified in a formal (peer-reviewed) publication, but has had an informal name applied, whether in the field, by a curator or visiting expert, or in an informal publication (such as unpublished or internal reports, or theses).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a duplicate specimen of the epitype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a duplicate specimen of the lectotype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a duplicate specimen of the neotype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), the same name based on the same type, published independently at different times perhaps by different authors. Note: only the earliest isonym has nomenclatural status. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a duplicate specimen of a syntype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a duplicate specimen of the holotype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), one specimen or illustration designated from the original material as the nomenclatural type if the name was published without a holotype, or if the holotype is lost or destroyed, or if a type is found to belong to more than one taxon.
In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), a syntype designated as the single name-bearing type specimen subsequent to the establishment of a nominal species or subspecies.

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), a specimen or illustration selected to serve as nomenclatural type if no original material is extant or as long as it is missing.

In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), the single specimen designated as the name-bearing type of a nominal species or subspecies when there is a need to define the nominal taxon objectively and no name-bearing type is believed to be extant. If stability and universality are threatened, because an existing name-bearing type is either taxonomically inadequate or not in accord with the prevailing usage of a name, the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature may use its plenary power to set aside that type and designate a neotype.

In the International Mineralogical Association's mineral nomenclature scheme (IMA), a specimen chosen by the author of a redefinition or re-examination of a species to represent the species when the holotype or cotypes cannot be found. It must be shown that every attempt has been made to locate the originally described material. Neotypes can also be designated when examination of all holotypes and cotypes has shown that the definitive unit-cell parameters and chemical composition cannot be experimentally determined. All neotypes require the approval of the Commission on New Minerals and Mineral Names of the International Mineralogical Association.
A specimen that has never been designated as a nomenclatural type or type specimen, of any variety, in a formal (peer-reviewed) scientific publication or work.

In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), each specimen of a former syntype series remaining after the designation of a lectotype. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN).

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), any specimen cited in the protologue that is neither the holotype nor an isotype, nor one of the syntypes if in the protologue two or more specimens were simultaneously designated as types.
In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), each specimen of a type series other than the holotype.
A sample or specimen that is considered a key reference or exemplar for a specific locality, stratigraphic unit, geological feature or class of geological object.
The status of a specimen in relation to how it has been portrayed in the scientific literature (e.g. figured, cited)

In the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) and the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN), any specimen cited in the protologue when there is no holotype, or any of two or more specimens simultaneously designated in the protologue as types.

In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), each specimen of a type series from which neither a holotype nor a lectotype has been designated. The syntypes collectively constitute the name-bearing type.

An obsolete term, no longer regulated by the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), for a specimen originating from the type locality of the species or subspecies to which it is thought to belong, whether or not the specimen is part of the type series. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN).

In the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), the series of specimens on which the original author bases a new nominal species-group taxon. In the absence of a holotype designation, any such specimen is eligible for subsequent designation as the name-bearing type (lectotype); pending lectotype designation, all the specimens of the type series are syntypes and collectively they constitute the name-bearing type. Excluded from the type series are any specimens that the original author expressly excludes or refers to as distinct variants, or doubtfully includes in the taxon. No equivalent exists in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN) .

A fossil specimen (or series of specimens) designated as the object or element to which a name or definition is attached, and as the objective standard of reference whereby the application of the name of a nominal taxon can be determined, for the purposes of biological or paleontological taxonomy. Type specimens are generally divided into primary (e.g. holotype, lectotype, syntype, neotype) or secondary (e.g. paratype, paralectotype) types, with primary types being of greater scientific importance.

A specimen designated as the element to which the name of a taxon is permanently attached, under the provisions of the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants (ICN; Shenzen Code, 2018); the type specimen is not necessarily the most typical or representative element of a taxon. Type specimens are generally divided into primary (e.g. holotype, lectotype, syntype, neotype) or secondary (e.g. paratype) types, with primary types being of greater scientific importance. As part of the requirements for taxonomic validity, type specimens are recommended to be held in public collections with a policy of giving bona fide researchers access to deposited material, and should be scrupulously conserved. Note that although microbialites are officially excluded from the ICN, the Proposed International Code of Microbialite Nomenclature (PICMN, Grey and Awramik, 2020) specifies that 'Provisions in the Shenzhen Code Articles 9 and 10 should be followed in designating and naming microbialite types, and for reference to terminology relating to different types (e.g. lectotype, paratype, etc.) and the rules governing their use' (point 11, p. 196), with that advice followed herein.

A specimen (or series of specimens) that provides the objective standard of reference whereby the application of the name of a nominal taxon can be determined, under the provisions of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN; 1999, with 2012 amendments). Type specimens are generally divided into primary (e.g. holotype, lectotype, syntype, neotype) or secondary (e.g. paratype, paralectotype) types, with primary types being of greater scientific importance. Recognizing that name-bearing types are international standards of reference, type specimens should be deposited in an institution that maintains a research collection, with proper facilities for preserving them and making them accessible for study.

Reference sample of a named meteorite deposited in an approved type-specimen repository and meeting the minimum mass requirements, as set forward by the Meteorite Nomenclature Committee (also known as NomCom) of The Meteorological Society. NomCom regulations require a meteorite type specimen to be a minimum mass of 20 g or 20% of the total mass, whichever is the lesser amount. Suitable type-specimen repositories are described as 'institutions that have well-curated meteorite collections and long-standing commitments to such curation' (section 7.1). Unlike other nomenclatural codes, meteorites only recognize a single classification of type specimen.

Reference samples for the definition of mineral species as per the mineral nomenclature scheme of the International Mineralogical Association (IMA). Although a vast number of minerals, especially those discovered in antiquity, have no designated type minerals, modern practise is to deposit all type minerals in a 'non-private, institutional, professionally curated, research-oriented' museum, with the type status of each specimen clearly designated.

A low area in the Earths crust, of tectonic origin, underlain by a substantial thickness of sedimentary rocks that possess unifying characteristics of stratigraphy and structure due to their deposition during a regionally restricted episode of crustal depression or a related sequence of such episodes. As well as being applied to the deposited rocks, or to their outcrop area after erosion, the term is used also for the actual crustal depression in which they accumulated. Sedimentary basins range in size from small continental basins to large oceanic basins. The essential element of the concept is the tectonic creation of relief, to provide both a source of sediment and a relatively low place for the deposition of that sediment (after Miall, 2000). In the Western Australian context, most Precambrian basins are tectonic components of either cratons or orogens, whereas Phanerozoic basins do not have an immediate tectonic relationship to any orogen.

A part of the Earth's continental lithosphere with a thick lithospheric root that has remained tectonically stable for a long period of time. Whether or not an amalgamation of components constitutes a craton depends on the point in geological time at which the overall tectonic configuration is considered. In the Western Australian context, cratons usually comprise component terranes, but can also represent amalgamation(s) of older cratons bounded by orogenic sutures. In the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) Explanatory Notes System, the latter are ranked as a higher level tectonic unit type to preserve the identity of the original cratons. The nature of tectonic processes that modify cratons, including rifting, accretion and removal of the lithospheric root, result in boundaries between cratons, orogens and basins that can be either sharp or gradational, such that the spatial limit of cratons both at surface and at depth may not always be precisely defined. In the global literature, cratons can be referred to as shields, and basins covering cratons as platforms; these terms are not used by GSWA.

A tectonically bounded body of rock of regional extent within a craton, characterized by a geological history different from that of contiguous tectonic fragments. In the Western Australian context, a cratonic terrane is a coherent, tectonically bounded part of a craton that has moved over a substantial distance into juxtaposition with geologically unrelated parts. Not to be confused with terrain, which refers to topographic features of the Earth's surface.
A hierarchical subdivision of cratonic terranes based on similarities in stratigraphy, metamorphic history and structural evolution.

Lithotectonic units typical of Archean terrains, commonly referred to in the literature  but the use of these terms as formally named tectonic units is to be avoided. Greenstone belts are elongate or belt-like volcanosedimentary complexes within cratons that are characterized by dark-green, altered or metamorphosed mafic and ultramafic igneous rock, such as basalt, gabbro and komatiite, that owe their colour to the presence of chlorite, actinolite or epidote. An individual belt may contain the deformed and metamorphosed rocks of one or more volcano-sedimentary sequences. Granitic complexes are tectonically domed expanses of granitic rocks containing granitic intrusions of widely different ages and mantled by greenstone belts (Van Kranendonk et al., 2004).

A lithotectonic subdivision in Western Australia, used to identify an exposed group of rocks from an older tectonic unit that is surrounded by rocks from a younger tectonic units (inlier), or an exposed group of rocks from a younger tectonic unit that is surrounded by rocks from an older tectonic units (outlier). These are not tectonic units per se, but are commonly singled out both geographically and geologically. The Geological Survey of Western Australia's convention is to always list the broader unit inliers/outliers are part of in their name (e.g. Pinjarra Orogen, Leeuwin Inlier; or Bonaparte Basin, Mount Rob Outlier).

An orogen (orogenic system, orogenic belt) is a linear or arcuate region in Earths lithosphere where a mountain belt is created by tectonic processes involving deformation, regional metamorphism and associated magmatism, usually caused by convergence ( subduction, accretion and/or collision) between two tectonic plates or major crustal blocks. The rocks of an orogen may include deformed and reworked parts of older (pre-orogenic) lithosphere, as well as new (synorogenic) volcanic, sedimentary and igneous rocks. An orogen is conceived to have been established by a distinct tectonic event of known duration, but it is also possible for orogens to be reactivated during later tectonic episodes, and they normally remain as permanent zones of weakness in the Earths crust. A named orogen includes any associated sedimentary rocks, which may not be strongly deformed or metamorphosed, but whose deposition was directly related to the formation of the orogen. Geosyncline is an alternate obsolete term not recommended for use.

The exterior area of an orogenic belt where deformation occurs without significant metamorphism. Generally the foreland is closer to the continental interior than other portions of the orogenic belt are.

A smaller hierarchical subdivision of a tectonic orogenic foreland that presents some unifying features or a geological history that distinguishes it from that of adjacent components of the tectonic province.

A hierarchical subdivision of a larger tectonic unit (commonly an orogen, but also a craton or a superterrane) that presents some unifying features or a geological history that distinguishes from that of adjacent areas within the larger tectonic unit. The concept includes seismic provinces, i.e. discrete volumes of middlelower crust that cannot be traced to the surface and whose seismic reflectivity is different from that of vertical or horizontally adjoining provinces (Korsch and Doublier, 2016).
A smaller hierarchical subdivision of a tectonic province that presents some unifying features or a geological history that distinguishes from that of adjacent terranes/zones within the province.

A discrete volume of middle to lower crust that cannot be traced to the surface, and whose crustal reflectivity is different to that of laterally or vertically adjoining provinces (Korsch and Doublier, 2016).
A hierarchical term applied to separate depocentres within a basin that are separated from other parts of the basin by tectonic/structural element(s) such as faults or basement highs.
A smaller component of a sub-basin, e.g. ridge, arch, terrace, etc.

A tectonic suite represents the expression of a tectonothermal event that resulted in the formation of a lithodemic suite, i.e. a group of igneous rocks of the same age that can be shown, or reasonably inferred, to be related to the same parental magma.

A superbasin is a hierarchical term applied to a group of largely interconnected or associated sedimentary basins of the same or similar age. Its component basins may be separated or partially separated by tectonic elements that define 'boundaries' between them, or they may have been subjected to somewhat different geological influences.

The tectonic unit representing the expression of a specific tectonothermal event that resulted in the formation of a lithodemic supersuite, i.e. an assemblage of igneous rocks of any composition that formed as a result of volcanoplutonic episodes involving either addition of new crust or remelting of existing crust.
An amalgamation of different cratonic terranes (i.e. fault-bounded tectonostratigraphic terranes), into a larger structural entity typical of cratonic areas.

A smaller hierarchical subdivision of a tectonic province terrane/zone that presents some unifying features or a geological history that distinguishes from that of adjacent components of the tectonic province.

A high-level tectonic or lithotectonic unit type that encompasses large tectonic components of the State of Western Australia (e.g. West Australian Craton) or facilitates grouping of certain elements (e.g. large igneous provinces and dyke swarms).

The highest-ranking type of 'tectonic' unit in the State of Western Australia. It encompasses the geographical extent of the State (i.e. an area bounded by latitudes 8.00S and 40.00S, and longitudes 102.00E and 132.00E). It has no geological significance, other than being defined for the purpose of allowing all other tectonic subdivisions of the State to be grouped within a single hierarchy.

The first official national Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD), proclaimed in the Australian Commonwealth Gazette No. 84 of 6 October 1966. Area of use: Australia onshore and offshore, and Papua New Guinea onshore.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 49: Australia  onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 108E and 114E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 50: onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 114E and 120E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 52: Australia  onshore and offshore between 120E and 126E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 52: Australia  onshore and offshore between 126E and 132E.

An update to the official Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD), adopted and in effect from 1984. The AGD84 national system replaced AGD66 but was officially adopted only in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia; it was later replaced by GDA94. Area of use: Australia  Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, federal areas offshore west of 129E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 49: Australia  onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 108E and 114E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 50: onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 114E and 120E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a Transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 51: Australia  onshore and offshore between 120E and 126E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 52: Western Australia east of 126E, South Australia west of 132E, offshore federal waters between 126E and 129E.

The Australian national map projection accompanying AGD66. The Australian Map Grid (AMG) is derived from a transverse Mercator projection of latitudes and longitudes on the Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD66). The AMG corresponds with the Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid, with a system of rectangular grid coordinates (eastings and northings) expressed in metres. AMG zones are numbered from zone 47 (with central meridian 99E) to zone 58 (with central meridian 165E). Each zone is 6 wide with a half degree of overlapping.

The Australian national map projection accompanying AGD84. The Australian Map Grid (AMG) is derived from a transverse Mercator projection of latitudes and longitudes on the Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD84). The AMG corresponds with the Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid, with a system of rectangular grid coordinates (eastings and northings) expressed in metres. AMG zones are numbered from zone 47 (with central meridian 99E) to zone 58 (with central meridian 165E). Each zone is 6 wide with a half degree of overlapping.

Between 1858 and 1966, geodetic surveys in Australia were computed on either a jurisdiction (state or territory) or regional basis using more than four different spheroids and as many as twenty coordinate origins. In Western Australia, the most widely used geodatum and ellipsoid since 1945 was the Clarke 1858; the State was covered by four separate longitudinal zones, numbered 1 (one) to 4 (four), each with a 5 longitude width.
Zone 1 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 113.5E to 118.5E.
Zone 2 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 118.5E to 123.5E.
Zone 3 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 123.5E to 128.5E.
Zone 4 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 128.5E to 133.5E.

The official geodetic datum adopted nationally in June 2020. GDA2020 is a coordinate reference system with an origin that coincides with a determination of the centre of mass of the earth, hence the term geocentric. GDA2020 is a plate-fixed or static coordinate datum based on the International Terrestrial Reference Frame 1992 (ITRF92), held at the reference epoch of 1 January 2020. Area of use is the same as GDA94, i.e. all the areas contained within Australias marine jurisdiction (within 200 nautical miles of Australia) and its external territories, and the areas of Australias continental shelf beyond 200 nautical miles as confirmed by the United Nations Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf: Australia including Lord Howe Island, Macquarie Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island; all onshore and offshore.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 49: Australia  onshore and offshore west of 114E; Christmas Island  offshore east of 108E.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 50: Australia  onshore and offshore between 114E and 120E.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 51: Australia  onshore and offshore between 120E and 126E.
