The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 52: Australia  onshore and offshore between 126E and 132E.

The official geodetic datum adopted nationally in January 2000. GDA94 replaced the Australian Geodetic Datum 1966 (AGD66) and Australian Geodetic Datum 1984 (AGD84), and was later replaced by GDA2020. GDA94 is a coordinate reference system whose origin coincides with a determination of the centre of mass of the earth, hence the term geocentric. GDA94 is a plate-fixed or static coordinate datum based on the International Terrestrial Reference Frame 1992 (ITRF92), held at the reference epoch of 1 January 1994. The distance between the origin points of GDA94 and AGD is approximately 200 metres. Area of use: Australia including Lord Howe Island, Macquarie Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island; all onshore and offshore.

The accompanying national map projection to MGA94, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. A local grid is a locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary, fixed point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted, instead of using a national or global datum.

Locally defined coordinate reference systems, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted. The coordinates of the base station point are known.

Locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted. The coordinates of the base station point are not known.

The standard map projection associated with GDA2020 is the Map Grid of Australia 2020 (MGA2020), a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to the internationally standardized Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. The UTM system has been used with the GRS80 ellipsoid and Geocentric Datum of Australia (GDA2020) latitudes and longitudes to define MGA2020.

The standard map projection associated with GDA94 is the Map Grid of Australia 1994 (MGA94), a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to the internationally standardized Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. At that time the recommended reference ellipsoid was also changed from ANS to the Geodetic Reference System 1980 (GRS80) ellipsoid. Area of use: Australia including Lord Howe Island, Macquarie Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island; all onshore and offshore.

The Universal Transverse Mercator coordinate system (usually simply called UTM) is a map projection system (not a projection) designed to assign coordinates to locations on the surface of the Earth. It divides the Earth into 60 zones, each 6 of longitude in width. These longitudinal zones are numbered 1 to 60  east from longitude 180; the polar regions south of 80S and north of 84N are excluded. Each zone is characterized by a central meridian; as a result, within a zone nothing is more than 3 from the central meridian and therefore locations, shapes and sizes and directions between all features are very accurate. The UTM sometimes also uses 20 latitude bands, each 8 high, numbered A to Z (with O and I not being used)  north from Antarctica. The UTM was developed in 1947 by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO).
The coordinate reference system is not known or specified.
The 49th UTM zone spanning from longitudes 108E to 114E. Central meridian 111E.
The 50th UTM zone spanning from longitudes 114E to 120E. Central meridian 115E.
The 51st UTM zone spanning from longitudes 120E to 126E. Central meridian 121E.
The 49th UTM zone spanning from longitudes 126E to 132E. Central meridian 129E.

The World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) is the reference frame used by the Global Positioning System (GPS). It was developed by the US Department of Defense and is maintained by the US National Geospatial Intelligence Agency (NGA). WGS84 defines an Earth-centred, Earth-fixed coordinate reference system with an origin that coincides with a determination of the centre of mass of the earth, and a geodetic datum. The datum defines meridian 0 as the International Earth Rotation and Reference System Service (IERS) Reference Meridian and the datum surface is an oblate spheroid. Officially adopted as the world geodetic datum in 1984, WGS84 is a dynamic reference frame. WGS84 has been revised several times since its conception and is at present aligned at the centimetre level to the International Terrestrial Reference Frame (ITRF), which generally ensures scientific integrity and compatibility with international standards and conventions. At the beginning of each year, the NGA updates station coordinates to account for plate tectonic motion. This means that WGS84 coordinates derived by users from GPS measurements will appear to move over time. In January 1994, GDA94 and ITRF were coincident, but since Australia is moving up to 7cm per year in a northeasterly direction, there was a 1.8 m difference between the two systems in 2020  for applications that require uncertainty better than 5 m, GDA94 and WGS84/ITRF cannot be considered equivalent. Area of use: world.
The 49th Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 108E and 114E, southern hemisphere between 80S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; Indonesia.
The 50th Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 114E and 120E, southern hemisphere between 80S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; Indonesia.
The 51st Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 120E and 126E, southern hemisphere between 80S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; East Timor; Indonesia.
The 49th Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 126E and 132E, southern hemisphere between 80S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; East Timor; Indonesia.
